SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On Monday I received three questions and two supplementary questions on aged care, and on Tuesday in a question Senator Forshaw quoted from a statement he said I had made in the Senate the day before. I assumed that Senator Forshaw was referring to an answer I gave in relation to a question from Senator Campbell. In that answer I referred in some detail to bonds. As a result, in my answer yesterday I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will repeat that that statement was in relation to the payments of bonds, as Senator Forshaw well knows.

After reading a transcript of Hansard last night, I discovered that Senator Forshaw was in fact quoting from another answer I had given on Monday and not that answer. Clearly in my answer on Monday I was referring to fees.

In checking that quote from Monday, I also discovered that my reference to 40 per cent of pensionable people in nursing homes who do not pay additional fees was incorrect. In fact, it is 65 per cent of people in nursing homes who are fully pensionable and do not pay any additional fees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Senate, by resolution, required Senator Alston to table the first ACIL Economics report on waterfront reform and related material by 5 p.m. yesterday. He did not. Not only did he fail to table the material required by the Senate, he did not even bother to give this chamber the courtesy of an explanation. There was a call to my office by one of his staff after 5 p.m. to advise that the government planned not to observe the return to order.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not as if this request by the Senate came out of the blue. The documents that are the subject of this return to order were first sought by the Senate through the estimates process in August this year. We were told in those hearings that the ACIL consultancy was commissioned by the department. We were told that the department let the tender and we were told that the work had been completed and the department had the report. But we were denied the document and we were denied important details relating to the second contract let without a tender process to this company. Even though there was nearly $700,000 of taxpayers' money spent or committed on the ACIL consultancies, the very committee process established to scrutinise the expenditure of public money was denied access to the material.

Last Thursday the Senate considered a motion that required Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, to table the ACIL material denied to us in estimates. In a statement Senator Alston advised the Senate that the material was commercial‐in‐confidence. He said it was cabinet‐in‐confidence, and he added that its release could put people's physical safety at risk. Given Senator Alston's revelation, the matter was postponed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: I have listened to Senator O'Brien for a couple of minutes and I think this is an important matter that should not be dealt with by leave. I would think these matters, if they are to be raised, should best be raised when the minister responsible is here and able to respond. I have been informed by our whip that Senator Alston has been given leave till midday today and would ask that perhaps Senator O'Brien delay any activity on this matter until Senator Alston is here and is able to respond.

—On the point of order, Madam President: while Senator Campbell seeks to make that point, I think it is fair to say that Senator Alston was not, as I understand it, on leave when he was due to report to the Senate, Senator O'Brien has not been given the courtesy of any response to the order of the Senate and I think it is quite within Senator O'Brien's rights to raise the matter. If the government had actually taken some action to respond to the return to order and done Senator O'Brien the courtesy of consulting with him, perhaps we would not have got into this problem. But I think Senator O'Brien has taken the only opportunity available to him, due to the lack of courtesy and lack of response displayed by the government.

—On the point of order, Madam President. I do not believe that there is a point of order, but let me say this: if what Senator Campbell is saying in his point of order is that he is offering a chance to continue at a time when Senator Alston is in the chamber, namely, at or shortly after 12 midday—and Senator Campbell is not indicating either way at the moment—I would be happy to consider that if that is a proper process to deal with the matter and if that is in order and acceptable to the Senate. However, if that is not acceptable, I would seek to continue my remarks now. I would indicate that it might be appropriate for Senator Alston's office to contact my office and discuss this matter prior to that time as well.
—Senator Campbell, are you still seeking the call?
—I should seek to speak by leave, which is probably what I should have done at the time.
—On the point of order—

—There is no point of order. There is no further discussion required on that. I appreciate that, by leave, senators may wish to contribute, with a view to working out a solution to the matter before us.

—by leave—I will respond to Senator Chris Evans and Senator O'Brien. As I recall, Senator Alston made his intentions quite clear in relation to this return to order, and the fact that it was not replied to may not have come as a surprise to Senator O'Brien.

BREAK.PARA: On the specific point raised by Senator O'Brien, what I am foreshadowing is that the coalition for its part would grant leave at an appropriate time. If we were in the middle of a piece of legislation at 12 o'clock, I would not seek to interrupt that, but, at the nearest possible time after that, the coalition for its part would grant you leave to continue the statement that you are making, Senator O'Brien.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is of concern to me to hear Senator Campbell indicate that we should not be surprised.
—I didn't say that. I said that Senator O'Brien would not be surprised.

—Perhaps Senator O'Brien might or might not be surprised by Senator Alston's actions in this regard. It is nonetheless of concern to me that the Manager of Government Business in this chamber should suggest that the government is seeking to defy an order of the Senate. I think the Senate is entitled to an explanation, and in what has been said this morning I have heard not one word about the government's willingness to come in here and explain to the Senate why it is defying an order of the Senate. All I have heard is that Senator O'Brien might get a phone call. The government has an obligation to explain to the Senate why it is in defiance of an order of the Senate, and I think we are entitled to that explanation at 12 o'clock. In that way the Senate can determine what action it takes.

—by leave—in relation to this matter, my concern about the proposal is that we may not deal with this matter before consideration of matters of public interest at 12.45. I am happy that the debate not be interrupted precisely at midday—shortly thereafter would be acceptable. I do not want to interrupt a speaker or a particular matter but I want to proceed to that matter before 12.45, so that we can deal with it and conclude it, as far as we can, before 12.45. If we can have that assurance, I will be happy with that.

—by leave—It is not fair to the minister, who is not in the place at the moment, for me to make some sort of commitment about exactly when that might be. I have said to the chamber that Senator Alston would want to respond to this. Senator Carr has ignored the fact that I have said that. Senator Alston is not in the building at the moment. Senator Carr was not listening or paid no attention when Senator Alston set out his response when the matter of the order was being made. He went into some detail about the fact that the government regarded a whole series of the documents as matters that should not be tabled in the Senate.
—So you are going to defy the order, is that what you are saying?

—Senator Carr, Senator Alston will, in his time, respond. Clearly the Australian Labor Party do not want to ensure that Senator Alston is able to listen to what Senator O'Brien says here today. They want to continue to speak. I am not going to lock him into it, so, Senator O'Brien, I am very happy for you to seek leave now to continue with your statement if you wish to do so. We will get a copy of the Hansard , and Senator Alston will respond in his own good time.
—Senator O'Brien does not need leave to continue with his remarks. Leave was given to him to speak and, if he wishes to continue, he may do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Given what I take to be an open‐ended comment about Senator Alston's response and the timetable, I had thought that what was being said was that I should speak when he was due to be back in the building.
—Senator Carr rejected that.

—No, I made a specific statement in relation to a proposal and asked for certain assurances—not that the debate be interrupted precisely at 12 o'clock but that the matter be dealt with very shortly after that and certainly before other items on the Notice Paper take precedence. I am not seeking to take other people's time in relation to matters of public interest discussion. Senator Camp bell is now saying, `We can't give you a guarantee that Senator Alston will necessarily be here, because he does have leave until midday.' I was happy to delay until then, but what Senator Campbell says now is that he does not know what Senator Alston's timetable is and cannot be sure that he would be available at that time, and so I now accept his statement—
—That's fair enough.
—Is that fair enough?

—If you will let me finish—that I should continue my remarks now and that Senator Alston will respond later, and we will continue the debate later. But I believe it is appropriate that I put on the record, in continuing what I said, that I wrote to Senator Alston last Thursday, following the statement that he made, representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). In that letter, which has been incorporated in Hansard , I sought clarification of the alarming matters he raised in the Senate last Thursday. My letter provided him with an opportunity to justify his claims, and Minister Alston replied on Friday. Again, his response has been incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: However, I think it is fair to say that he failed to clarify a number of the key issues in his statement. We have no idea as to the nature of the commercial damage to the Commonwealth or others that might result from the release of the material. We have no idea as to the nature or extent of the damage that might be caused to Commonwealth relationships with the states, and we have no idea as to the validity of the minister's claim that people's safety might be threatened if this material is released. The Senate, therefore, cannot make a judgement about accountability, commercial and cabinet sensitivities and people's safety, because the minister will not let it.

Last Thursday Senator Alston told the Senate that the release of the material could endanger the physical safety of a person or persons. If people's safety is at risk as a result of this consultancy, I assume that the Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone) has been advised, and I assume that she has taken action to protect those people who are exposed to physical harm. I would appreciate advice from the Minister for Justice on that point. If that has not happened, the government has placed itself in a position where it has information that a person's physical safety is at risk but has not acted to protect that person. Alternatively, if the government is using this defence simply as a means to deny the parliament important information about a key area of reform, as appears to be the case, the minister should be condemned and the material provided to the Senate immediately.

The Howard government identified the maritime industry as a key policy area in the lead‐up to the last election. It remains an area of great interest, not only to this parliament but also within the community generally. In fact, Minister Reith was on the radio this morning discussing that matter, and there are meetings occurring today.

The Howard government inherited a division within the department of transport with both expertise and experience in waterfront reform. That division costs taxpayers approximately $60 million a year and has a staff of over 50 officers. The government chose to add to that substantial resource by engaging a consultant, who happened to be a former employee of the Liberal Party, at what is now appearing to be a cost approaching $700,000. It is, in our view, in the public interest that this material be released and there is no practical reason why it cannot be tabled.

The government has been aware of the Senate's interest in this matter since August. Notice of this motion was given on 17 September and the report has been sitting with the department. The Senate's deliberation of this important matter is being frustrated by the actions of the Minister for Workplace Relations and his representative in this place. They are ignoring key issues of both public interest and government accountability and they are in breach of a resolution of this place. The Senate not only has the right to properly examine this material; it has a responsibility to do so.

I suggest that, if the minister is interested in finding a way of satisfying the order of the Senate or finding some way in which an independent person, agreed by the opposition and the government, can examine the material to establish and, if necessary, remove any areas that require removal under commercial‐in‐confidence or on the grounds of personal safety, that may be an option which we can discuss profitably. However, no such discussions have taken place and the opposition can only assume that there is no intention to seek to satisfy the order of the Senate in any way. I remain open to discuss this matter with the minister when he is available. I look forward to his comments on the matter. The government can rest assured that we will not let this matter rest at this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking in continuation on this Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill . The bill goes to the qualifications for appointments of presidential members of the National Native Title Tribunal and provides for the establishment of a register to enable temporary appointments to the tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill allowed me to make some remarks on general native title administration. Yesterday I referred to a claim made by the Undumbi people on the Sunshine Coast and I pointed out a number of claim restrictions that they wanted to place on properties. In point (o) of their claim, they claim a right to:
. . . grant or refuse permission to any other person to do some or all of (a) to (n) either at all or subject to terms and conditions.
That is an issue that the Native Title Tribunal will have to look at very closely. Families out west have overlapping claims on their properties. Why should they not be anxious?

The author of the article I quoted from yesterday made a lot of the alleged fear that properties would be taken away from farmers. Neither the NFF nor the National Party of Australia have ever told leaseholders that this would be the case. The article claims that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) travelled to Longreach to counter the mischievous information pastoralists had been fed. I was at Longreach and I have been to many meetings where the issue of native title has been raised. People are not fearful of losing their properties. They are fearful of how coexistence can work, how there can be two titles to the one piece of property; fearful of how native title might develop and restrict their family, living and business activities; and fearful of years of court cases before they will really know where they stand on their own properties.

Does anyone honestly think that, if we believed properties were going to be grabbed, the National Party of Australia would not have kicked up a major stink by now on that issue? It has not happened. There never was any major concern on that point put out by any reputable organisation. There are too many other real things to be worried about.

The article mentioned a land valuer who said that not one of his company's Queensland valuers has found a single sale which can be said to have been devalued by the Wik decision. Firstly, it should be pointed out that one does not have to sell land in order for it to be devalued. Indeed, devaluation would be a definite disincentive. Secondly, the schedule to a QIDC lending document gives the corporation the discretion to decide that the value of a property has been reduced by virtue of an Aboriginal claim in respect of actual or alleged rights. The existence of a claim on a property can constitute an `event of default' where, in the opinion of the corporation, such circumstances materially reduce the value of the mortgaged property or materially adversely affect the financial position of the mortgagor and/or the debtor.The existence of a native title claim is clearly seen by this major rural lender in Queensland as pivotal to the value and financial viability of the property.
I would also like to refer to a letter from one of Australia's leading banks which states, in reference to a property sale negotiation:
The bank will not countenance any further delays, particularly given that the security property is not apparently in a `Wik' affected area.
That is an acknowledgment that sales in Wik‐affected areas experience delays and difficulties because of it, and all of this is important for the tribunal to understand.

So it is quite obvious that the article in the Australian has got it wrong when it comes to the implications of native title for property sales. The country's major banks consider it a definite factor in their lending services policy.

The author found one pastoralist who thought the Aboriginal people wanted to take her farm. Of course, she was surprised that that was not the case when she sat down with the local Aboriginal people. As this pastoralist said, `the most important thing to them is recognition.'

What the author failed to mention is that the claims start off with the local Aboriginal people with whom the leaseholders have grown up or at least know well. What happens then is that the representative Aboriginal body gets involved with the registration and, from then on, leaseholders have to deal with quite a different group of people, whom they do not know and who have legal and other resources.

An example, which the tribunal ought to look at, of how this can make it very difficult and complicated to get agreement was reported in the Courier‐Mail on 24 February this year. I am very glad Senator Woodley is in the Senate to hear this. The tribunal ought to be be able to understand this. A Cape York cattleman, Alan Pedersen, had been negotiating successfully with local Aborigines with whom he want to school in Mareeba. Some are among his closest friends. He states:
I started talking with the elders but they got pushed aside and the solicitors and the land councils got into the act.
The former land council chairman, Bob Colless, said that the failure to forge an agreement prompted his resignation from the land council. He stated:

Alan is the fourth generation. His father grew up with our people. Tears were flowing when the agreement was almost reached. Some of the old people just wanted to be able to return to their land to die.
I don't know why solicitors have to look at things as a win‐lose situation.
He also stated:
The accepted authority of the people making decisions was so diluted by some radical bucks; people who had never been to the land before—
Senator Woodley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quoting an Aboriginal talking about Aboriginals, and it is a direct quote from an Aboriginal. He continues:

SPEECH.PARA: but suddenly wanted to be cattle barons and miners overnight.

Pedersen has driven more than 3,000 kilometres to attend meetings and says that the whole process had cost him more than $15,000, while `everyone else, the Aboriginal people, the government officials, the solicitors, all are paid.'

As he says, most land‐holders are not opposed to access agreements with local Aborigines. It is when the elders get pushed aside and replaced with solicitors and strangers that the difficulties arise, and the good working relationship between black and white Australians that existed in the bush before native title is irreparably damaged.

Native title negotiations are not achieved by sitting across the kitchen table with the friendly locals, as the article's token pastoralist will unhappily find out. The author is correct in assessing the whole situation as providing three basic options for farmers: legislate, litigate or negotiate. If both sides cannot agree, as in the Pedersen case, with interference from lawyers and radicals, then there are two options left. If legislation does not give certainty, there is only one option left and that is litigation.

As the author noted, times have been very tough in the bush over the past decade. There is no money for litigation, so what then? There is no need to cultivate fear. Don McGauchie is only guilty of trying to protect his people from their legitimate concerns. In that, he has the overwhelming support of rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Labor opposition, I rise to speak on the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 . I wish to address my remarks to the role of the tribunal. In doing so, I take exception to the sorts of approaches that Senator Boswell has made, because they reflect a very narrow view of native title and of the role of the tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition will be supporting the part of this bill which amends the Native Title Act—in clause 1 of schedule 1—to allow the president of the tribunal to appoint an acting registrar for a period of up to 12 months. We believe the government has made out its case for that part of this amendment bill and we will be supporting that clause.

However, we will be opposing that part of the bill which downgrades the qualifications necessary for appointment as president of the Native Title Tribunal. The government's amending legislation provides that a person may be appointed as a presidential member if they have been enrolled as a legal practitioner for at least five years, whereas the current arrangements provide that they must be a member of the judiciary.

The opposition has a number of reasons for taking this stance. It is the case that there has been some discussion on both sides of the parliament about the merits of this proposition, going back to 1995, and there have been some discussion papers which looked at changing the qualifications required for a presidential member.

I think it is fair to say that it is probably not a life and death issue, and the Labor opposition accepts that there is sustainable argument on both sides of this particular case. The reason why we take the position we do at the moment is because of the context. The strongest argument is that the current context we find ourselves in is not one in respect of which we want to send any signal about the downgrading of the role of the tribunal or the role that the president plays in the operations of the tribunal. You cannot divorce this debate from the general debate about the government's Wik plan and the next native title amendment bill, which we will be dealing with in the next couple of weeks.

We think that having a president who is a judge or a former judge adds to the stature of the tribunal and to the impression of impartiality, authority and integrity that attaches to the tribunal. As I said, in the current context we think that is a very important thing and worth defending.

The role Justice French has played has been an excellent one and I will make some comments about that in a moment. We have come to the view that we ought not do anything that would be seen to be downgrading his function and the role he has played. We think, therefore, on balance that it is preferable at this stage to oppose that part of the bill and we will be doing so in the committee stages.

I know that Justice French holds a contrary view. He has stressed on a number of occasions the mediation role of the tribunal and in general terms I accept his emphasis on the tribunal's work in mediation. But I am more inclined to share the view that Mick Dodson expressed in his report on native title for the year ending June 1996 when he said:

BREAK.PARA: This proposal may undermine the standing of the NNTT. In the establishment and consolidation phase of a body with the significant and unusual functions of the NNTT, it is vital that it be perceived as credible and impartial.

On balance we prefer to support the view that Mick Dodson expressed, largely because of the context of the current debate about native title and the important role that the tribunal will play in the development of native title over the coming 20, 30 or 40 years. That is one of the things I will be stressing in the coming debate, that we need to take a much longer term view about native title and the development of native title than people have been prepared to take. When we look at the experience in other countries, we see we are at a very early stage in the development of native title and we must take a much longer term view.

In speaking to the bill and the role of the tribunal I want to pay tribute to Justice Robert French who has proved to be an outstanding appointment. I think that is a view shared by all sides of the parliament. He has done a very difficult job extremely well. One of the signs of that is that at various times all the parties involved with the tribunal have seen fit to criticise him as leaning too far one way or the other in terms of the decisions he has made. I think he has been at pains to stress the mediation role of the tribunal. He has made himself available all around the country. He has spoken at conferences and meetings. He has done all he can to foster the role of the tribunal, to foster its acceptance and develop an understanding of its role.

Justice French has shown enormous sensitivity to Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal people's relationship with country. He has played a pivotal role in helping to broaden public acceptance of the concept of native title and the role of the tribunal. Clearly there is much more to be done but I would like to express my personal thanks for the role Justice French has played. When he does move on from the tribunal it will certainly be a great loss.

I also want to comment on the role of the registrar of the tribunal, Ms Patricia Lane. She has been instrumental in the very difficult job of establishing what has become an efficient and effective organisation. She has been responsible for building up a highly competent and committed staff complement at the tribunal and generally has done very well under quite difficult circumstances. If the tribunal is allowed to play its proper role in the coming years it will make an important contribution both to the development of native title and more generally to reconciliation in the Australian community.

We have been extremely fortunate to have two such highly capable people involved at the early stages of the development of the tribunal. When the current hysteria regarding native title subsides their role will be more widely recognised and the effective role that the tribunal has played in the first few years of the operation of the Native Title Act will also be more widely recognised.

One of my great concerns is that there has not been enough support for the positive role the tribunal has played. Some of that criticism can be levelled at this parliament. We have not done enough to support the role of the tribunal, foster understanding of native title and deal with the misunderstandings that exist in the community. I know that the native title parliamentary committee of which I have been a member since its formation has had to confront a great deal of that misunderstanding and the need for information in the community but has just not had the resources to be able to respond to those needs.

We have to conduct ourselves in this debate in a very responsible manner. There are a number of public figures who have not conducted themselves in a responsible manner in the native title debate and I must say that the conduct of the native title committee's inquiry into the Wik amendments has added to the tension and misunderstanding that surround native title. I do not think the role the committee played in this inquiry has been a positive one. I think the partisan nature of behaviour of members of the committee, the rudeness displayed on occasions to witnesses and the general lack of decorum shown has brought the parliamentary committee system into disrepute and has lowered the respect for parliament and the committee system that the general public hold.

I am not making these comments in any political partisan way; I am not pointing the finger. I think we have all contributed to that problem. We do need to have regard to how we conduct ourselves. I know the President has received complaints about the conduct of the committee and the conduct of members of the committee, and that is a disappointing thing. We have to show greater respect for the process and for witnesses. The Women for Wik are one example of witnesses who were patronised. That is an unfortunate development. I do not want to be too pious about it because I think all members of the committee have to share the blame and share responsibility.

I make the point that we have a role, particularly in the coming debate, of helping to contribute to reconciliation rather than of contributing to the division and concern in the community about native title.

One of the strengths of the tribunal has been its innovative and responsive approach. It has managed in a number of ways to bring Aboriginal culture into the operations of its mediation hearings and has been able to respond to Aboriginal cultural practice and custom in a positive way, which has been good for the work of the tribunal. It has been positive in terms of the outcomes that have been achieved and has allowed Aboriginal people to participate in the tribunal's processes in a positive way. There has been some criticism, particularly in the early days, from some groups about some of the processes that were adopted. This is a credit to the tribunal, and it is something this parliament has to take note of.

I am particularly concerned at the decision of the parliamentary committee not to organise the translation of evidence given by Aboriginal witnesses in their own languages at the hearings in Broome on 6 October. A particularly powerful presentation was given by local Aboriginal people, some of whom travelled hundreds of kilometres to present to the committee. Because a number of them were much more fluent in their own language, they chose to give evidence in that language. While I did not understand the words, I certainly felt the sentiment and strength of emotion when they talked about their relationship to country and culture.
It is a terrible indictment of this parliament that the entry in the Hansard records, for example, the evidence of one Mrs Maggie Long, a Jaru woman, as:
Evidence was then given in a language other than English—

That witness gave a quite moving and detailed presentation. Yet that is the only reference in Hansard . It is an indictment of this parliament that we have not been able to respond in a more positive way to recognise and understand the evidence that was given.

I point out that I am not making a criticism of Hansard in this regard. They did a tremendous job at these hearings in quite difficult circumstances. It seems we have not been able to find a way through to organise for this translation to occur. I do not understand that. I took steps following the evidence being given to the committee; I spoke to someone from the law and culture centre in the Kimberley about organising a translation. They said they were perfectly willing to do that provided the parliament provided them with the tapes and some funding for the translators to translate the evidence and make it available for inclusion in the Hansard.

We have got tied up in some sort of bureaucratic argument about who is going to pay for it and whether or not it is possible. I understand that the committee might even be writing to the witnesses now telling them that they can, if they like, provide translations of their own evidence. That is a terribly inadequate response and an indictment of this parliament. We really must do better at accommodating the witnesses who provide evidence in their own language. These are the original inhabitants of this country. The parliament really has on obligation to do much better than we have done on this occasion.

Quite frankly, it reflects very badly on the parliament. I think a lot of people will see this as a sign of how seriously this parliament takes Aboriginal views on this Wik legislation when we cannot be bothered to make the effort—considering all the resources that we spend on things that are of far less priority— to make available in the Hansard the evidence of those witnesses.

I do not want to labour the point. It really is a disgraceful situation and we must fix it. I am most concerned that the parliament do much better at allowing those Aboriginal people's points of view to be available to the wider community and to be understood by senators. Apart from being able to pick up the emotional impact of the evidence, I do not have a clue as to what those people said. Neither do any other members of the committee. Ten or 11 witnesses gave quite extensive evidence and we have not had the benefit of understanding what that evidence is.

I return to Labor's formal position on the bill and indicate that we will be supporting the bill but we will be seeking to oppose schedule 1, item 3, page 4—lines 20 to 27—which is the provision the government is moving to effectively downgrade the qualifications required for the appointment of presidential members. Apart from that position, we will be supporting the bill. We will be arguing that in the current circumstances that specific item of the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 . By all accounts, this is not a large or complicated bill. It is, however, a significant one. As outlined in the government's second reading speech, the first two amendments concern the qualifications for appointment of the registrar and presidential members of the tribunal. The third amendment provides a temporary appointment of the registrar by the president of the tribunal, and the fourth amendment provides further clarification of when a member of a tribunal is considered to have a conflict of interest in an application or inquiry before the tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: In the main, the Australian Democrats do not have any specific problems with this bill. However, we do share the concerns of the ALP about the watering down of the stature of the president of the National Native Title Tribunal from that of a judge to some other suitable person.

BREAK.PARA: I notice that previous speakers have gone beyond the purpose of this bill and have craved indulgence to make a few comments that perhaps do not address the bill directly but address the whole issue of the debate which surrounds the bill. I am afraid I am provoked by Senator Boswell in this instance because I doubt that he addressed the bill at all in his speech—except to give the tribunal a couple of whacks.

It seems to me that, if this is an indication of the government's attitude, then one must put some weight on the fact that the government wants to water down again the stature of the president of the tribunal and therefore to reduce its effectiveness. You cannot have it both ways. If Senator Boswell thinks that the tribunal is not operating properly, then he also should vote with the opposition, the Democrats and I presume the Greens to strike out that particular amendment.

I was provoked by Senator Boswell. The claim that the National Party and the National Farmers Federation have not created fear in the bush is—I do not know what words to use to respond to that—the most bald‐faced claim I have heard in this place. To see evidence of that one only has to refer to the television ads that the National Farmers Federation tried to broadcast and then, in great surprise at the response they got from around this country about the racism inherent in those ads, apparently withdrew.

The fact is that in Queensland the National Party has created so many problems over the years. I have 35 years of experience of their appalling regard for and record on Aboriginal and Islander affairs. When we come to the 10-point plan amendments obviously I will speak about this a lot more, but let me give one illustration. My own church, the Uniting Church, was the administrator of the community of Aurukun in North Queensland for 70 years. This in fact is the community where the Wik people live. We use this word `Wik' as though it refers to some ephemeral theory that is resident in only the High Court. In fact, the Wik people are real people and they live at Aurukun.

The Uniting Church, because it had moved to give the people there a measure of self- determination and was, together with the people, learning what that meant, had absolutely horrified the Queensland government because it wanted to keep them in ignorance and in the state in which they had lived for generations ever since the Queensland government had taken some interest in Aboriginal people. After 70 years of administration, the Queensland government, over the wishes of the people, gave the Uniting Church three weeks to quit the administration of that community and caused turmoil which continues to this day. So let us not pretend that the National Party in Queensland is not one of the fundamental causes of the problems we face in that state in relation to Aboriginal and Islander people.

I get a little stirred up when I hear Senator Boswell making those kinds of claims, although normally he and I agree on a lot of things. I challenge Senator Boswell to do the same as his colleagues in the National Party in the House of Representatives. It has been announced in today's media that Bob Katter and other members of the National Party will cross the floor. That will not make any difference to the numbers in the House of Representatives, where we know the government has the overwhelming numbers, but it would make a difference in the Senate. If Senator Boswell is really fair dinkum that the amendments that the National Party are to move are going to make a difference and help farmers, let us see them cross the floor here.

Let us see whether these are just words, which is what we usually hear from Senator Boswell, or whether we are actually going to see him take some action. That is the only way that farmers in Queensland can have any confidence that he really means what he says, otherwise his words mean nothing. So we will be waiting with great interest to see whether or not the National Party supports its amendments not only in the House of Representatives but here in the Senate.

Let me continue to deal with the bill. As has been mentioned in the House of Representatives, the true situation of the National Native Title Tribunal is borne out by a closer reading of section 110 of the Native Title Act, which provides for a judge or a former judge to be a presidential member. I would like to put on the record the appreciation and thanks of the Australian Democrats to Justice French for his considerable hard work in advancing the cause of reconciliation in this country. His very special personal qualities as well as his legal expertise epitomise the sort of person that we think should head the National Native Title Tribunal.

All sides of politics have acknowledged the good work the tribunal has done in what has been a very difficult political environment. We believe that this recent experience adds weight to the assertion that the tribunal's composition should remain the same. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Labor Party's amendment to this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 . As has been mentioned by other speakers, during Senator Boswell's statements it was hard to comprehend that that was what we were doing because they were mainly about responses to and knee‐jerk reactions about native title issues in general. Considering Senator Boswell continued in that vein, I would like to comment first of all on some of the issues that were brought up by him.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell quoted some of the words on a particular native title claim. I have been in situations in Western Australia where an angry pastoralist also quoted words from a native title claim. I find it extraordinary that the representative bodies of farmers and pastoralists have not provided even the most basic information to their members about what various phrases on native title claims mean and what the counteracting clauses—the `notwithstanding' clauses—mean also.

I find it extraordinary that the leader of a party in the Senate should actually quote those words in the Senate without any reference to those counteracting clauses. This is what causes fear within the community. Words like `exclusive possession' are counteracted by the clauses that say `notwithstanding'. We know that those `notwithstanding' aspects have in fact been clarified by the Wik decision in as much as they say, `Where there is a conflict, the interests of the pastoral leaseholders prevail.'

I was also disturbed to hear the government ruse, if you like, of using the word `title' in relation to lease. That is trying to make people believe that what they have in terms of a pastoral lease is the same as a title. It is not the same as a title in the sense of land ownership and never has been. It always has been a limited right in relation to title to pastoral leaseholders.

The nature of native title is not possible to define because it relates to what the land means to traditional owners. Because of that, it is rarely possible to be able to define native title in terms of one title for one piece of land and one title for another piece of land. The natural way of native title—that is, what land means to traditional owners—means that there are overlapping traditional claims. That is the way Aboriginal society in Australia works. There is not a boundary which says, `This is the end of this interest of this group of people and this is where the interest of another group of people starts.'

There are reasons why some groups have chosen to try to all be included on one legal document, but that is a totally different thing—whether it is possible for all of those people with a traditional interest in land to go on one legal document. There are reasons, and often good reasons, why there are separate physical claims, because sometimes it is like overlapping circles and networks. That is the way native title is understood by the people in that area. It is outrageous to suggest that we should expect Aboriginal people's understanding of their meaning of land to somehow fit into the white Australian society's view of land ownership. It is outrageous to suggest that it is their fault for not doing so.
Having got that off my system, I would like to address what we are actually supposed to be here talking about, which is the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 .

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to say `chest'.
—Thank you, Senator Collins; I really appreciated that gratuitous remark!
—What an extraordinarily sensitive flower you are this morning.
—Yes, I am fairly extraordinarily sensitive about sexism in the chamber.
—Sexism! Are you seriously asserting that you don't have a chest?
—Order! Senator Collins!
—I think that is taking political correctness just a tad too far, Senator.
—Order! Senator Collins!
—Sexism! You've also got two legs and a head.
—Senator Collins!
—There's nothing in it of course, but you've got one.
—Senator Collins, would you please cease interjecting!

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. This bill brings about four changes. The first three, I believe, are sensible to enact at this time. It is useful to allow the NNTT to quickly fill a temporary vacancy in the position of registrar. It is acceptable to provide for the functionary role of registrar—(Quorum formed)
—I call Senator Bob Collins. I understand an arrangement has been made to give leave to Senator Margetts to speak again on the bill later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —As a reference to the speakers list will show, I had not intended to speak in this debate on the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997, but I am happy to do so for a few minutes. Having followed the debate, as I did closely this morning, I hope that it will not be too much of a gross departure from the conventions and practice of the Senate if I actually, for a minute or two at least, talk about the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chris Evans has already noted that one of the few provisions of this bill before the parliament is to provide for a downgrading of the appointment of the presidential member from the current requirement of that person to be a judge to being a legal practitioner of five years standing. As Senator Evans also said, this is not a dying in a ditch issue for the opposition, but we feel that it would be inappropriate at this time to have a downgrading of the position in the context of what is clearly a fierce and very controversial—and, I imagine, will remain a very controversial—debate on the whole question of the operation of the tribunal.

One of the reasons that I am pleased to be able to say a few words in the debate this morning is to join Senator Evans in commending Mr Justice French for the superlative and professional way in which he has carried out his almost impossible duties of being in charge of the tribunal. Mr Justice French would have known at the time of his appointment precisely what he was taking on and that it was highly unlikely, despite his best and most professional efforts, that he would get too many thanks from anyone for the job that he was doing, or ever succeed in pleasing anyone in terms of the decision that the tribunal was likely to make. I join Senator Evans in publicly acknowledging the effort that he put into it and the professionalism with which he carried out that work.

Mr Justice French will certainly take from that position when he leaves a reasonable place in history in respect of native title and the efforts that he has made, as Senator Evans said. In promoting the work of the tribunal he has been absolutely tireless. I also want to place on record my thanks for the job that he has done.

Under the provisions of this bill it will be possible to place in that position a person who is not a judge but who has five years standing as a lawyer. I notice that one of our more illustrious and distinguished lawyers in the Senate has just joined us, Senator Vanstone. Years ago as a non-lawyer I used to dip my lid to lawyers who had the appellation after their names of `QC', standing for Queen's Counsel. I was ignorant enough many years ago to be very deferential to people who had the title of QC after their names on the basis that they were very illustrious lawyers indeed.

Over the period of time I have spent in politics I have met a number of Queen's Counsels, and the Queen, had she ever been in the unfortunate position of requiring their counsel, would have been in very deep water indeed. Nevertheless, generally speaking across the profession the title of QC or, as it has been far more appropriately termed now in some jurisdictions, SC, meaning Senior Counsel—in other words, it is a distinction provided by the profession to its peers—did hold some weight, some standing, some status in the community.

Regrettably, over the last week or two the distinction, the standing, of the title QC has been rather severely degraded in the jurisdiction of the Northern Territory, in which our Chief Minister has simply appointed himself a QC without the endorsement of the Northern Territory's Chief Justice. The Northern Territory's Chief Minister practised for only a very few years at the bar, from, I believe, 1982 to 1987. It was a short career indeed. The only thing that he did of any legal distinction during those few short years at the bar was to be found guilty of unprofessional conduct by the Northern Territory Law Society, one of a very few lawyers who have ever had that particular distinction. But on the basis of that record, recently, without the endorsement of the Northern Territory's Chief Justice, he appointed himself as a Queen's Counsel, thereby degrading the standing and the status of that office to something you would pull out of a cornflakes packet.

It would be possible under the provisions of this bill for someone with the title of QC, whose only distinction in the law is to have been found guilty of unprofessional conduct by the Law Society, to be appointed to head up the native affairs tribunal. I would hope that the Attorney-General is not foolish enough to appoint someone of that standing, with a fake QC after his name, to that position.

I also want to say a few words following the contribution that Senator Woodley made to the debate. Senator Woodley quite rightly and vigorously responded to Senator Boswell's assertion that the National Farmers Federation has not in any way contributed to misunderstandings about the application of the Native Title Act in Australia and the decisions of the High Court. If only that were true. I stand here as a person who had a close, amicable and, I think, positive relationship with the National Farmers Federation over a number of years. Between the government and the National Farmers Federation we achieved a great deal of good work on behalf of primary producers in Australia. I would like to think so.

That is why I was utterly dismayed and disheartened to see that appalling television campaign, which thankfully the NFF has not repeated, of the two young children, one black and one white, playing a child's game. That was not only offensive, it was not only divisive but it was factually inaccurate, which is the part about it that I really disliked.

That ad purported to give people in Australia a story about the decision on Wik. What offended me about that advertisement—and I saw it many times in flight from Darwin to Canberra on the inflight entertainment systems and elsewhere—was that, when the two children were playing that game and the black hand and the white hand were descending on the board, on every single occasion the black hand would come down on the piece of property first, then followed by the white hand.

What offended me about that was that, whatever else you might say about the Wik decision, the cold, hard legal facts were that in Wik the court found that, where native title might be established—might be established—and where that might be in conflict with the rights of a pastoralist, the rights of that pastoralist would prevail. In other words, if you really wanted to be that offensive, the white hand should have come down first, followed by the black hand.

BREAK.PARA: If people in this country want to scream such racially offensive, stereotypical garbage on television, then at least they should try to be just slightly accurate while they are doing so. I deeply regret that ad. I deeply regret even having to criticise the National Farmers Federation because of the long and, I believe, as I say, mutually productive relationship I have had with them. But I certainly do hope that the National Farmers Federation, who have been wise enough not to repeat a similar advertisement on television, do not advertise in this way again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is useful to allow the National Native Title Tribunal to quickly fill a temporary vacancy in the position of registrar. It is acceptable to provide for the functionary role of registrar to come from a more diverse field of suitably qualified candidates. And it is sensible to have further clarification of when a member of the tribunal is considered to have a conflict of interest in relation to an application or inquiry before the tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: But the fourth change that is proposed in this bill is far more problematic. Currently, only Federal Court judges or former judges from any jurisdiction can be appointed as presidential members, after the relevant documentation crosses Mr Howard's desk. The bill seeks to change this requirement so that a person who has been a legal practitioner for at least five years can be appointed as a presidential member, and this inserts a new subsection in the table contained in section 110.

Currently, there are five presidential members, including the President, Justice French; and 13 ordinary members of the tribunal. Two of the current full‐time ordinary members are Aboriginal. An ordinary member is only required to have been a legal practitioner for at least five years. The main difference between an ordinary member and a presidential member is the power to direct. For example, only a presidential member can direct the registrar not to accept an application because it is vexatious or frivolous.

The principle of non-judges being appointed to presidential positions may appear on the surface to be perfectly reasonable; for example, many experienced practitioners may have extensive knowledge about Aboriginal issues. Secondly, judges are nearly all ruling class middle‐aged white men—and this is a paradigm which should be broken down; and to select from a select pool of people could be considered as inappropriate for the Native Title Tribunal. To this end, there are no Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander judges or ex-judges in Australia. Thirdly, the current President, Justice French, is on record as supporting the proposed changes. In his August 1996 submission on section 110, Justice French said:

This section as it presently stands sets out the categories of membership of the Tribunal and the qualifications for appointment to those categories. The amendment extends the qualifications of Presidential Members to include persons who have been legal practitioners for five years or more. The amendment is supported. It will provide greater flexibility in the appointment of Members to the Tribunal.

My fourth point is that, in addition, the government appears to be finding it difficult to find presidential members. Justice French wishes to resume his Federal Court duties but has recently been persuaded to remain until at least the end of the year. There does not appear to be in the NTA any provision for the position of Acting President. In addition, the government can no longer compel judges to sit on tribunals—and that came in Wilson v. Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. However—and this gets to the heart of the matter—it is unclear whether the government is simply rejecting many possible appointees, especially ex-judges, because those willing to take up the job are perceived as being too progressive.

Very importantly to the Greens, Aboriginal people we have spoken to, such as Commissioner Mick Dodson and others from various Aboriginal corporations, believe that the requirement that presidential members come from the judiciary should remain. There are a few reasons for this. Firstly, they believe that the government is wanting to open up the field not to appoint presidential members who are more appropriate but, to the contrary, to appoint people who will do the government's bidding.

Secondly, they believe that it will lower the stature of the National Native Title Tribunal, which has come under considerable attack in recent times, and that this will become just another area where Aboriginal people's fora are downgraded. Thirdly, judges are less likely to be influenced by the government which has appointed them than a lawyer. Judges have had the experience of working in an environment with clear separation of powers, and will respect the need to remain independent.

Commissioner Dodson in particular has much more trust and respect for the judiciary than the government. In our conversation last Friday, he said that it was the judiciary who gave Aboriginal people native title and the government which is attempting to extinguish it—and that, of course, is a salient point. Commissioner Dodson wrote in his 1995-96 Native Title Act Report:

This proposal may undermine the standing of the NNTT. In the establishment and consolidation phase of a body with the significant and unusual functions of the NNTT, it is vital that it be perceived as credible and impartial. This perception would be undermined if the President and Deputy President of the NNTT were not required to have judicial experience. I therefore believe that the proposed amendment is inappropriate.

The importance of Aboriginal people having faith in the independence and standing of the NNTT is absolutely crucial. Given the current attacks on Aboriginal people by this government, it would undermine the whole native title process if Aboriginal people felt the tribunal was `stacked out' with government lackeys.

Why should we not look at any changes that the government makes with regard to the native title process with extreme scepticism? After all, it is this government which, in the words of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Fischer), is seeking to enact `bucket loads' of extinguishment. It is this government which is seeking to destroy the right to negotiate process, including, under proposed section 36, taking away the tribunal's power of determination with regard to future acts when the minister considers that a decision has not been reached in a `reasonable' time.

When it comes to native title, one shudders to think what a minister of this government would consider to be reasonable. It is this government which is proposing, under the new section 82, to change the rules of evidence to make it far more difficult for Aboriginal people to present evidence in a manner which takes into account their cultural concerns. We heard from Senator Evans today a disgraceful story of a situation where the traditional owners of an area did not have the courtesy of having their evidence translated to be made available to the Senate and the people of Australia. That is the situation we are dealing with.

Against the trend in law to make rules more flexible, this government wishes to reimpose the hearsay rule to exclude genuine evidence from indigenous claimants. Perhaps they will also exclude evidence that is not in English. Well, we are an English speaking country, are we not! The utterly ethnocentric proposed section 82 really seems to echo the shameful mutterings of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) more than that of the government, which has a serious debt and responsibility to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country. It is part of the continual scapegoat politics mentality in Australia. That is, take your eye off the ball, the main game—that is, what is happening in the country with social issues, the gap between the rich and poor, unemployment, and the attacks on the community—and push that ball on to those people who have the least ability to be able to fight back. That is scapegoat politics.

Why should we believe this government when it says that it only wishes to remove the requirement for the President to be from the judiciary in order to `open the field'? This government has created a climate of mistrust with regard to Aboriginal affairs which has not existed since the dark times when indigenous people were considered non-citizens. It cannot now expect us to take it on good faith that this change is being enacted to enable the appointment of a more appropriate President. The fear is real and apparent that this government is more likely to use this amendment to appoint someone far less appropriate.

The government has made mention of the necessary scaling back of presidential powers of determination due to the effect of the Brandy case, which held that administrative tribunals cannot act in a judicial capacity. However, it is currently unclear—and research is being conducted—whether the removal of powers, such as being able to reject an application, are necessarily due to the effect of the decision in Brandy or whether the government is seeking to weaken the National Native Title Tribunal for political reasons. In any case, even if the Native Title Amendment Bill is enacted, the President will retain significant powers as the chief decision‐maker of the tribunal, and any suggestion that such a role is purely administrative is inaccurate.

Clearly, I have signalled the fact that the Greens (WA) support the ALP's intention to omit schedule 1, item 2, which seeks to weaken the role of the President. I think this is vitally important. We are hearing in the media today of a proposal in the lower house to put some sort of beads and trinket amendment to the Native Title Amendment Bill. From this we can assume that none of the issues raised by the 1,600 people who gave evidence and produced submissions to the joint standing committee is important enough to be taken notice of. Perhaps some of the evidence was taken notice of but not other parts.

We can also assume that somehow or other it will be fair and reasonable to extinguish native title and to offer freehold title on crown land which nobody else wants—that is, until someone finds something which they want to mine—and which is not and never will be anywhere near a town. That is the beads and trinkets approach that we have got from the government and from coalition members. That is why nobody in their right mind would support the downgrading of the presidency of the Native Title Tribunal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank all senators for their contributions to the debate, although I have to say that I am personally deeply resentful of the kind of contribution that has just been made by Senator Margetts, with her gratuitous, narrow‐minded attitude and prejudice about what one major political party thinks versus another. Clearly, she has a misunderstanding of what has actually happened.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally would prefer if debates in this place were conducted on the basis of what had substantively happened as opposed to people tossing their own prejudices from one side of the chamber to another. One example of that is the remarks by Senator Margetts that this government deals with indigenous communities in a bead and trinket fashion. That does not seem to be the type of contribution that this debate merits. This debate merits a more substantive contribution and a more substantive argument than the pejorative assertion of a beads and trinket approach. It is not something in the past that I would have expected from Senator Margetts, but that is for her to be responsible for.

Before turning briefly to finalise the debate, I mention Senator Bob Collins's views on the capacity of people to acquire the title QC. Interesting as that may have been to some members, I did feel slightly miffed that Senator Collins chose to focus on Mr Stone in the Northern Territory because, if you want to look at people who have had themselves appointed QC and argue the case as to whether it was meritorious or not, you need look no further than the other chamber in this parliament, the House of Representatives, to the now Mr Gareth Evans QC. Ask yourself whether that was a meritorious appointment and whether he had to, in fact, go and beg and plead with the Chief Justice in Victoria to get himself nominated.

What is particularly fascinating about the title QC being held by Mr Evans is that he is a republican. That is no big deal—I believe not only that Australia will become a republic but that it should, so I do not single him out in that respect. But I do single him out as being a republican who just cannot bear to give the commission `Queen's Counsel' away. He could give it away. He could say, `This is no longer representative of what is appropriate in Australia. I don't want to be the Queen's Counsel. I am going to give it back.' Do you see someone like the former Senator Evans giving his commission to be a Queen's Counsel back? No, you do not. It is just more of the two‐faced lily‐livered rubbish that comes from the other side. Nonetheless, I will leave that be.

The point in question that has perhaps had most focus in this debate is the question of the need for a judge or otherwise. It is probably worth running through the argument that the bill will downgrade the status of the National Native Title Tribunal. It is not the government's view that it will do that. The amendments address the implications of the High Court's decision in the Brandy case by transferring the determination‐making function of the National Native Title Tribunal to the Federal Court. Under the new scheme all applications for compensation and native title determinations will be made to the Federal Court and the court will have sole responsibility for making any determination concerning native title or compensation. Under the existing regime, a presidential member can direct the Registrar to accept or not accept an application for consideration for the tribunal.

It was appropriate for presidential members to be judges or former judges as they could in effect overturn a decision of the Registrar. The new regime provides that all applications for a determination of native title will be made directly to the Federal Court. So presidential members of the National Native Title Tribunal will cease to have any function in relation to the acceptance of claims. This new regime for processing of native title claims is largely based on the amendments included in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1995 introduced by the previous government at the end of 1995.

As the tribunal will no longer apply an acceptance test it is no longer necessary or appropriate for presidential members to be limited to judges or former judges. Judges are not the only people with the skills needed to lead the tribunal effectively. That is the government's position. In closing, I endorse the remarks a number of people have made as to the contribution of Justice French.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate on behalf of the opposition that we are opposing schedule 1, item 3, page 4, lines 20 to 27 of the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 which has been the centre of the debate on the second reading. I do not want to delay us much longer but just put on the record that this is the provision which seeks to change the qualification for a presidential member from that currently existing of requiring a judicial appointment to make it open to any person who has been five years enrolled as a legal practitioner. We argue that that is a downgrading which on balance we do not support at this time.

That schedule 1, item 3 stand as printed.
