SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely sure this Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is the bill that Senator Murphy wants to pay particular attention to. It involves the thin capitalisation issue that he particularly among the senators on this side of the chamber is interested in.

SPEECH.PARA: When the clock struck me down last time on this matter, I was part way through my speech. I would like to pick up that speech where I left off and refer to the backdown by the government in terms of offshore groups here. The education and training industry in particular is concerned about the possible effects of the redrafted legislation.

For example, International Training Australia—ITA—has written to the opposition expressing their concerns about the bill before the Senate today. ITA is a private company whose shareholding is comprised solely of Victorian government enterprises. It was established to combine and coordinate the training and education capabilities of the Victorian TAFE system in large‐scale overseas projects. ITA is very concerned that the provisions in this bill will impact on its members' current drive to increase the export of Australian educational services.

For commercial reasons these Australian educational institutions often have to establish foreign subsidiaries or Australian subsidiaries which do not operate principally in Australia. These bodies are not engaged in tax avoidance, but they may be caught by this legislation and, hence, lose their tax exempt status. Clearly this would be a poor outcome for the nation, as these bodies are in fact engaged in earning export income for Australia.

There has already been an attack on public education by this government, with the latest fiasco of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) on literacy merely a symptom of this government's misguided approach. The opposition is very concerned that this legislation may further inhibit the legitimate activities of the educational sector.

Some religious groups have also been very concerned about the potential impact of this bill. For example, the African Evangelical Fellowship of Australasia sends missionaries to Africa and the islands of the Indian Ocean, where they are engaged in a wide range of religious, humanitarian and social programs to assist the peoples of the region. This group has been operating for more than 100 years, providing vital assistance to underprivileged peoples. Fortunately, the government has amended the legislation to ensure that such important organisations are not disadvantaged, and we support this change of heart.

The Trustee Corporation of Australia—TCA—was also concerned about the potential impact of the legislation, from a different perspective: the impact on wills and on charitable bequests arising from wills. The TCA was concerned that the legislation might mean that many trusts would have to appear before the relevant state supreme courts in order to amend their terms to comply with the new regime. For example, amendments may have been needed to expressly prohibit overseas distributions. This would have been a potentially complex and expensive process and may have been more legally difficult than the government assumed. Again, fortunately, good sense prevailed. After this matter was raised by my colleague, the member for—ironically—Wills (Mr Gareth Evans), the government amended the bill to deal with these potentially large problems it was going to create. We are now happy to support these provisions.

However, there is still one more area where the legislation is seriously deficient. That is the area of its effect on Australian charities which have made distributions since the commencement of this legislation—namely, since budget night on 26 August, 1996. There are two spectacular examples of the problem of drawing this anti‐avoidance net too wide. These are the Buckland Fund and Philanthropy Australia.

Australia does not have the enormous private philanthropy sector enjoyed by the United States. However, both these charities have a significant history in the Australian context. The Buckland Fund was started in 1879 and has, since that time, been assisting ex‐employees of the Bank of New South Wales who have fallen on hard times and their dependents. Some of these people live overseas and have been paid assistance since 20 August last year. Hence, the fund is looking at losing its exemption permanently. There is no thought of tax avoidance; the problem is merely a government which does not pay proper attention to the impact of its proposals. Similarly, Philanthropy Australia, which is a major benefactor of other charities, is also unfairly threatened by the bill as currently drafted. I will return to these matters in greater detail at the committee stage, as the opposition will be moving some amendments to clear up the mess created by the government.

The issue of stopping the use of charitable and other trusts for tax avoidance brings me to the general issue of trusts and tax avoid ance. We all know that this is a very sensitive issue for the government. There is now widespread knowledge in the community that considerable leakage of revenue from the tax system arises through the use of trusts. In a speech to CEDA on 10 September, the Tax Commissioner, Mr Carmody, put the issue squarely in the Treasurer's court when he addressed the issue of the taxation treatment of trusts and whether the current arrangements were appropriate. Mr Carmody made the point that in some situations trusts can allow the tax‐free receipt by beneficiaries of profits which would have been taxable if they had been earned by companies and then distributed to shareholders. How can such a situation be fair and promote the efficient conduct of business?

There have been reports of one particular high‐wealth individual—which is code for a rich person—receiving a tax‐free amount of $19 million in just one year. How can such a system be supported when part‐time workers earning just over $100 a week have to pay income tax? Why is the government so reluctant to address the issue associated with the use of trusts? Why are we still waiting for the government's final legislation dealing with trafficking in trust losses?

Labor introduced legislation into the parliament in 1995 to deal with avoidance practices involving trust losses. The then opposition, now government, refused to pass these provisions and delayed the measures in a Senate committee until the election in 1996. Since then we have had two budgets which both announced further relaxation of Labor's fair proposals. It is only now that we have finally had this legislation introduced into the house—around two years after Labor's legislation was introduced. The reason for this unprecedented delay is pretty obvious. The issue is too difficult for the government because too many of those opposite have family trusts and hence have a conflict of interest in seeing the issue properly addressed.

Mike Seccombe in the Sydney Morning Herald reported on 4 July 1997 that 13 of the government's 27 ministers had family trusts according to the official register of interests. So there is a real problem for the Treasurer (Mr Costello) if he wants to improve the fairness of the tax system. Half of his ministerial colleagues will presumably resist moves to increase the amount of tax that will be paid on their family income.

The tax commissioner has clearly signalled the direction which he prefers: the comparable taxation of both companies and trusts. The response of the government to the review of the tax treatment of trusts will be a key indicator of whether the Howard government will simply be a re‐run of the Fraser government, which let tax avoidance get completely out of control, culminating in the infamous bottom of the harbour scandals. Or will it continue the outstanding efforts of the Hawke and Keating governments, which re‐introduced equity into the Australian tax system?

The problems of tax avoidance are perennial. Once one loophole is closed, the advisers move on to the next one. Governments can never relax in their task to keep the tax system fair. I can assure the Australian people that the Labor opposition will keep raising these vital issues to ensure that proper fairness is introduced into the tax system.

There are a number of other minor matters in the bill that are not controversial and are supported by the opposition—namely, electronic lodgement of returns and electronic funds transfer; the new rules concerning group certificates for employees ceasing employment; the treatment of tax exempt entities that become taxable; and the rate of tax for friendly societies will be frozen at the current level of 33 per cent from 1997‐98 and 1998‐99 pending the outcome of a review of the proper taxation regime for the life insurance business and friendly societies. I would have liked to have spent some time explaining our position on each of these. Due to the interrupted nature of my address and the fact that the light is on and I am almost out of time, I cannot do that but I may seek the opportunity in the committee stage.

As I commented at the commencement of my remarks—and let me wind up on this point—Labor does not oppose the principle of these measures, but we are concerned about some of the effects of the bill and we will be moving amendments to overcome those in the committee stages. I think our amendments will address very serious problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —On the issue of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) , I will not be taking up much of the Senate's time. Basically the Greens (WA) find this bill fairly non‐contentious. The measures in it are designed to address various avenues for tax minimisation available to corporations and the rich but rarely available to ordinary people or businesses. Some of those avenues, such as the thin capitalisation treatment, were intentional. The government is now moving to reduce the possibility of such tax minimisation. Other measures arose due to clever accountants recognising how tax laws designed for other purposes could be manipulated to provide tax benefits. The issue of charitable trusts is such a case.

SPEECH.PARA: We are, in general, happy to support this bill, and I will flag now what we intend to do on amendments. We will support the government's amendments to change the dates to bring them more in line with the passage of this bill. We did have an initial concern that some charitable trusts established for legitimate charitable purposes may be affected. We are satisfied now that none that I know of will be detrimentally affected.

However I would like to say that I welcome ALP amendments Nos 3 and 4, which provide for a situation where, while the default is to pay tax, there are options for charitable trusts which are legitimate charitable organisations to ask for an exemption, and if examination shows that they are established for charitable purposes and not for tax minimisation, for them to be granted an exemption. If the tax office and the Treasurer can be satisfied that a charitable trust is established for a bona fide purpose, they should be able to make that exemption.

However, we will not support ALP amendments Nos 1 and 2. These allow more `thin capitalisation' to occur in areas of low employment. While we are, of course, entirely sympathetic to the idea of doing something about the huge issue of rural and regional unemployment, I do not believe that this is a solution. Is creating a possibility for tax minimisation really a replacement for industry policy or systematic programs for regional development? Whilst I recognise that Labor has more industry policy suggestions than the coalition, it is obviously still not enough and it is not a replacement for it.

The problem of structural unemployment is in part a problem of the deregulation that allowed such power to reside with capital. I do not believe that the solution is to encourage investment by reducing the portion of profit that is returned to the community through taxation. We already know that, on average, companies and corporations in Australia pay less than a quarter of the tax revenue that ordinary citizens pay into the tax revenue. It is generally thought corporations hold Australia together in terms of providing for things like housing and health, but that is not the case. The average ordinary taxpayer pays in total—cumulative—over four times what companies pay in Australia.

As I said, we believe that we should not be encouraging that proportion of profit to be reduced in terms of its tax contribution. The result is that profit, or capital, is maintained and concentrated in the hands of corporations. There is no guarantee that this will subsequently be spent, reinvested or retained in Australia. Of course, we know from the previous government that Mr Keating may have railed against companies for what they did or did not do but it is the case that, in the current situation, we are not necessarily getting that contribution back into the community. Investment requires capital—not wages, which do little other than cover expenses.

I think the focus on attracting investment by reducing labour costs or taxation has been one of the factors driving the increase in structural unemployment, and that is because people are feeling less sure about where their next income is coming from. It may also be that more and more people in our society are joining the ranks of the working poor; that is, they do not have money to spend on goods and services above the necessities of life within their local community. That, in my belief, is one of the driving forces of structural unemployment, along with the concentra tion on downsizing in services and large corporations which, I think, is to the detriment of those industries as well.

I cannot support a measure which effectively does more of the same with less to look forward to. I think we should be looking at positive solutions rather than negative ones that simply support the situation we have seen up to now, where we are saying to corporations, `We will join in this race to the bottom' in terms of speculative investment and `We will offer you less wages and taxes to take over our existing companies.' I do not think that is the way we should be going. Instead of a continuation of slash and burn speculative investments, we should be looking at solid industry policy in Australia. We should become less dependent on investments flying out of the sky from multinationals overseas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to limit myself by concentrating on one section of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) , and that is the measures to address tax avoidance through tax exempt entities distributing funds offshore.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill, as it relates to charities, proposes measures which were announced in the 1996‐97 budget. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced that the government intended to introduce legislation to counter tax avoidance through the use of tax exempt bodies distributing funds offshore. When the exposure draft of this legislation was released, there was a great deal of concern from this sector; however, changes were made where possible to take account of those concerns.

The reason I want to speak on this bill is because, together with my staff, I have taken a very active role on behalf of the charitable sector in presenting their case to the Treasurer and Treasury officials. Those efforts have resulted in changes that the government has made to this bill.I want to put on record publicly my thanks to the Treasury officials for the very willing cooperation they gave me on this matter. They could not have done more.

The government has made it very clear that any distribution of funds received from donations, gifts, offerings, `plate money' and donations of that nature will not affect an organisation's tax exempt status. That has removed a most valid concern which was held by quite a number of organisations and churches.

The other area of great concern was in relation to charitable trusts. In terms of charitable trusts, the government has taken the necessary steps to ensure that as far as possible bona fide organisations will not lose their tax exemption. The charitable trust sector is a very important sector operating under the philanthropic umbrella. Trust law at the best of times is complex, and it is very necessary that in taking steps to curb avoidance we do not at the same time make it unattractive for people to become involved in the provision of funding through this particular vehicle.

The bill also makes it clear that organisations based in Australia will not be affected by the measures proposed as long as they incur their expenditure and pursue their objectives principally within Australia.

This clear statement of the intention of the legislation again should serve to allay the concerns of many organisations around the country who, in the course of their activities, undertake or are involved in some overseas work.

This legislation is about stopping tax avoidance. It is not about curtailing the donation of moneys to overseas causes. It is about ensuring that the causes to which a trust donates are real and bona fide—causes that are recognised by this and other governments through section 78 of the tax act.

Having given those assurances, I will certainly be watching this legislation to ensure that its effect in practice washes over only those for whom the bill was intended. These elements are a small part of the philanthropic activity in Australia, an area which is very wide and in which we make a great national contribution.

When people think of philanthropic activity they tend to think of the compassionate element—the relief of suffering, pain and distress in members of the community—and that, I think, is at the heart of philanthropic activity in Australia. But philanthropic activity covers a much wider field now. It covers a great part of education, it covers the arts and it covers sports. Those last three elements are a larger part than the compassionate element of philanthropy which most people associate with the philanthropic sector.
The philanthropic sector is very important to Australia. As Rousseau said:

Compassion is a natural feeling which, by moderating the violence of love of self in each individual, contributes to the preservation of the whole species. It is this compassion that hurries us without reflection to the relief of those who are in distress.

Philanthropy is an area where we do make a great national effort, and very few people recognise the scale of the effort that Australians put into it. It is an industry that involves over $5 billion per year, and probably the major part of that—over 50 per cent—comes from governments at all levels, both directly through tax concessions for donations, wholesale sales tax exemptions and fringe benefits tax exemptions and indirectly in the form of rate concessions and other concessions by local governments. So the government does have a direct interest in the philanthropic sector as a donor, and it has a duty of care to those who support philanthropic activities in ensuring that funds play a worthwhile and effective role.

We have over 100,000 employees in the philanthropic sector in Australia, and Australians collectively contribute more than 95 million man‐hours of voluntary labour each year to philanthropic activities. From this, we derive very great social benefits.

I would argue that, for very small changes in the way we approach the philanthropic sector, we could get even greater benefits. I believe it is the one great area for social change that is open to Australia for the generation ahead.

All I am saying is that for the effort we make we could get better outcomes. To bring those about there are four simple things we need to do. We need to educate the community. We want to make it simple and easy for people to give either their time or their money. We want to reward or recognise those who are involved in philanthropic activities and we want to do as much as we can to have an assurance of value within the system.

I believe it is a responsibility of government to educate the community on the obligations they have to voluntarily support those who are less fortunate than themselves. That will fall on barren ground in some cases, but it is possible to get more people involved in philanthropic activities as a result of government persuasion in this matter. It can be quite pleasantly and honourably done.

We also have got to make it much more simple and easy for people to give of their time and their money. We have got a huge legislative muddle out there. Over 70 pieces of Commonwealth legislation relate to charities alone. There are hundreds of pieces of state legislation relating to charities. A lot of those are in conflict. World Vision Australia some years ago estimated that it cost them a million dollars a year just in compliance costs coping with different state legislation in their fundraising. We have got the nonsense of capital gains tax. If I die and leave a million dollars to a charity, it is assumed that that gift was made before my death occurred and therefore that gift attracts capital gains tax. That will be taken out of the residue of my estate before it passes to whomever I leave my money to. That is clearly a counterincentive to people supporting charities.

Another thing we have got to do is recognise and reward those people. Not everyone wishes to be recognised or rewarded. Some people do like to work privately for charities, but most people like a pat on the back in some way. I am not saying we give them the Order of Australia or anything like that but there should be some public recognition of those who serve the community in a voluntary way.

The final thing we have got to do is have an assurance of effectiveness in the whole of the charitable sector. Most charitable organisations are extremely honest and if they were not honest they could not come back year after year and raise tens of millions of dollars from the public. The word would get out. But there are small operators in the field which are not endowed with great integrity and they ought to be controlled and removed from the scene.

For example, there is no qualification at all for anyone to go onto the market and raise money for a charity. You do not have to publish a prospectus; you do not have to say what you are going to do with the funds. Again, if you want to raise $2 million to build a ward at a hospital and you raise only $1½ million, there is no obligation on the person raising that $1½ million to pay that $1½ million back because they cannot meet their target figure.

There are no agreed auditing standards for charities and, except in the state of New South Wales, there is no legislation covering the overheads, how much money it costs to raise funds and what the residue going to philanthropic groups should be. So there is a great need for reform and streamlining of the legislative approach here.

We do need to try to develop efficiencies. Some charities are very efficient. Some regrettably are not, with the best will in the world. Other charities surprisingly are not even effective. They do not ever get around to doing what they set out to do. Again, most of them set out with the best will in the world but they do not get there.

Then there is the problem of what the Americans call self‐inurement. If you have got a big charity that has a budget of $10, $20 or $30 million a year, the chief executive running that fund has got to be a very experienced and able person and they attract a high salary. But then the widow who is being appealed to, to give a donation of a dollar or $2 out of her pension for that fund, does not like the fact that a chief executive gets a salary of $100,000 or $200,000 a year. That is a matter that has got to be looked at and dealt with carefully.

But to return to my original theme: the place of philanthropic activity in Australia is very large. It is not recognised by the country collectively for the size and the contribution it makes. I am not saying at all that we want to move away from the welfare programs that governments have. My belief is that, irrespective of the parties in government in Australia, the level of government welfare for the community will by and large continue at the level that it is today. But by reforming the philanthropic sector we can deliver very great changes for the next generation for the benefit of the Australian community. It is something that we can do with minimal legislative change and minimal social dislocation. I believe the benefits that would come from that are really quite enormous. I see that this bill makes a contribution towards that path and that is why I wish it a speedy passage through the Senate.

I am now aware that the government is not going to support this amendment and I understand that the Australian Democrats may not support it. From the contribution by Senator Margetts I understand that the Greens are not going to support it, which I find somewhat unusual.
—It is amazing.

—It is amazing, Senator Cook, but in so far as the Greens are concerned it is even more amazing. But I will get to them shortly. What the amendment proposes to do is achieve something the government has been talking about doing although it has not done anything for some time. One of the reasons for this amendment is that the proposed bill in its current form would significantly affect a development in my own state. I will very clearly, up front, express that interest when saying where I am coming from. The project I talk about is Starwood, which is a medium density fibreboard plant which is yet to commence operation. It is a very significant investment on the part of a Japanese company known as Hokishan. It represents about $100 million of investment and will create a number of jobs in a region of Australia that has probably one of the highest levels of unemployment. Certainly it has one of the highest levels of unemployment in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment that we are proposing does not seek to remove or change the government's objective; rather it seeks to introduce it on a sliding scale, with a focus on areas of high unemployment. It says that, where unemployment is four per cent higher than the national seasonally adjusted average, the proposal for thin capitalisation—the reduction of three to one to two to one—would be phased in over a five-year period.

I would have thought that that is totally consistent with what the government has been saying in recent times about industry development, getting industry moving and job creation. We know that we have an unemployment problem. The government has said, `We'll look at tax breaks, free trade zones, grants' and so on. The amendment that is proposed by us would have a minimal impact on the revenue that will be raised by this taxation measure—I understand it is around $70 million per annum—because only one project is likely to be affected, that is, the project that I have spoken about in my state.

The reason it is important is that the MDF plant at Bell Bay is a two‐stage project—stage 1 is almost complete; indeed, it is due to be opened next month—and the second stage was based very much on the budget that was worked out prior to the changes to these laws. We had another battle not that long ago with another taxation measure. We found that the government had accepted what we proposed at that time.

It meant a significant saving to this company, which has implemented and will be implementing ground‐breaking technology. It is a first in this country that MDF is proposed to be made from eucalypt. The technology is state-of-the-art. All of the product will be exported. It is one of those projects that goes very clearly to what the government is seeking to do. Yet the government does not seem to be prepared to support it in any way, shape or form. It makes a lot of noises about what it proposes to do and how it proposes to see industry develop, but there is very little on the action front.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is downstream processing too.

—It is very much a downstream processing project. In 1995 the company commenced a 500‐hectare plantation with a 30‐year rotation. It is not an overnight development. It will be around for a long time. Given that the impact of these measures in dollar terms—
—You should have been here during the Wesley Vale debate.
—Senator Campbell, I hope you take this on board when you stand up to speak. You are talking about $1½ million additional cost to this company over five years.
—Where were you during Wesley Vale?

—I was around when Wesley Vale was on, but we are not talking about that at the moment. If you want to have a debate about Wesley Vale, I will go to that at another time. This project is totally export orientated.
—So was Wesley Vale.

—Senator Campbell, when you stand up shortly to speak you have the capacity to say that the government will support a measure that will guarantee that the second stage of this development proceeds. That is what this is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the amendment we are going to move will have an effect on this company. It may assist others around the country but it will assist only those in areas of very high unemployment. If you read the amendment and take on board its objective, you will see that it does have that focus. It is for areas of very high unemployment—where, as I have said, the unemployment level is four per cent above the national seasonally adjusted average, which in today's terms is around 12½ per cent.

Senator Campbell, if you inquire of your own offices in various departments, they will be able to tell you that there is not a huge plethora of developments proposed or being built for operation that this amendment will affect and therefore have some serious effect on the income measures in this bill.

I do not necessarily have any argument about what the government is intending to do about thin capitalisation. But given all the noises that the government has made over time about trying to address the unemployment problem, saying, `We are going to look at tax breaks, free trade zones and grants' et cetera, I would have thought that the opposition amendment is totally consistent with what it has been saying. Senator Campbell, here is your opportunity to put your hand up and say, `Yes, we are prepared to do something in areas of high unemployment, and we are prepared to do something that will assist projects that are totally export orientated.'

George Town, in my home state, has an unemployment rate of 20 per cent. It has one of the lowest participation rates in the country. It is of serious concern to me and to other Tasmanians, including the Liberal Premier, who has written to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) about this. I urge the government to rethink its position.

What I find even more amazing is the position of the Greens and the Democrats. The Democrats generally have taken an approach of being interventionist. Again, here is their opportunity to intervene and do something in the interests of the very high areas of unemployment in my state and in other areas. Here is an opportunity for them to see money, in terms of tax breaks, et cetera, that will be driven by unemployment—the high levels of unemployment. In regional Australia—the people that they say they stand up for no end—it seems that they are going to fall over it before they even get to the barrier.

I have heard the Greens both in Tasmania and in this place making noises about downstream processing, saying that they want industry development to have a plantation based focus so that we over time remove the necessity to use native forests. Here is a chance for them to support a development that is headed that way. It is one development that they ought to be totally behind.

Yet Senator Margetts, in her contribution, said, `Oh, no. We're not going to support it—no way.' I hope Senator Brown might be able to convince his colleague to do otherwise. Otherwise, I hope Senator Brown can explain to the Tasmanian public, particularly those in the area of George Town, why, on the one hand, they make noises about supporting industry development and downstream processing and then stand up in the Senate and vote against them.

Even though I am probably being a little parochial in so far as development in my own state is concerned, I do hope the government will consider this. I would be interested to hear from the government what they think the financial impact of this amendment would be. My view would be that it would be very low, yet the benefit from the development in Tasmania will be very high.

So I urge the government to consider this amendment very seriously. I hope that they may be able to change their mind and allow this to proceed because it is of fundamental importance. If the government are to at least demonstrate to the Australian public that all of the statements that they have made with regard to industry development and dealing with unemployment are to be believed, or at least partially believed, then they will support our amendment and allow for some opportunity to give some focus to industry development in areas of high unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: This relates to schedule 1 and what has been referred to in this debate as thin capitalisation. My staff have just advised me that I am wrong when I am right. This is one of those occasions where I would like on the record that I was right and they were wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name them, Senator Cook.

—Oh, no; I would not embarrass them that way. Now that I have a little bit on the record, that is enough. However, let me turn to the matter before the chair. The amendment the opposition has moved is a pro rural and regional employment amendment. After two Costello budgets that have ripped the financial heart and soul out of rural and regional Australia, it is once again left to the opposition to try to provide an incentive to invest in rural and regional Australia and therefore to create jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition is not opposed to the general thrust of this proposal which seeks to reduce the foreign debt to foreign equity ratio, which currently stands at three to one. This bill reduces it to two to one. We agree with the government that in essence this is an anti‐avoidance measure. But, as is usual with the government, in their haste to close down the exploitation of the current tax law they have opened up unintended consequences. One of these unintended consequences is to now penalise companies that have already begun investing in Australia and in particular in rural and regional Australia, which are the main areas of high unemployment.

This amendment will seek to allow companies that invest in areas of high unemployment access to the more concessional debt to equity ratio based upon a sliding scale. For the 1997-98 financial year the ratio would remain, in my amendment, at three to one, moving to 2.8 to one for the 1998-99 financial year and so on until the year 2002‐03, when the foreign debt to foreign equity ratio will be two to one for all foreign investors. That is the two to one that is embodied in this bill.

The qualification test for the concessional treatment will be whether the geographical area of investment is a high unemployment area. The test for this will be the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the labour force region in question plus four per cent. So, if an applicant fails to meet this test, they will face the two to one ratio immediately, as is intended by this bill. As there are 120 ABS labour force regions in Australia, this means that on average a qualifying region would contain between 120,000 and 150,000 people, roughly speaking. Given that in the September quarter the reported seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 8.7 per cent, only areas of 12.7 per cent or more would qualify under Labor's proposal if an investment were to be made tomorrow.

BREAK.PARA: I therefore put to the Senate, and the government in particular: do they believe that an area that has an unemployment rate approaching 13 per cent should not be assisted by this measure, as minor as it is? I also ask the National Party: do they believe that rural and regional areas of Australia, many of which they represent, where there is unemployment of 13 per cent or more do not deserve some form of minor assistance through this tax initiative that this amendment seeks to introduce?

In the second reading debate we heard from my colleague Senator Murphy, who spoke more specifically about this matter. The particular instance was a $90 million investment in a wood processing mill which is now at risk in northern Tasmania due to the government's haste or inadvertence. The unemployment figure in that region where this investment is at risk is close to 15 per cent. Shouldn't we do something in some small way by seeking to encourage such investments in high areas of unemployment? Are the government serious about assisting rural and regional Australia, or will we get just more rhetoric from the government that they are great supporters of regional and rural Australia? I say to the government: support your rhetoric with action and support Labor's amendment.

I make a particular entreaty to the Greens, the Democrats and the Independent members in this chamber to see this as a way in which we can merge towards the principle that we all support in terms of the ratio being reduced from three to one to two to one, but quarantine from that overnight change areas of high unemployment in Australia so that the reduction is slower and so that major investments of the sort that Senator Murphy has referred to which will create jobs for people in those regions can go through and give them a chance to look forward to work opportunities. I do support very strongly what Senator Murphy said about the particular project in northern Tasmania that he referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wesley Vale, was it?

—No, this is the Hokishan plant of medium‐density fibreboard. It is taking from the forest wood which is not commercial, not able to be milled as planks or turned into woodchips, and melding it into fibreboard as a building material. So materials that would normally either be burnt off or be in many cases too small for chipping can have a commercial value. That is an investment that therefore means that in terms of forestry—
—Why is your party so hypocritical in relation to this versus Wesley Vale?
—In terms of forestry, Australia is getting the maximum use of an important resource. Materials that would not be used can now be used. It is for export.
—Why the hypocrisy on Wesley Vale?
—Order! Senator Campbell!
—Talk about hypocrisy.
—Senator Campbell, I ask you to withdraw that.
—I just said, `Talk about hypocrisy'. Do I need to withdraw that?
—You said `hypocritical' before.
—I stand and withdraw.
—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman.
—Talk about your hypocrisy on Wesley Vale.
—Senator Campbell, I ask you to withdraw again.
—I withdraw. Talk about the Labor Party's hypocrisy on Wesley Vale.

—Let me not be diverted by this. Let me get back to the issue. Here is a $90 million project in an area of unemployment in excess of 15 per cent and where my amendment will help that investment go ahead and create some hope for those people in this region. That is a laudable thing. As I was saying, when you actually look at the type of project this is, you see that it takes materials that would not otherwise be used and turns them into a product which can be used for housing construction. So that is in itself the best use of resource. This is an investment to add value to a basic material and therefore get a higher return to the nation because of the value adding process. It is primarily for export, so it will earn export dollars as well. That is a commendable example of what this amendment would do, and I seek the support of the chamber on it.

BREAK.PARA: There have been some interjections during my remarks. If the interjection were true—I put that on the basis that I do not believe the interjection is true—I put this to the government: if you think that Labor were wrong about what they did at Wesley Vale, that is not a reason to vote down our amendment, because on this amendment you would have to agree that Labor is right. It is a classic fallacy to say: `You were wrong then, so we will vote against something that is right now.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not saying that. I am saying you guys are hypocrites.
—You are saying that we are hypocrites.
—Senator Campbell, I ask you to withdraw again.
—You are allowed to say that. You are allowed to say that the Labor Party are hypocrites.
—I am asking you to withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—If you think we are saying one thing and doing another, if that is your point, then I am sure you will vote for this so that the accusation you make against us, which I deny, cannot be used against you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook has accused us of acting in haste to close down a tax avoidance loophole, a loophole that Senator Cook knows favours foreign companies and advantages them over Australian companies. If we stand accused of acting in haste to close down tax loopholes, we plead guilty. In relation to the interjections, we are not set to draw a distinction between this amendment and accept the validity of this amendment versus the action in relation to Wesley Vale. Senator Cook, in his contribution in the committee stage debate, put forward an argument that would have been eloquent and convincing in the series of cabinet meetings that discussed Wesley Vale. I think former Senator Peter Walsh outlined those cabinet meetings in his recollection of them. If I have accused him wrongly of detailing the processes that surrounded those cabinet meetings, then I apologise in advance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook's was an eloquent speech in favour of the decision to proceed with the Wesley Vale pulp mill in the late 1980s. From what I know of Senator Cook I suspect he made a similar sort of speech in that cabinet meeting. It was an eloquent speech and a sound argument for proceeding with that project in terms of downstream processing, using resources and creating jobs in Tasmania. It certainly supports the amendment moved by Labor in relation to changing the thin capitalisation measures. However, the government believes that there are a number of significant problems with it. I will outline those.

Firstly, our legal advice is that the measure would be constitutionally invalid because it would discriminate between labour force regions in the various states. Of equal weight in the government's mind is that it would create further opportunities for tax avoidance. So in other words, you put this measure in and you open this gate for access to special thin capitalisation measures for foreign companies. But as you open that gate, you allow other people through it. To give you an example through you, Madam Temporary Chairman, for Senator Murphy's benefit and Senator Cook's benefit, it would be quite easy for a company to arrange to earn some of its income in a labour force region of high unemployment without being physically located in that area. This would enable such companies to continue to avoid paying their fair share of Australian tax for at least the next five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, can I go to what Senator Campbell seems to be pursuing. He says: `You did not support Wesley Vale.' Senator Campbell, I do not know how much you know about Wesley Vale, but I would think not a great deal. I do not expect that you would need know to great deal about it, but I say for your benefit that this is a totally different issue. The issue surrounding the development of the Wesley Vale pulp mill—and there were many, but one of the principal ones—involved environmental concerns, to do with the effluent and outflow.

SPEECH.PARA: A process was put in place by the then government to resolve those issues but that was in no way the thing that undid the development of the Wesley Vale pulp mill. If you went into the detail you might find that one of the key factors that impacted on the Wesley Vale pulp mill not proceeding was a number of decisions taken by one of the major partners involved in that proposed development. It had nothing do with the government at the end of the day. Sure, the government took some steps to ensure that the environmental controls with respect to effluent and outflow were in line with world's best practice—in hindsight the right decision.

The other major difference with regard to the project that this amendment is primarily intended to assist is that the wood proposed to be used will ultimately be plantation based wood. The Wesley Vale pulp mill development would have seen an increase in the use of native forest hardwood. It is not that I was opposed to that. It was one of the major concerns, but it was not one that I necessarily opposed.

The other important factor is that this is totally export oriented—totally. None of this product will be sold within Australia. Moreover, it is a development that proposes one of the best downstream processing models. It uses low grade wood and turns it into a very high quality product—a product that is still seeing high degrees of development. That development will continue.

I would have thought any government, and any Democrat senator, who is interested in industry development would like to support such development. Senator Campbell, I do not accept what you are saying with regard to `legally invalid constitutionally'. Nor do I accept your argument that a company could proceed. If they are the problems, then I am sure that this amendment could be further modified to take account of those difficulties. If they are the two things that you see as being reasons for not supporting this amendment, then I am sure they can be overcome.

The big question for you, Senator Campbell, and the government is this: whether or not you support development of industries in regions of Australia where there is high unemployment. That is the big question. The government has made many noises on this issue, but it does not seem prepared to follow them up with action. So that is where you are at. If you think there are a couple of problems with our amendment, I am sure that they can be attended to and, if need be, we can take some time to address that and then bring the amendment back. But, as I have said, the big question for you, Senator Campbell, and the government is this: whether or not you are prepared to support areas where there is really high unemployment.

I will make just one point about George Town and the George Town area. According to the 1996 census figures, unemployment in the George Town area was 20.9 per cent; the participation rate was 33½ per cent. That is a very serious problem. We have also had the closure of a couple of other processing plants there, one which related to aluminium wheels. Those figures are likely to be worse now. We have also lost around 170 jobs at a plant called Southern Aluminium.

We desperately need assistance in Tasmania. I again remind you, Senator Campbell, and other government senators that it was your government that made a very clear statement and commitment to Tasmania: you would do whatever you could to assist our state—the state with the highest unemployment of any state or territory in Australia—and take whatever steps you could.

Here is but one small step that the government can take. I hope—just as I hope Senator Murray might see fit also to encourage—that such a step will be taken to support industry development in my state and specifically in a region of my state that is suffering very badly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Three issues arise as a result of Labor's amendment. The first issue is that of regional development. The second issue is that of unemployment. And the third issue is that of the specific needs of northern Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: If we deal with regional development first, it was our great regret as Australian Democrats—and I think a regret shared by most of the non-government parties in this chamber—that the 1996 budget, known as Treasurer Costello's budget, colloquially now known as the `slash and burn budget', hammered funds for regional development. In fact, my memory recalls that something like $160 million was withdrawn from that budget, and numerous and very effective offices were closed as a result. I am hopeful that, having learned the lessons of a scorched earth policy, the government's new reorganisation of its ministry will, in fact, contribute to recovering some ground in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's like shifting the deckchairs on the Titanic .

—Well, they have put local government, territories and regional development together. So, regardless of where you stand with politics in this chamber, I think it is in the interests of Australia that its rural, remote and regional areas have special attention given to their advancement, in terms of both traditional rural pursuits and industrial development, where appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think our great concern with the government and regional development is that there is still no plan, no vision, no sense of direction. I do hope that, as it progresses in its term, the government will begin to advance plans in that area which will win back some of the losses consequent to policy and budget cuts. The first thing we have to say is that any tax assistance to regional development issues which advance the cause of regional development in a positive sense would, in principle, be welcomed not only by us but I am sure by every party in the chamber.

BREAK.PARA: The second issue—and the first and second issues are not necessarily the same—is that of unemployment. Senators would be aware that there are regional areas where there is no unemployment—and thank goodness for that. One of the ones I know of is the Barossa Valley. I am not sure that there are too many others. But I do know that, in the Barossa Valley, there is always a shortage of workers if actual work needs to be done. It is one of those lucky areas, quite frankly, which does better than much of regional Australia.

As opposition senators have rightly pointed out, it is more common than not that the unemployment rate on average in regional Australia is worse in many respects than the average for the country as a whole. Once again, the useful focus provided by the Labor Party amendment is that it says, `Look, you need to provoke tax devices which pay attention to advancing the cause of lowering unemployment.' It does not mean that if you are unemployed in a region of only four of five per cent unemployment it does not matter as much as it would if you were in a region of 20 per cent unemployment. If you are unemployed, it hurts. But it is the case that the community can cope with a lower percentage of unemployment better than with a high level of unemployment in the double figures. Again, in principle, it is our belief that we should focus on unemployment levels which are higher than the country's average.

The third point that I want to make is relevant to the needs of northern Tasmania. It seems inappropriate to me to advance a major change in tax recommendations and tax policy for the sake of one company. It concerns me that this particular policy—which has some substance intellectually speaking and therefore should generate some support—is driven by the needs of looking after one company. I am not sure that it is right to change the tax policy for Australia as a whole when one company has a particular need, even if it might be a good case.

This is not a minor change. If it were a minor change, nobody would care, but this is a major change. I would have preferred Labor to have put forward an amendment which asks the government to look at the relation ship between regional development, tax incentives and unemployment and then come back to us with a report detailing their opinion on the most appropriate way to drive industry development in the regions and to lower unemployment.

Senator Cook, you know where my heart is with this stuff. I am supportive of your general intention, but I am not sure that this is the appropriate vehicle or method in which to drive it. If it is driven by one company's needs, however good that case may or may not be, I find it difficult to support it, because it offends the general principle of how tax legislation should be dealt with. Accordingly, I will not support your amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words in a final effort to persuade senators to accept this amendment. The argument put by the government falls into two categories. The first one is: what did you do in Wesley Vale? That argument is a red herring, and I have dealt with it before. In any case, I think that Senator Murphy dealt with it more extensively. What I did in cabinet is a matter of cabinet confidentiality, but my conscience is absolutely clear on these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The other argument put by the government is whether or not our amendment is constitutional. This is an argument that gets trotted out every now and again when there is nothing else to say. It radiates the sense that maybe you are treading on very dangerous legal grounds. I am not at all persuaded on this occasion that what we are doing is anything close to unconstitutional at all. I am not a constitutional lawyer, and that ought to be taken into account, but my clear understanding of the constitution is that you cannot discriminate between states.

This amendment looks at areas of Australia where there is high unemployment. Maybe there would be a constitutional argument if all of the regional areas of high unemployment in Australia were in one state. Someone might hold, therefore, that it was discrimination positively in favour of a particular state, but senators in this chamber know that high levels of unemployment occur in regions throughout Australia and in many states of Australia.

BREAK.PARA: I am not sure whether there are high levels of unemployment in all states, but I suspect there are. Therefore, you could put that this provision is analogous to the tax zone rebates provisions: where those zones take up particular regions of Australia and are regarded as constitutional. I think that is the appropriate analogy here. Ergo, I regard that the regions that we would identify here would also be constitutional.

Bear in mind that their identification is a moving target. The effect of my amendment would be that, if those regions fell below the level of four per cent above the average of unemployment, the change sought by the government would immediately apply. If the amendment worked to the extent that it attracted investment in those regions which reduced unemployment, the effect would be that the bill in its present form would apply.

In this battle against unemployment there is no simple and easy solution, and all ideas should be boldly tried. I wonder whether Warwick Smith, the member for Bass, has considered in detail what his constituents in George Town face with an unconscionably high level of unemployment in that area. I wonder whether he would have voted for this amendment or whether he would have been locked up by the government and voted against it.

The point I am making is that, if it does attract investment, the government gets its bill and unemployment is lower. That is a win-win outcome for everyone. If it does not attract investment, then it phases down and eventually the government will get the full weight of its current legislation.

The third argument raised in this debate came from a quarter which I always have great regard for and pay great attention to. It came from Senator Andrew Murray of the Australian Democrats. Senator Murray is a knowledgeable person in this field so one would be wise to listen carefully to what he has said. I understood, though, that what Senator Murray is saying on this occasion is that he feels constrained not to support our amendment because it looks shamelessly like a way in which you can support one company—those are my words, not his. If that is the proposition, can I say that that is not the intention of the opposition at all.

We have used a graphic example of where this would apply, and it therefore appears that there is just one case, and only one case. I have not been able to be exhaustive and look at all other areas where unemployment would be four per cent above the mean but I am sure that if we were to do that exhaustively there would be many other areas too where this could apply, and not necessarily in the type of industry that we are talking about here in northern Tasmania but in other sorts of industries that have a rural connection. What springs to mind immediately are some areas where there is some old mining activity. The mines are running out and the future for those regions is bleak. There are other downstream processing possibilities in mine site reclamation, stockpile review or slagheap re‐filtering that could create further employment and, who knows, this may follow.

So, to the third argument: it may look as though it is supporting one company in one given area but I remind the Senate that this applies to all areas of high unemployment in regional Australia and I do think there would be other cases in which other companies would be interested in taking advantage of what is after all a very small loophole, a very small change.

I conclude by saying that we support the principle at play here. We have said that all along. In fact, I think we said it first and sought to close off this principle first. So we are not here saying that we do not believe that tax avoidance should somehow be curtailed, nor are we here able to be accused of supporting tax avoidance. We are on the record clearly about that right from day one and have been consistent about it. But in the closing‐off of this loophole, and balancing that against the other evil of high unemployment in regional Australia, we think there is a phasing mechanism that can apply that will create a win‐win outcome. It is for that reason I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats recognise the problem inherent in the government's original proposal for charitable trusts. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No 4) 1997, as introduced into the House, had the potential to prevent funds being distributed overseas, even for missionary or aid purposes. The government corrected this in the House of Representatives but has acknowledged that some trusts might still be picked up. The concern was that the spill would apply from budget night on 22 August 1996, but the draft legislation was not produced until some months later and not introduced into the parliament until June, 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result, a number of charitable trusts have apparently distributed funds offshore, without realising or appreciating that such an action would result in their losing tax exempt status. The Democrats have had discussion with the government on this issue and informed the government that we believe the August operative date is unfair and that the bill should rather apply from the beginning of this financial year. The government has now brought that forward as a formal amendment, and I want to record the thanks of the Australian Democrats to the government for taking that action and for correcting weaknesses in the bill. We will be supporting the government amendments fully and, therefore, we would expect Senator Cook's amendment to fall away.

I should point out that a trust does not lose tax exempt status for distributing donations. These measures apply only to income earned by a trust which would otherwise have been assessable. When charitable trusts become aware that distributions overseas can still be made out of donated money, I think that this measure will not occasion some of the concern that it might have occasioned at first glance. The government's bill is, by and large, a very welcome bill. It is a well‐conceived piece of legislation, and your ability to listen to concerns and to correct weaknesses and inadequacies is to your credit. I thank you for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret this, but I have just received advice in the chamber, consequent upon my last remarks to the chamber about whether these amendments meet the needs of the trusts concerned.
