This grant was allocated because it meets the abovementioned guidelines and will assist the development of a new visitors centre, as the old centre could not accommodate the growing number of visitors to Monkey Mia.

In addition to promoting Monkey Mia, it will have the dual purpose of assisting visitors with information about the Shark Bay world heritage area, Hamelin Pool, Shell Beach, the Francois Peron National Park, the Kennedy Ranges and Dirk Hartog's landing. Dirk Hartog came to Western Australia in 1616, long before Cook came up the eastern Australian coast.

I recently launched the Green Corps program in Shark Bay, which is in the Francois Peron National Park. It is a very lovely area and is an extremely useful example of the initiative of the government in helping to develop infrastructure in some of these places. The group in Shark Bay is renovating the Old Denham Homestead and helping to prepare a resource centre for tourists. This project is integrated with the aims and objectives of funding allocated through the national tourism development fund. The project is also linked to programs within the $1 billion commitment under the National Heritage Trust.

Australia and, in particular, Western Australia must capitalise on the natural benefits of areas such as Shark Bay and the Ningaloo Reef through ecologically sustainable tourism enterprises to provide opportunities for business growth and employment in regional and rural Australia. Another project which received funding was Oxers Lookout, in the Karijini National Park. The Karijinis used to be known as the Hamersley Ranges, and Oxers Lookout was named after a Wittenoom doctor who loved the Hamersley gorges. After he died his ashes were scattered through the area. The lookout, which is located in a high position in the Hamersley Ranges, was causing safety concerns, so it was allocated a grant to assist the financing of two new lookout platforms and the provision of picnic tables and wheelchair access. This project is strongly supported by local tourism associations, the Karijini Aboriginal Corporation and tour operators who share concerns about the safety of visitors to this area.

Again in Western Australia in the Kimberley region, a group called Kimberley Cultural Expeditions was provided a grant to assist the operations of its 10‐day cultural tour from Broome to Kununurra. This venture is Aboriginal‐owned and involves 10 Aboriginal communities who give tourists insights into the Kimberley region and some experience of Aboriginal culture, for example, samples of bush tucker. The project aims to attract an increased number of domestic and international tourists to the Kimberley region, and will provide employment opportunities for indigenous communities. It will also enable participating communities to enjoy the economic benefits of tourism and will be used as an incentive to pursue new tourism ventures in the area.

In the 1997‐98 budget, the Federal Government also announced an extension to the export market development grants scheme which will enable tourist operators to access funding through this program. This will mean that tourist operators will be able to enhance the export marketing of their programs and claim as promotional expenses, for instance, the actual cost of providing samples of these services to wholesalers.

During 1996‐97, 375 Western Australian companies received more than $20 million in export market development grants. As I have stated, from 1997‐98 tourist operators will be able to access these grants. I encourage tourist operators throughout the country—especially those in the north—to consider applying for such grants, which will greatly assist them in developing their programs.

The Kimberley Tourist Association has also initiated a regional awards scheme to increase recognition of quality tourist operations in that area. The various categories include a land operator award, a charter operator award, an accommodation award, an individual award, an aviation award and a new product development award. These awards, which were presented only a few days ago at Fitzroy Crossing, sought to recognise those who have contributed to tourist development in one of the more remote areas of Australia. The awards give recognition to the innovation and enterprise of the people involved in developing tourism in the Kimberley area.

I congratulate the Kimberley Wilderness Adventure tour operator, which was the winner of the land operator award; Triple J, the winner of the charter boat operator award; Singlair Heliwork WA, winners of the aviation ward; `Kimberley Klub', the winner of the accommodation award; and the Broome Brewery and Matso's Gallery, the winner of the new product development award. The individual award was given to Steve Sharpe from Lake Argyle Cruises. I congratulate all the winners of these inaugural awards and commend the contribution they have made to regional and rural employment in the north‐west.

Finally, of importance in terms of access to the north of Australia is international air access. There are presently target markets of backpackers in South‐East Asia who come down as far as Thailand and Indonesia and who could be encouraged to come into Australia. There is a need for a loosening up of our approach to international access so that we can bring some of these European tourists—who get as far as South‐East Asia—directly into the north‐west of Western Australia, the Northern Territory and North Queensland more easily than happens at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon, in this matters of public interest debate, I will address the issue of recent criticisms of and by the judiciary generally. Honourable senators may recall recently that the Chief Justice of the High Court embarked on an attempted defence of the judiciary in his recent speech to the 30th Australian Legal Convention, where he was somewhat critical of the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams).

SPEECH.PARA: His Honour's comments were variously reported and attracted headlines such as `Bombshell by the Chief Justice'. His speech was described as `slamming the Attorney‐General', which of course gave an opening to the shadow Attorney‐General (Senator Bolkus) to enter onto the stage as well. At best it was very naive of His Honour to give the opposition such an opening; at worst, a deliberate entry into the political fray. I must say I believe it was the former.

What was this bombshell? His Honour was upset that the Attorney‐General did not defend the High Court and the judiciary against political attacks. He asked, `Why should an Attorney‐General not defend the reputation of the judiciary, explain the nature of the judicial process and repel attacks?' The chief justice's desperate plea for someone to defend the judiciary is, I submit, pitiful, but also exposes the chief justice's incapacity to comprehend the judiciary's self‐made problem.

Once you have lost respect you are not going to win it back by trying to bully the Attorney‐General into running a defence on behalf of the court. The simple fact is the attacks on some elements of the judiciary are the products of those same judicial officers playing politics and being political. The chief justice must surely understand that, just as an umpire cannot don the colours of his favourite team and then demand respect for the independence of his decisions, similarly judges cannot stoop to partisan political debate and then claim immunity, trying to hide under wig and gown.

I believe His Honour would have done a greater service to this nation and the concept of separation of powers and respect for the judiciary if he had called upon his fellow judges to refrain from political controversy and abide by legal principles. Such a message would have automatically commanded respect. His injudicious demand seeking respect will, I fear, have the opposite impact. You cannot demand respect; you can only command it and then, by your own presentation.

The chief justice is surely not oblivious to the behaviour of some of his fellow judges. Examples of this behaviour include a Supreme Court judge addressing a rally called to dissuade the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) from pursuing certain amendments to the Native Title Act. According to the chief justice we should accept such partisan behaviour. I submit that such behaviour disqualifies the judge from the respect the chief justice craves, as does the behaviour by a Federal Court judge who attacked the government's 10‐point plan in response to the Wik High Court decision, and urged people to see something sinister about the plan.

That judge's criticism was at a forum where I was present, and it was more strident than that of the Aboriginal activist who was putting the indigenous case. One wonders why a judge of the Federal Court found it necessary to be so strident and, indeed, extreme and political in that criticism. Unfortunately, every level of the judiciary is tainted by the antics of some who are clearly—in my mind, at least—frustrated legislators. Possibly the most gross example is that of the Chief Justice of the Family Court. I note with interest that the previous government, through its now shadow Attorney‐General, said of this judge that he had `damaged the integrity of his office with his ill‐informed and factually incorrect comments.' They were the words of the then minister for immigration, Senator Bolkus, the now shadow Attorney‐General.

Many of us on this side of politics find ourselves agreeing with Senator Bolkus—albeit that it is somewhat distasteful for us to be seen to do so. Both sides of politics have had occasion to highlight this behaviour which, unfortunately, reflects poorly on the judiciary as a whole. In an expose of the Family Court, recently printed in the Sydney Morning Herald, we are told, `The court is a very nasty political place,'—the `court' being the Family Court—`the way they got rid of people they did not want absolutely appalled me.' Yet the Chief Justice of the Family Court tells us politicians how to run the affairs of state when his own court is subject to substantial criticism.

Further, the chief justice's attack on One Nation is, I submit, similarly unacceptable. Let me state for the record that I agree personally with his criticisms of One Nation, but I do not believe it is appropriate for a judicial officer to come into a political debate taking one side or the other. Although I agree with his criticisms of One Nation, my argument is that it is not for him to make those sorts of criticisms. I would submit that it is not for a judge in a non‐judicial context to accuse an elected parliamentarian of `bigotry, xenopho bia, racial intolerance and misinformation', and then make links with Nazism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope she never has to go to his court.

—Senator Ian Macdonald raises the point, `I hope she never has to go to his court' and that is the point I am about to make, Senator Macdonald. You, as a former lawyer like myself, understand the principles very well. It is the exactly the same behaviour that the Chief Judge of the High Court railed against when he sought protection from politicians who make allegations that the High Court has made the country ungovernable. The question, of course, has to be asked. If I were a family court lawyer and I happened to know that my client's spouse had somehow had an involvement in One Nation, take the tip: if I knew the Chief Judge was going to sit on that case, I would try to wangle it into the affidavit material to let His Honour know that the person on the other side had in fact had some involvement with One Nation—because the judge had already shown a gross bias towards One Nation. I might add that it is a bias which I personally share with His Honour, but he should not have been making those sorts of comments in the gratuitous way that he did.

SPEECH.PARA: Another example can be seen on page 636 of the Hansard of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee of 7 March 1997 where we were discussing legal aid, and the Family Court put in a submission signed off by the Chief Judge. This statement was in it:
The economic rationalist argument that `the community can no longer afford it' does not stand up to international comparisons . . . and is, in any event, a generalisation without substance . . .

I would have thought, with respect, that if the Family Court were concerned about these matters they could have sent along a non‐judicial registrar who could have given expression to those sorts of concerns on behalf of the Family Court administration, without the judge involving himself in that sort of partisan comment. I put to His Honour, `I am just wondering about the wisdom of the judiciary embarking upon such a course.' His Honour replied:

BREAK.PARA: I understand that there are difficulties about that course. But I am certainly not going to back off from what the court has said in relation to these matters, because we do think there is a mistaken approach being taken.

Take the tip. If he thinks the federal government and the executive have taken a mistaken approach to certain elements of those things which are clearly within the province of government, why should it then be that we as parliamentarians are not allowed to comment on those things which are clearly in the judicial domain when judges make decisions? It is a two‐way street. The judges in this country cannot have it both ways—as seems to be the case, as it has been presented by His Honour Chief Justice Brennan.

I will make further reference to His Honour the Chief Judge of the Family Court. In an address on 3 August 1996 to the Law Society of Western Australia, he was basically defending himself in relation to a speech that he had made. On page 8 of that speech in Western Australia, he said:

One of the most unusual responses from a politician was that my remarks reflected `narrow cast but very trendy beliefs'—a rather unusual claim to fame for a Judge! They were also considered `an attack on the institution of the family' and a step towards a `non‐reproductive society' which had to be fought `tooth and nail.'
Just in case we did not know who had said all those things, he kindly footnoted it and told us that it was the Deputy Prime Minister of this country, Mr Tim Fischer.

If the judge is going to make comments about political debate in this country gratuitously when he is invited to give speeches, he does invite political partisan comment in return. That unfortunately embroils His Honour in partisan political debate where there is a conflict of ideas and a conflict of values, and I believe that that besmirches His Honour then when he seeks to sit on the bench and be seen as completely independent and above the political fray. Let me also say that on page 11 of that speech His Honour tells us:
It is instructive to observe how far behind this country is on issues such as this when compared to Canada—
and he is talking about another matter now—
with its Charter. In this country a Bill of Rights is anathema to most conservative lawyers and politicians and quite a few on the Labor side of politics.

What is a judge, who is still a sitting judge on a bench, doing by engaging himself in a major political debate as to whether this country ought to have a bill of rights or not? In fact, that was tried as a referendum some time ago, albeit as a limited bill of rights, and was overwhelmingly rejected by the people of Australia. I think that that course of conduct by a judge is most unwise.

One thing that disturbed me deeply was in this same speech at page 16, where His Honour commented on a first instance decision of 1983 known as L and L, which suggested that a court faced with a homosexual applicant should consider a checklist of factors. I will not delay the Senate with what those factors ought or ought not be, but he then goes on:
Interestingly, the correctness of the L and L approach has not been the subject of a challenge before a Full Court.
And then, wait for this:

I cannot say what a Full Court would do with such an issue, but I would hope that the passage of years and the resulting change in community attitudes would be reflected in the Court's consideration of the matter.

Basically he is saying right up front, `If this matter comes before me or any of my brother or sister judges on the Family Court of Appeal, I would hope that they would make a different determination.' Any person who would then be in the position of appealing such a case to the Family Court would undoubtedly think that they had a head start, and the opponent of such a case would realise that they were behind the eight‐ball right from the beginning.

I think I have set out enough examples where the judiciary have let themselves down. I plead with the judiciary to stay out of politics. Having said that, I trust that this country can return to a proper separation of powers, where judges stay out of politics and where the politicians do not make the sort of adverse criticism of our judges that we have witnessed over the past year or so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many people in this country at this point in time who are rather vexed by the fall in the stock market—not just this stock market, but a number of stock markets around the world. I do not intend to come before the Senate today and say, `I told you so,' but there are a lot of commentators who have been saying that a stock market correction has been long overdue. I am of the belief that the correction which we are seeing has, in fact, been long overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: What worries me is that many of the people who invested in the stock market were perhaps unaware of the savageness with which the market can correct itself. For example, the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong eight days ago was standing at 12,403.1 points. Yesterday, it closed at 9,059.89 points. In other words, it was 17 per cent down on where it was a week beforehand. There have been similar falls across other markets.

It is interesting to note that there have been substantial falls in some markets versus where they were on 1 January. For example, the stock market in Hong Kong has lost 31.3 per cent of the value it had on 1 January. The Australian stock market is down 13.9 per cent on where it was on 1 January.

It is appropriate for us to ask: what is the cause of this stock market volatility? If this was all reasoned investment based on the fundamentals of the companies in question, then one would doubt that there would be huge swings and lurches in the stock market. What has in fact happened is that we have seen an enormous amount of speculation; not investments in the companies in the hope of getting a return in the way of a dividend, but investments in the companies in the hope of getting a capital gain. Where has all this money come from? That is the question we have to ask ourselves.

In large part, the money which has been gambled on the stock markets has resulted from the excess money that has been in the superannuation funds. Why do I say that? A couple of years ago I did a survey which showed that the stock market, if you took all of the new issues coming on to the market, could only absorb between one‐quarter and one‐sixth of the new moneys paid into the superannuation system in that same 12‐month period.

Of course, honourable senators will know that the new capital raisings are not all available to the superannuation funds. Some will be rights issues and so on, so that they cannot all be taken up. So what you have is a situation where there are excess funds in the superannuation system, and they are literally being punted on the stock market and demand is driving up the prices of the shares to unrealistic heights. One only has to look at the price‐earnings ratios of some of these shares to see that the fundamentals were not backing up the investments that were being made. On top of that, we now have a low growth environment and, on top of that, we have seen a collapse of the South‐East Asian bubble.

There are certain things that can be done to protect against one's nest egg being at risk on the stock market. I am very glad to see that we have been joined by the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, because—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget me!
—Hear, hear!

—I note you, too, Senator Parer, and Senator Herron. But I want to single out Senator Kemp for particular praise because Senator Kemp will recall that about four or five years ago he and I were campaigning for retirement savings accounts. One of the reasons we campaigned for retirement savings accounts was so that people could shift their superannuation savings out of the stock market and into a more secure environment. That, I believe, is important. And I believe that this stock market crash vindicates, Senator Kemp, the stand that you and I, and others on this side of the chamber, took when we were in opposition, because that is very important.
—A bit of a long bow.

—Senator Mackay interjects that it is a bit of a long bow. It is not a bit of a long bow. The facts are that somebody who plans to retire next year, or this year, unless there is an equally sharp upturn in the stock market, will find that they do not have the money in their superannuation that maybe they had been expecting to have. This stock market correction will affect many people who are close to retirement age who had, for whatever reason, left their funds with superannuation funds that had invested heavily on the stock market.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another problem as well. I believe that we have a structural problem. The structural problem is that we have too many superannuation funds. I believe that we would have been better to go the Singaporean route. That decision has been very much made for us, and it is very difficult to unscramble the egg. But if we had taken a route where we said to people, `We expect you to make a higher rate of contribution, get a lower rate of return, but your savings will be guaranteed so that what is there today will definitely be there tomorrow, and maybe a little bit more,' then we would not find this problem where people's savings have been so heavily savaged by the corrections in the stock market.

I believe what the government now needs to do is give consideration to whether it is a good idea to have hundreds of superannuation funds out there competing with each other, replicating administration costs, replicating promotional costs. Or maybe, when we talk about the contributions that people make from their own wages as opposed to the contributions that employers make on their behalf, it might be a good idea to put those funds into a lower risk, lower growth, centralised superannuation system so that they can quarantine a portion of their superannuation contributions from corrections in the market, and ultimately we will ensure that fewer people are hit as badly as many soon to be retired people will be hit by this correction in the stock market.

My prediction is that there are many people who would like to retire at the end of this year or next year and who will now defer their retirement because of the correction in the stock market, because their superannuation nest egg is not what they want, and that will have consequences for unemployment. I believe we now need to look at the superannuation system as a whole and try to find ways to ensure that people's savings are better protected than they are at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of a decision by the West Australian Department of Health and Family Services approving the transfer of and a new provider number for 63 elderly Perth nursing home residents who, as a consequence, will now be charged up‐front entry fees of up to $65,000 to move across the road when their run‐down nursing home closes next year? Can the minister confirm that this approval is based on advice from the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services? Minister, will you guarantee that these fees will not be charged and honour your promise that no person already in a nursing home before 1 October will have to pay the new accommodation bond?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little concerned for the health of the questioner—
—You're a surgeon. I'm sure you can fix that.

—Not as a surgeon. I think it would need a physician. Then, again, I think it might have been a little bit of a rush to get here—a simple physiological cause. I take it that Senator Neal is referring to the Corrinya Nursing Home in Western Australia. I assume that. There has been a press report in relation to the Corrinya Nursing Home in Western Australia. Is that correct, Senator Neal? Are you asking about the Corrinya Nursing Home?
—It would be the Perth—just answer the question please.

—I am aware of a situation in respect of the Corrinya Nursing Home and I assume it is the same one because Senator Neal referred to a 63‐bed facility. But the principle is the same. The principle applies to other nursing homes in a similar position. The government has said that residents in care prior to 1 October will not have to pay a bond to keep the place they are in. It has always been the case, however, that if a resident moves to a new facility they can be asked to pay a bond if they can afford one. If they paid a bond in the previous facility any bond paid to the new facility would be capped at the amount they were refunded. There was no such protection, I might tell you, Madam President, under Labor's entry contribution scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of Corrinya the residents can choose to move to the new facility next year. The minister understands that most will choose to do so. The new nursing home will be state of the art. Millions of dollars are being spent by the provider to create high quality accommodation with single bed and two‐bed en suites, and even a bed‐sitter for families to stay in when they visit.

I understand that the home's director of nursing has been discussing this with existing residents and their families and that, not surprisingly, the new places are in high demand. It is the provider's intention to continue to care for all of the existing residents in the new building. They are discussing bonds and negotiating sensitively with families to achieve that objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question, Minister, which you failed to answer, was whether you will meet the promise given by this government that no‐one in a nursing home before 1 October will be required to pay an accommodation bond. Will you stand by the promise made by this government in relation to these people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered that question but perhaps I can extend the answer further just to explain it fully. It depends on the means that the person who is going into a nursing home has. If they have assets over $22,500 they may be asked to pay an accommodation bond. We have assured people that that is the state of affairs—it was the same principle under Labor. They will not be forced to do anything. There is no force; it is a matter of negotiation between the provider of the care and the person going into the nursing home.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the minister advise the Senate of the appalling financial position this government inherited from Labor and what progress has been made to fix this economic mess? How will the Charter of Budget Honesty ensure that the Australian community is not deceived again?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for that important question. Senator Coonan, the community may be aware of the Australian fiscal position when we came into government. The reality is that the fiscal position was very poor. This was despite the fact that Labor had promised time after time that the budget was in surplus. I need only remind the Senate of perhaps one of the most famous quotes—certainly one the Labor Party would prefer to forget; certainly Senator Cook would prefer to forget it—of Senator Cook in November 1995. This is what Senator Cook, the recently promoted Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, said:

ANSWER.PARA: This current budget . . . put the budget into surplus—and not just a surplus this year but also a surplus next year . . .

I say to Senator Cook and others that the fact is this: the budget ended up with a deficit of $10.3 billion. Contrast that with Senator Cook's claim that the budget was in surplus. The Labor Party had run up deficits of $70 billion over the past five years. The government debt levels exploded under Labor. Labor policies led to two downgradings of Australia's international credit rating.

This government knows the importance of getting the fundamentals right so that we can maximise our opportunities. That is why this government is turning a $10 billion deficit into a surplus within this term of parliament.

Sadly, it was not enough for Labor to leave the fiscal house in a disgraceful mess, as everybody knows they did; they have used every opportunity to talk the economy down and to undermine confidence in the economy. I bring to the attention of the Senate that yesterday the shadow Treasurer, Gareth Evans, claimed that government policies had made Australia more vulnerable. Not only is this blatantly false, but also it is very irresponsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did you go at the super committee last night?
—You might be interested in this, Senator Conroy. You were not at the super committee last night. One does not know where you were, but apparently it was not so important that you could turn up.

ANSWER.PARA: An article in the Australian noted today that a responsible politician would not utter the words of the ALP deputy leader, Gareth Evans. Labor reiterated their approach to fiscal responsibility last night by attempting to white‐ant the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . Among other things, the amendments that were moved by Labor would lead to the detailed disclosure of tax avoidance opportunities. Their amendments risk making the Public Service a research arm for the opposition. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, last week you took on notice questions, or parts of questions, asked by senators McKiernan, Ray, West, Denman and Gibbs. When will you provide an answer to Senator McKiernan's question on medical expense rebates for nursing home fees; Senator Ray's question on the nursing home promotional campaign; Senator West's question on the effect on middle-aged children with frail aged parents, and the five-year time period; Senator Denman's question on the prudential protections for those who choose to make periodic payments; and Senator Gibbs's question on the income tax and capital gains tax implications for those frail aged who attempt to hang on to their family home? Minister, when are you proposing to provide the Senate with an answer to those very important questions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of those questions required quite detailed answers. In fact, I understand that one of them in particular required information that is not presently available. I am not sure which question it was. Sorry, I will rephrase that: I am not sure who asked that particular question.

ANSWER.PARA: One of them asked for the number of people in nursing homes who had assets over a certain figure. My understanding is that that material is not immediately available. I will provide the answers to the questions as soon as they are available to me. I will ensure that the request that has been made by Senator Faulkner is taken to the relevant ministerial office and we will get back to him as soon as we can. I understand there is a statutory requirement of time to do so, and I am sure we will follow that statutory requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, would you agree that it would be reasonable for those sorts of issues to be considered by governments as they develop policies as controversial as that relating to nursing homes? What is the use of your being available to answer questions in question time if we have to wait days to get answers on issues as important as these—and, when do get them, they are wrong, like the one that you gave to Senator Forshaw yesterday, where you were forced to come into the Senate this morning and correct the record, or attempt to reinterpret the question that was asked.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to draw the attention of the Senate to the track record of the Labor Party when in office in relation to this. I would be happy to produce a comparison for you with the delay that occurred. Senator Faulkner, as you well know, the minister in the other house is provided with a brief of possible questions that might be asked. If questions asked are not in the brief, it is not the right of the relevant minister to make it up as he or she goes; it is a statutory requirement to produce a correct answer to a question.

ANSWER.PARA: If it is not available to the relevant minister who is responding in the other chamber, then it is a requirement to produce an answer from the department or from the minister as soon as possible. That is what I am attempting to do. I will do so for those questions. Some of them obviously will require quite detailed material to be provided. It is not up to me to decide what the fervid imagination of the opposition is going to produce. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of Mr Boutros Harb, a member of the parliament of the Republic of Lebanon. I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. There are media reports today which say that the Labor opposition are now opposed to any further sell-down of Telstra, contrary to the position adopted in their draft policy platform, which provides for a further 16 per cent sell-off of Telstra. Do either of these policy positions commend themselves to the government? What would be the impact on Australia's international reputation if either proposal were adopted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the short answer is that no, neither of these extraordinary propositions do commend themselves to the government. We do not want to be an international laughing stock. We are not prepared to allow our policy positions to be determined by the trade union movement. We are not prepared to hand over a veto, as clearly the Labor Party is prepared to do.

ANSWER.PARA: This issue first arose last week, when the cat was let out of the bag with the draft policy documents saying that Labor was prepared to retain Telstra in majority ownership. We then had a relaxed and comfortable shadow minister saying that Labor had no plans to further sell down, that the conference might approve the document and that the draft was no more than a statement of principles and did not suggest scope for a further sell down.

That is where he stood last week, until of course he realised that this was diametrically opposed to his clients' interests and that in fact not only is his preselection under threat from the phone box minority in South Australia laughingly called `the Bolkus Left' but significant sections of caucus would not have a bar of it.

This is the absolute antithesis of leadership and policy responsibility. The Australian public want to know why you are not prepared to face up to the international reality. If you want to align yourselves with North Korea and Albania, that will not do. I can assure you that you will not get any support for that sort of approach in this country.

We read in today's paper that Mr Beazley, the epitome of pusillanimous leadership, is now telling caucus that he would oppose any further sell down. This is the bloke who has never had the guts to come into this parliament and deny that he told Frank Blount on a number of occasions that he was more than happy to privatise Telstra—probably lock, stock and barrel.

So what has happened is that Mr Gareth Evans, who is desperately keen to get his hands on the money so he can fund a few election promises, went off on a frolic of his own without even consulting, presumably, Mr Beazley or Senator Schacht. What sort of a doormat do we have here? Here is the bloke who is supposed to be responsible for policy clearly having not the faintest idea that this was in the draft policy platform! Can you be any more culpable than that? You have no idea—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because Cheryl Kernot has taken over the job.

—It is no wonder that Cheryl said, `Mr Beazley is a decent bloke, but.' It has to be a `but' in 10-foot high letters after this performance. Poor old Senator Schacht clearly had no idea what was in the draft policy platform or, if he did, he is utterly derelict in his duty as far as the caucus is concerned because they will not wear it. So now he is getting up telling them he is going to draft a motion to be put to the conference ruling out any further sell down.

ANSWER.PARA: This is laughable. This is highly embarrassing for us on the world stage. Let us be perfectly clear about this: there is only one reason why Mr Beazley went to water, as usual, and that is that, if he had not said he was opposed to any further sell down, he would have gone to gaol, because the Telstra offer document, the form of which he approved precisely, said the Leader of the Opposition has stated that the Australian Labor Party is opposed to the further privatisation of Telstra.

So the Leader of the Opposition has gone out there and told the entire Australian population that he is opposed to that, even though we know he is not, at the same time as his deputy has been out there trying to open the door—presumably to renovate the policy and to be freed from the shackles of the trade union movement, but more likely to get his hands on some billions of dollars—and is sitting there hoping he will get away with it and no-one will notice.

What happens? They both go to water as soon as it sees the light of day and Senator Schacht clearly finds himself in an utterly untenable position. It is very bad news for Australia because investors are looking for some sort of policy sense on this issue. They know what has happened around the world. They know that every other democracy has gone down this path years ago and here they find—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the minister confirm that Mr Gerald Wheeler, the Prime Minister's speech writer, is the author of a document dated 17 September addressed to the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy? Does the Prime Minister agree with his speech writer that the convention election is a battle of the mainstream versus politicians, artistic figures, academics, journalists and businessmen? Does the Prime Minister agree with his speech writer that this ballot is the greatest opportunity to vote against people that mainstream Australia has `always hated'? Given the recent reports of death threats and racist abuse directed at some convention candidates, does the minister consider it appropriate that the Prime Minister's speech writer is peddling the politics of hatred and division?
—I saw press reports to which I think the honourable senator is referring. I interpreted it as an episode of comedy hour, Senator. I attach no other significance to it whatsoever.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say I am very disappointed in the minister's response to that question, but I ask him by way of a supplementary question: is it a fact that this advice was penned by Mr Wheeler in the Prime Minister's office using public resources? What inquiries has the Prime Minister made to satisfy himself that this indeed was not the case?
—The Prime Minister has been—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I was wondering whether you could indicate what tenuous link the supplementary question has with the answer given by the Leader of the Government. It bears no relationship to the answer given. It is a completely fresh question, has new issues and is completely unrelated to the answer given.

—On the point of order, Madam President: we have had the Leader of the Government in the Senate indicate that he considers what I think most Australians would think is an important issue—a member of the Prime Minister's staff penning such advice to an organisation—as an episode from comedy hour. It is perfectly proper for Senator McKiernan to follow that up with a supplementary question asking whether there has been a misuse of the Prime Minister's office resources in this. I would ask you to rule the supplementary question in order as a clear follow-up to not only the answer Senator Hill gave but the question that was directed to Senator Hill that was answered in such an appalling way in his attempt to cover up this issue.

—Supplementary questions have come to be more supplementary to the question than to the answer. This falls into that category and, consistent with others similar, I will allow Senator Hill to add anything he wishes to add.

—I was saying, in case the honourable senator had missed the fact, that the Prime Minister was overseas and, I presume, attending to more important matters. The article, as I recall it, suggested that this letter had not been penned on prime ministerial letterhead. I presume, from the tenor of it as reported, this was a private contribution by Mr Wheeler to the debate on the election of delegates to this convention. I did not take it seriously, I suggest other Australians should not take it seriously and I do not think it deserves a reply of any further significance.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Minister, are you aware of a major research project by the World Resource Institute in Washington that shows that 14 developing countries have reduced fossil fuel subsidies by 45 per cent over the last five years, with a significant consequent reduction in consumption and carbon emissions? Is it not the case that many developing countries are now doing more than Australia is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions? In particular, are you aware that Brazil, India and Mexico have launched specific energy efficiency and renewable energy programs at the same time as your government has abolished the Energy Research and Development Corporation? So, Minister, when will you stop using the developing nations' response to greenhouse as part of your excuse for Australia's position as we approach the Kyoto conference?

—The Democrats continue to be determined to undermine the Australian government negotiating position, which I very much regret. There are alternatives to the use of fossil fuel. There is nuclear power. If Senator Lees is suggesting that Australia move to nuclear power, that move will cost a very large sum of money. I presume that is her concern, the capital cost. Some might say that there are other concerns as well. Certainly France has an advantage over Australia in that 75 per cent of its power is produced through nuclear sources.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Can we ask that the minister direct his answer to the question, which was about developing countries and the response of developing countries to the greenhouse issue?
—Senator Hill, I am sure you are aware of the question.

—I am. I am trying to explain to the honourable senator what are the alternatives to burning fossil fuel. One of the alternatives is nuclear power. I was making the point that that is why France can make claims within these negotiations that basically it creates energy through a lower percentage of fossil fuels. But I presume Senator Lees is not advocating that Australia convert to nuclear fuel, firstly, because of the cost of doing so and, secondly, because there is another waste issue involved in it, which is certainly not a greenhouse issue. But the environmental picture does not just involve greenhouse gases; it involves other consequences as well. Similarly, some other countries have an advantage because they are able to utilise hydro-electricity. But I do not think Senator Lees is calling for more dams to be built in Australia.
—You're right. Hooray!

—Correct, is it, Senator Woodley? So you start to rule out the other alternatives, Senator Woodley. You are learning how this works. Certainly there is greater opportunity for the use of natural gas in Australia, but it is to date a much more expensive alternative. Somebody has to pay the cost difference and that has an effect upon GDP growth and therefore upon jobs. We want to encourage the development of the gas market so there will be greater competition from natural gas, and that can contribute to a better greenhouse outcome as well.

BREAK.PARA: Finally, there is the additional factor that, if we can reduce energy consumption or reduce it from business as usual, there is a greenhouse gain, and we accept that. That is why we have had a voluntary program, particularly with industry, to reduce energy consumption on a win‐win basis. It is good for the environment and it is good for their bottom line. So you can get economic benefits as well. Also, that is why we are going to be soon announcing further domestic reforms—as I have said to you, but you have ignored—which will require even greater effort from the Australian people to reduce their consumption of energy. That is okay, because we want Australians to play a constructive role in this international challenge—the challenge to stabilise world greenhouse gases.

We can do it better across a range of sectors. We can do it better in relation to energy production. We can do it better in relation to transport. We can do it better in relation to building and housing infrastructure. We want Australia to do better in these areas, but we do not want to do it at a cost of Australian jobs. That is where we significantly differ from the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I cannot thank the minister for his answer because he did not answer the question, so I will try again. Is it not the case that many developing countries are now doing more than Australia is doing on greenhouse? This had nothing to do with nuclear energy or any other issue that the minister has raised. If he is really stuck for what Australia should be doing, I draw his attention to our document we have put together entitled Saving face at Kyoto . However, Minister, are you now with a clear conscience still going to use the response of the developing world as an excuse for Australia doing very little as we approach Kyoto?

—Senator Lees will not listen. She is determined not to listen. She is determined not to hear a good news story, and that is that the government is determined to grow the economy and create jobs whilst at the same time produce a better environmental outcome. That is what we are all about, but that is not of interest to the Democrats. I know Argentina has entered into an understanding with the United States whereby it, as a developing country, is prepared to come on board and voluntarily contribute to a better global outcome. We are strongly of the view that the developing countries must come on board. As Senator Lees might know, two of the five largest emitters in the world, India and China, are not included in countries that are expected to assume any greater constraint. The third of the five is Russia, which fits into a special category. So three of the five largest emitters are not really going to be bound by anything, short of differentiation in the case of Russia and nothing in the case of the others. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. It follows on from an answer he gave yesterday to a question from Senator Harradine on anti‐dumping. Minister, didn't the coalition promise in its election policy to reduce the maximum investigation period for anti-dumping complaints to 155 days? Yesterday you said that it took 215 days to process a complaint. When are you going to deliver on your election commitment?

—I believe I answered that question yesterday, for Senator Harradine. I pointed out that Mr Willett did a study of the efficiency of the program and the total process was reduced by 30 days following an investigation. That is the shortest period of any country.
—Two hundred and 20 days.
—I am advised by the Minister for Customs that that is the shortest period of any country in the world.

—I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you did say yesterday that it was reduced to 215 days but your election promise was to reduce it to 155 days. Your former minister Mr Prosser indicated that you had referred this matter to the ADA in terms of achieving the 155 days. Mr Fraser from the Anti-Dumping Authority advised the estimates committee last August that he had received no such direction from the government. You might like to answer that, Minister.

—I do not think there is anything I can add. I gave a broad answer yesterday to Senator Harradine. I have given a similar answer that in June 1996—I will say it again—Mr Laurie Willett was appointed to head an external review to determine how best to implement the government's announced policy. His report was completed in 1996. As a result, the time period was reduced by 30 days. You people were there for 13 years. You had this pressure put on you time and time again—and what did you do? You did absolutely nothing.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Parer yesterday said he would refer the matter to the minister and come back with detail. You might like to add some of the detail that you proposed to come back with yesterday, Minister.
—There is no point of order.

—I know it is not a point of order but it does give me the opportunity to respond. Senator Harradine asked specific questions. If Senator Murphy would like to wait, at the end of question time I will come back with the detailed response I promised Senator Harradine yesterday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. I refer to my question without notice to him on 24 September 1997 concerning the expansion of production of uranium at Roxby Downs in South Australia and to his press release dated 11 June 1997. In his response to my previous question he indicated:

QUESTION.PARA: and that includes the consultative committee—
will be called for and appointments made in the near future.

You indicated that you would provide me with further information on the independent audit. At a recent meeting with conservation groups, officials from the environment protection group in your department indicated that they had not seen the audit and the consultative committee has not been formed, let alone met. Minister, what is the problem? Does Western Mining have something to hide? Finally, given that these issues were a condition of approval, what are you doing to progress these important questions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that I said the Olympic Dam environmental consultative committee would be set up. It is in the process of being set up. Appointments are to be made—
—Round up the usual suspects.

—The usual suspects are being rounded up by us, the state government of South Australia and the company and it is being coordinated by my colleague Senator Parer. Upon making further inquiries I understand that Senator Parer is confident that the appointments will be made before the end of this year. So that will all occur within the next couple of months.

ANSWER.PARA: I said to you that, from memory, the audits would be put to that committee. I checked and that was the case. I understand that the first of such audits has been conducted. Therefore, there is no reason why it will not be put to the first meeting of that committee which, as I indicate, should occur shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Has the government got problems with their `round tuit'? It was 11 June originally that the press release was put out. You say `in the next couple of months'. You have said before, `shortly'. If by the end of the year—and of course we will not be here—that means some time next year, can we expect further watering down of these two basic conditions? And what does that say about the other conditions relating to the expansion of uranium mining at Roxby Downs?

—No, there is no watering down of any conditions. What I have just said to the honourable senator is that we are in the process of implementing the undertakings that we earlier gave. I expect the committee to be set up within the next few months. It will be able to meet and consider the first audit report, which on my instructions has already occurred.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Minister, can you quantify the employment losses in industries covered by your portfolio if the European targets on greenhouse gas emission reductions were adopted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank very much for that question. From remarks made by people like Senator Cook and your leader, Mr Beazley, they would not support going down the route of accepting the European proposals because they believe in approaching this in a way which will not adversely affect our industries. The estimates given vary, but one of the estimates is that if we went down that route we could be looking across the board at job losses in the vicinity of 90,000.
—Within your portfolio.

—Madam President, some interjection is coming in there `from within your portfolio'. Some months ago I answered a question, and I think it was to the ex-Senator Kernot, who now, of course, is filling the policy vacuum of the Labor Party—
—Don't laugh at your own jokes, Warwick.

—I am just listening to everyone else laughing, Senator Collins. Areas would be adversely affected. I could not help but notice in the blueprint put out by the Democrats—and they put out their policy on this matter on the same day as Senator Kernot resigned; it was good timing—that one of the areas they talked about as being a `big loser', and I just give you this as an example, would be Yallourn, in Victoria, where there is brown coal for the production of electricity in Victoria. Other areas that would be affected—
—How many jobs would Yallourn lose?

—Just listen to what I have to say, Senator; give us a chance. Other areas that would be affected would be places like the Bowen Basin in Queensland; Gladstone, Senator, from your own state; the Hunter Valley; Newcastle; and, of course, Yallourn.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the major effects—and I notice that this came through in a statement made, I think, by my opposite number, Mr Smith, to say what we should be doing in regard to this, and this is the sort of very point I would be making—the growth that we expect in Australia in the next few years will come from downstream processing. It will come from areas like more alumina refineries, steel mills, and things like that, we hope. They would be the big losers.

TALK.START.PARA: —So just tell us the jobs in those places that would be lost.
—Across the board. He does not know. He is asking me—
—How many jobs would go, Warwick?

—The jobs that would go, Senator, are the jobs that are involved in the projected high growth rates that we are anticipating in this country because of the policies of this government. If you want to put them at risk—
—No, no. Just tell us how many.
—I know that you do not want to put them at risk, although you are all over the place in regard to our response.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht, cease interjecting.

—But there is no doubt that the majority of those 90,000 jobs that have been talked about by ABARE would relate either directly to the portfolio that I represent or to the downstream processing that comes from the energy materials produced by that portfolio.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister, but you did not really answer my question. What I want to know is: how many jobs will be affected in the areas that your portfolio covers?

—Senator, what we are looking at now is the projected growth rate of the Australian economy and where we expect a lot of that to come from. A great amount of that job creation will come from the growth which we are seeing in Australia today of downstream processing. This is the point that you seem to have overlooked: what if that growth does not occur because we had to go down that track of the Europeans, which I might say—and I do not think there is any disagreement from your side—is inequitable, inefficient and will not contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas emission?

—My question is addressed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Minister, the coalition government is committed to ensuring that there is a comprehensive and adequate social security safety net for all Australians. I ask: what progress has been made by your department in upholding the integrity of our social security system? What action is the government taking to reassure Australian taxpayers that social security assistance is going only to those who need it? Finally, how does the record of the coalition government compare with the efforts of the previous government on social security compliance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crane for his question, which is really a very, very important question to Australians. I suppose that is why he was greeted with noise from the opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I am now tabling the DSS fourth quarterly report on compliance activity. Maintaining the integrity of the social security system, while ensuring that there is an adequate safety net for all Australians, has been a major focus of our government. That is why this is also a very, very important report.

The Labor Party said that the system was as tight as a drum when they were in government—as tight as a drum. Former Minister Peter Baldwin claimed that it was of world leading standard. It is also interesting that the Labor Party's own review, after they lost the election last year, found that almost everyone in Australia thought they knew a welfare cheat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Play to the prejudices. Go on, keep on playing to the prejudices.
—You just listen. Taxpayers' money needs to be effectively targeted to ensure the integrity of the system. The taxpayers want this, and so do those who are genuine social security recipients.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—Australians right around this country have said to me that one of their major concerns is that welfare payments are being paid to those who are not entitled to them. This government has heard those concerns. I have insisted, since coming to government, that my department focus on compliance and effective targeting, and we have put the resources in place to enable that to happen, to achieve results.

BREAK.PARA: During 1996-97 there were over 55,000 tip-offs from the public; that measure alone led to over 12,000 cancellations and reductions. Over three million reviews were conducted during 1996-97; that is up almost 28 per cent over the previous year. Also, 333,120 payment cancellations or reductions were put in place; that is an increase of over 40 per cent over your time in government. Debts recovered were $369 million, which is up 47 per cent over the previous year. And just remember this: almost $28 million every week—$28 million every week—was saved as a result of the compliance activity during 1996-97.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many are on three pensions?
—Senator Bolkus, you have been interjecting persistently during this answer.

—This government is serious about maintaining the integrity of the system for the benefit of the Australian taxpayer but also for the benefit of the genuine social security customer. It is not a question of `if you will be caught' if you are cheating, but `when'.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer and I am sure that all Australians will welcome the results she has reported to the Senate.
—They will welcome them and you should welcome them as well. I ask the minister: how does the government's approach to improving compliance with social security compare with that of other countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of concern to many countries. There was in London just a month ago a conference of a number of countries about fraud and compliance. Let me outline what `New Labour' is doing on social security fraud in Britain. After all, it was the Blairesque reshaping which prompted the great defection by Kernot to tired old Labor in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: New Labour in the United Kingdom introduced a new fraud act on 1 July this year. They have spelt out three principles in the fight against social security fraud: fairness, responsibility and honesty. They have appointed a minister to focus on benefit fraud. Their new act includes much tougher penalties and a far tougher approach. And why are they concerned? Because of the loss of funds to the taxpayer, as well as to those who are in genuine need.
The social security minister, Mr Denham, said in July:
The UK aspires to a social security system which is a social asset valued by all and not seen as an ever‐growing burden on taxpayers and open to abuse by a minority.
(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. I ask: is the minister aware of the scam in which some businesses and primary producers avoid paying excise on diesel fuel for off‐farm situations by getting excise free diesel fuel ostensibly for farm use, but actually using it for other purposes such as operating trucking companies? Is it the case that the Customs Service has conducted an extensive and expensive training campaign, involving in New South Wales alone as many as 100 staff, designed to detect diesel fuel excise avoidance? If so, why did the Customs Service advertise on 22 August for outside auditors to carry out this work, rather than the staff it had already trained at public expense?
—Order! Senators on my left are constantly calling out for questions to be answered. In this case you started shouting as soon as I called the minister to answer. You should listen to the answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Senator West has cast a major slur on the rural industry. She has cast a major slur on the farmers.
—Have you read the last Auditor‐General's report, Warwick?
—Senator Collins claims that all the farmers are into a scam, by the sound of it.
—About $40 million a year, Warwick. It's in the report.
—Order! Senator Collins will cease interjecting.
—Let me say that the majority of the farmers are not into scams.
—Correct.
—That was not the implication of Senator West's question.
—The majority aren't.
—Order! Senator Collins, I have already asked you to cease interjecting.

—It is quite obvious from the interjections from the Labor side that they are making the assumption that all people in the rural industry are somehow involved in some sort of scam. There is no doubt that there will always be some people who will play the system. I point out to Senator West that, if my memory is correct, there was a case six or seven months ago where a farmer in Queensland was actually picked up and is now spending some time in gaol because of this. There is no doubt that these things have been going on.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the policing that is happening, it is a Customs job to go around the place making sure that fuel can only be used for specific purposes if people are to claim the diesel fuel rebate. Senators might recall that we put amendments into this place not so long ago to actually prevent these sorts of actions occurring.
Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You were in government for 13 years and you had a section in the Customs Act which said that, if the fuel was bought with the intent of using it for eligible purposes, people would get the rebate; they did not have to use it. We changed that particular act so that it tightened up the system. In fact, the whole basis of many of the amendments we put in in the last few months was to tighten up the system.

ANSWER.PARA: All I can say is that the customs officials are very much aware of this. They do their best to police it and I think they do a pretty good job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The nub of the question was: is it true that there has been an extensive training campaign amongst staff, including 100 or so from New South Wales, to detect the diesel fuel excise avoidance? I am advised that the Customs Service did advertise on 22 August for outside auditors to carry out this work. Why is it going to outside auditors when it has already trained up a significant number of its staff to undertake the same exercise?
—I will refer that matter to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. There will be a perfectly logical explanation. They may be doing both, but I will check it and find out.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, can you confirm that the review of trusts taxation being undertaken by the tax office extends to considering the commissioner's proposal that trusts be taxed in the same way as companies, and also whether partnerships should be taxed in the same way? Do you agree that the neutrality principle in taxation should ensure that taxpayers are taxed on the basis of the income they earn, not on the basis of the taxation entity or structure that they chose? Do you agree that the same neutrality principle should ensure that trusts making income should be taxed in the same way irrespective of whether they are family trusts, discretionary trusts, business trusts or unit trusts? Does this government intend taking tax evasion using artificial structures much more seriously than did the previous government, which allowed the number of trusts to explode by 63,000 and the income funnelled through trusts to explode by a massive $36 billion or 46 per cent in the last three years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray for that question. Senator Murray quite correctly drew attention to the lack of performance of the previous government.
—You knocked our legislation out. Tell the truth.

—Senator Cook, you are getting very excited again because you know what I am going to say. You may not be a genius but you know what I am going to say. Senator Murray, you were quite right to refer to the appalling performance of the previous government in relation to tax avoidance. It is true that after 12 years in government the former Labor government did bring in legislation on trusts—after 12 years. That legislation was never passed. It was referred to a Senate committee and, of course, in due process an election was called. Senator, you were quite right to draw attention to the lethargy of the previous government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, let me state clearly that the government is concerned to ensure that the tax provisions relating to trusts deal appropriately with the modern‐day usage of trusts and do not permit tax avoidance or undue tax minimisation. You were quite right to refer to the Treasury and the ATO. We will release a discussion paper outlining relevant tax issues and broaching policy options. The timing of this will enable the government to consider the matter in the context of the 1998‐99 budget. Of course, the government reserves the right to take earlier legislative action to prevent tax minimisation or avoidance through the use of trusts. It is a complex area and that discussion paper will be very informative to the community.

You raised a number of issues in relation to equity and neutrality. These are always important issues in the consideration of taxation legislation. There are often cases where there is a conflict between making sure that there is proper equitable treatment and some of the other issues that you raise. The reason that we have made these appropriate changes in relation to family trusts is to ensure what we think is a more equitable system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. Senator Abetz, as someone who is a trustee of a family trust, I see great merit in having a similar tax treatment for each legal structure and I will retain my family trust structure for valid personal reasons. However, I do believe that there should be neutrality and equity in the matter. Minister, my supplementary question is: will the government, in examining and reporting on the nature of trusts, quantify in its report the scale of unwarranted evasion or avoidance that it believes may be conducted in the hundreds of thousands of trusts that are currently in the system?

—Senator Murray, I note that you have declared your interests in this question and that was certainly appropriate. This will be an important and comprehensive paper. There will be many issues covered in that paper and I am sure that you and other members of the community—and even the Labor Party, who did practically nothing on this issue in all their years of government—will find it instructive and important.

—My question is directed to Senator Ellison, representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp. Did the previous ministers for both education and science promise to review the government's doubling of HECS charges for university science courses if enrolments fell? Given the three per cent fall in enrolments in 1997, and now the news that, for 1998, science applications have fallen by 7.3 per cent in some states, when will the minister honour the government's commitment?
—I am not aware of the prior statements made by the ministers you refer to, Senator Denman, but—
—What?
—You were here when it was said.

—I do not recall those statements made by the prior ministers. I did not have responsibility for this aspect and nor do I have now. That is the responsibility of Dr Kemp in the other place. I will take the matter up with Dr Kemp and get back to the senator.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Having kept our commitments to privatise one‐third of Telstra and use part of the proceeds to establish an environment rescue package by establishing the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, will the minister inform the Senate as to the progress of the $1.25 billion trust; in particular, the response from community groups in Victoria and what the Victorians can expect from the Natural Heritage Trust this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator, certainly the contrast is there—quite stark—between this government and the ALP. The ALP claimed that it would not privatise public concerns such as the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and the like but, of course, it immediately reneged. I suspect we are seeing the same occurrence, unfortunately, in relation to Telstra at the moment. Mr Beazley says it is not the intention of the ALP to further privatise Telstra. Yet there is an item on the agenda of the national conference to enable him to do so. It sounds like the same rock solid promise that we have heard before from the ALP.

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, we have kept our promise and we are seeking to sell one‐third of Telstra, and we are committed to providing the capital funding for the Natural Heritage Trust out of that money. Under that anticipation we are, as you have indicated, currently making grants to community groups, in particular, to enable them to get on with the task of reinstating the health of Australia's natural environment.

Therein lies another contrast between our approach to environmental matters and that of the ALP. We on this side of the chamber believe that the solution really lies in the hands of the community, the best way to respond is therefore for government to support the community in its efforts and you will get the best result in terms of environmental bottom line. We have very much structured the trust program to achieve that objective.

In that light, we have already been able to indicate that we can support more than 1,000 projects worth $63 million in South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia. What is more important, and consistent with what I have just said, is that the community applications account for more than 60 per cent of the successful projects. Victoria, which is the state you particularly mentioned, Senator, is in line for at least $33 million this year in trust funding. Last Friday we announced 416 successful projects worth $23.8 million, and of these 266 were from community based applications for projects across the state of Victoria.

South Australia will receive at least $24 million from the trust this financial year. I recently announced the first instalment of some $15.7 million for 309 projects from across my state. What is pleasing is that 239, or more than 75 per cent of the successful projects, were from community based applications—a total of some $7.5 million. In Western Australia, 336 projects will receive $23.5 million, with 210 of such projects coming from community based applications. Once again, this is just the first instalment for the state of Western Australia, which is expected to receive at least $30 million in this financial year.

We are hopeful that New South Wales will be signing up to the trust this Friday and that Queensland will do so next week, after which we will be able to give similar good news to the community bodies within both of those states that are seeking Commonwealth support to implement the environmental remedial programs to which they are very much committed. It demonstrates that this government is a government that keeps its promises, that it supports the community in solving environmental problems and that it will continue to do so until we can produce a better environmental outcome not only for this generation but for future generations.
Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in question time Senate Harradine asked me a question relating to a complaint of dumping of coated paper from 14 countries, mainly in Europe and Asia. I provide the following answer to the question and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

Can I say at the outset that I am well aware of the importance of the forest industry to Northern Tasmania and in particular the paper manufacturing plants at Burnie and Wesley Vale which contribute an enormous amount both in employment and purchases to the Tasmanian Economy.

I am also well aware of the potential effect on paper manufacturing operations in Tasmania and the social impact that they may have on the community there should there be any dumping of coated woodfree paper in Tasmania.

In this case we have a complaint by the Australian Industry which manufactures coated woodfree paper, Australian Paper, against exports of this paper to Australia from 14 countries in Asia, Europe and South Africa.
The application for dumping notices was lodged with the Australian Customs Service on 19 June and on 9 July Customs initiated an investigation of the allegations made in the application.
The time frame in this investigation has been extended from the normal 85 days to 120 days because of the complexity of undertaking concurrent inquiries in 14 countries.

Difficulties in obtaining appointments with companies, indeed even contacting appropriate people in companies in both Europe and Asia because of the summer holidays there has caused the extension to be taken.
I am advised that Customs has visited a number of Companies in the 14 countries.
The Report is due for completion by 6 November when a preliminary finding will be made. In the event of a positive finding provisional duties may be imposed.

In the event of a positive finding the matter must be reviewed by the Anti Dumping Authority which has a further 110 days to complete its review. If the finding is negative the applicant may seek review by the Anti Dumping Authority which then has 60 days in those circumstances to complete its review.
In relation to your second point the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs is aware of the issues raised in relation to the inquiries made overseas by the Australian Customs Service.

They are matters which are more properly put at this stage of the investigation to Customs and the applicant has been advised of this. I am advised that issues already raised by the applicant with Customs have been addressed by Customs on the public file. The Public File is accessible to all interested parties.

The Senator also needs to be aware that there are statutory processes that need to be followed in this and investigations like it and that the decision making powers at the Preliminary Finding stage rest with the Chief Executive Officer of Customs.
I must add that the Minister for Customs is taking a very keen interest in the outcome of the Complaint.

He is not a bad middleweight performer in the chamber, I acknowledge that, he is a good journeyman, but his trouble is that once he walks out of this chamber he does nothing. TALK.START.PARA: —He's a good doormat.

—Senator Ray should really think back to when we took the vote in here on Telstra. I could not see the government of that time supporting our position on one‐third. He has a very interesting definition of the Australian Labor Party position at this stage: they want to keep the majority ownership of Telstra in the government hands. His only activity now—he thinks he is rather smart and maybe politically slick—is to try to find ways to stand up in the Senate in question time and attack other political parties in a typical, low‐life barrister style, as though he was representing landlord racketeers in the Prahran Magistrates Court.
