PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY BILL 1997

The purpose of the Australian Meat and Live‐Stock Industry Bill 1997 and associated bills, is to provide a legislative framework to facilitate the move from statutory to new company structures and operational arrangements, for the Australian red meat and livestock industry. The new arrangements are a major step forward, advancing industry towards management of its own affairs and importantly, increasing efficiency and competitiveness in structuring this industry to continue as a world leader. This reform is focused on the future needs of industry.
Background

The government is committed to improving the overall international competitiveness of all Australian industry. We are particularly keen to do so in our important agricultural industries. Unless we continue to improve productivity and cost efficiency throughout the food supply chain, we will lose ground against our international competitors and will not be able to maximise our national wealth, export opportunities and value enhancing potential.

The meat and livestock industry earns Australia, on average, about 3 billion export dollars a year. We need to set our targets for achievement at a higher level. As a single agricultural commodity export earner for Australia red meat and livestock ranks third, after wheat and wool. The potential of the industry is considerable, however to realise this potential we need to deal with a range of inefficiencies including high costs in the processing sector.

In 1994, the Industry Commission inquiry into the performance of the meat processing industry confirmed the importance of achieving and maintaining improvements and competitive efficiencies. No one can contest these simple objectives.

The commission found that Australia was not able to capitalise on its comparative production price advantage because the industry's processing sector was operating at significantly higher cost levels than the processing sectors of our major competitors. The commission, at the time it put forward its report, found that Australia was losing market share in almost all its major export markets.

It is not just these barriers in the processing sector which are impeding the meat industry's capacity to be competitive in world markets. Other costs associated with Australia's labour market, waterfront and quarantine and meat inspection processes, are also being addressed.
Honourable senators will no doubt agree that we must have a vision for the future and that reform in these key areas is vital to the long‐term viability of Australia's meat and livestock industry.

This government is tackling these necessary reforms and significant initiatives are already under way. For example, in the key area of industrial relations the government has put the workplace relations act in place and, as a consequence, award simplification test cases have been formulated for examination by a full bench of the Australian industrial relations commission. One of the test cases includes the meat processing industry and the particular issue of the tally system. The outcome of these cases will have particular importance for the industry.

The response to the Industry Commission's 1994 report was the establishment of the Meat and Live‐Stock Industry Act 1995 which allowed for some institutional restructuring, particularly in relation to priorities and policy direction. The act was designed to commence the process of engaging industry to accept a greater role in self determination.
This bill, in effect, takes the major final steps towards empowerment by providing the industry with a structure which offers ownership and management of its own affairs.
Review of current arrangements

By the end of 1995 it was clear that beef producers were suffering from the effects of a major drought and other significant international market factors which forced saleyard prices down to very low levels with consequential reduced returns to producers. Furthermore other red meat producers and other sectors of the industry were also facing problems.

The government instigated a review of the current institutional arrangements to determine if early action might address at least some of the meat and livestock industry's problems. To that end, a joint industry and government meat and livestock industry reform task force was established in 1996. The task force reviewed the structural arrangements, the financial management and operational effectiveness of the present statutory bodies. It also pinpointed key industry policy and program issues for early action by government and industry.
The task force found that market and industry circumstances had changed since the establishment of the Meat and Live‐Stock Industry Act 1995.

The task force found that the current statutory arrangements, which had worked well in the past, needed to be adjusted to deliver what industry required for the future. Prevailing and future commercial realities demand a structure which can deliver more flexible and focused commercial programs and operations. A sense of industry ownership and deeper involvement by levy‐paying stakeholders is also required.

Working from these findings, the task force report offered a wide range of recommendations based on two underlying principles. The first was that the meat industry in Australia must move towards a more self‐regulated, responsible and market driven operation. The second was that the role of government must move to one side, with a more clearly defined set of core functions for industry while at the same time improving strategic alliances with and within industry for the delivery of these functions.

The report also suggested that significant savings could be achieved by changing the current structures and levy‐ funded functions and making the provision of services fully contestable and transparent to the industry stakeholders.
Finally, the report advanced proposals for government on joint industry/government policy and program actions.

These proposals cover a broad range of joint actions that in large part cross state/Commonwealth responsibilities and those of industry. Many aspects of these proposals are already being addressed by commonwealth and state agencies, in direct consultations with industry.

A number of recommendations were made on the need for uniformity in regulatory legislation and administration across Australia. A whole of government approach is essential to ensure an integrated and consistent basis for meat safety and other regulations and provide a national regulatory underpinning for industry driven quality assurance and self‐regulation schemes. My colleague, the minister for primary industries and energy, the Hon John Anderson, intends to continue to advance these issues with his colleagues on the agriculture and resource management council of Australia and New Zealand.
New arrangements

The government decided on new arrangements following extensive consultations with all parts of Australia's vast and divergent meat and livestock industry. Full consensus has not been possible and is not possible. In an industry as diverse as this one, this is not surprising. I am pleased to say, however, there is broad agreement on major issues and each sector is in the process of implementing the changes sought. These included the need for a non‐government, commercially based organisation; the necessity for industry to manage its own affairs; a more hard headed approach to how levy‐payer monies are spent; and separately accountable beef and sheepmeat marketing and promotion divisions and separately accountable research and development divisions, within a commercially based organisation.

Another key area of agreement is that joint industry functions such as research and development, food safety and quality, market intelligence and market access issues, animal health and welfare, crisis management, eating quality standards, and Ausmeat should be dealt with co‐operatively and collectively, and be adequately funded and serviced. The industry is now focused on their collective responsibility in scoping projects and programs within each of the joint function areas. This is fundamental and very important.

The new structures will consist of a new producer owned service delivery company, limited by guarantee under the corporations law, to provide a range of services to the industry including professional guidance. The role of the company needs to be recognised, more so than the fact that it will be producer owned. The company will replace the statutory authorities of the Australian Meat and Live‐Stock Corporation (ALMC) and the Meat Research Corporation (MRC).

The company will be accessible to all sectors within the industry in every sense, including service delivery, professional guidance and advice. All sectors will independently enter into contracts with the company for specific services. Importantly, the company will be a fully professional organisation which will be able to develop initiatives and proposals and advise industry and government on key issues.
There will be separate companies, limited by guarantee, for the meat processors, livestock exporters and for the red meat advisory council, which I will discuss shortly.

There will be a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between industry sectors and government to ensure co-operation in the overall interests of the red meat industry. There will be a commitment to the principles of a meat industry strategic plan and collective activities under genuine partnership arrangements.
This bill is designed to free the industry from the legislative constraints imposed upon statutory bodies. The new, privately owned structure will allow industry to take appropriate steps towards:
1. Increasing industry's role in self‐determination and self‐regulation, in a commercially oriented environment;
2. Enhancing industry's capacity to determine and address areas of market failure;
3. Progressive implementation and facilitation of future industry agreed structural and other reforms;
4. Encouraging inclusion of all parties through willing partnerships, as well as separate contractual arrangements;
5. Improving industry co‐operation, principally through empowering industry leadership, with rapid development of sound policy decisions and co‐operative mechanisms;
6. Minimising government intervention while at the same time, ensuring continuing and appropriate representation, governance, accountability and crises management arrangements; together with,
7. Providing clear ownership by levy payers and non‐statutory contributors, and appropriate participation in decision making processes and resultant benefits.

The new arrangements will empower the industry peak councils to take leadership roles. The peak councils are expected to be as broadly representative of their sectors' interests as possible, bearing in mind that there will always be dissenters and detractors of any systems put in place. Under voluntary systems, it is rarely possible to have full representation. Members of each sector should seek to make their views and concerns known to the peak councils. It is the responsibility of each and every participant of the industry to make their views known and seek to influence industry representation where appropriate. A requirement of what we are doing is that the relevant representative bodies be open to all views and embrace genuine representative responsibility.

Peak councils will carry responsibility for decisions on levels of levies and non‐statutory funding for the new service delivery company. They will be responsible, among other things, for the development of their sector's input into the meat industry strategic plan and for the implementation of that plan.

To be able to effectively carry out the new responsibilities which will be required of them, the peak councils will need to be adequately funded so that they can have access to the professional expertise they will require. A primary new source of funding for peak councils will be income earned from investment of industry reserves. We must approach this issue, practically and sensibly, according to the needs and responsibilities of each sector or agency.
The `Red Meat Advisory Council', which may operate under another name, is primarily to provide advice to government on issues affecting the whole of industry.

It is proposed that the advisory council be incorporated as a company limited by guarantee with directors being the chairs of each of the six peak councils who will be voting members, and representatives of the processor and livestock exporter companies who will be participants. It will also draw, as appropriate and when required, on advisers from government and other involved expert areas of the industry. The framework in which the advisory council will operate will be agreed in the MOU. Its functions will include:
advice to the minister;
custodianship of the MOU and the Meat Industry Strategic Plan (the MISP);
co‐ordination and development of, and assessment of performance against, the industry strategic plan;

being the trustees (within a deed of trust) for industry reserves currently held by the statutory corporations, and ensure the investment of these monies by a reputable and reliable trust fund manager;
administer arrangements to fund peak councils including the distribution of funds (from investment of reserves) to peak councils;
provide an interface for resolving sectorial differences or problems in a way which does not adversely affect industry but in a way which promotes the image and purpose of the industry.

The terms of the council's custodianship of the industry reserves will be determined jointly by industry and government. The principal requirements will be that the funds be used for the benefit of industry as a whole, be managed transparently in a manner consistent with an industry developed strategic plan, and be based on accepted commercial practice. It is envisaged the returns on investments would be used, primarily to fund peak councils and, in a small part, to defray the costs of running the council.
Levies, charges and other funding

Under present arrangements industry levies and charges primarily go towards funding the industry's three statutory bodies—the ALMC, the MRC, and the Meat Industry Council. Other agencies which receive funding from industry levies and charges, include the National Residue Survey (NRS), the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation (RIRDC), the National Cattle Disease Eradication (NCDE) program and the Australian Animal Health Council (AAHC).

Under the new arrangements contributions will be sourced from various industry sectors, either on a statutory or a non‐statutory basis. The collection of statutory levies will still be based on the present system but with changes allowing for a transaction levy on sheep, lambs and goats to replace the livestock slaughter levy previously paid by processors, and a separate transaction levy component on grain fed cattle.

The transaction levy approach for sheep, lambs and goats was adopted at the request of a clear majority of industry whose submission met all of the re quirements of the government's levy principles. A similar request was also submitted by the grain fed cattle industry sector for a separate cattle transaction levy. Again this submission met each of the government's levy principles.
The existing levy and charge imposition acts have been modified to provide for clear sectoral ownership.

Processors and livestock exporters will contribute on a non-statutory basis. To accommodate the non‐statutory nature of the funding, the now separate processor and exporter levies will be set at zero, provided these sectors meet their share of whole of industry obligations under the new arrangements. There will be no changes to current levy rates until the new arrangements, including formal agreement on the nature and extent of processor and livestock exporter contributions, are fully in place and contractually deliverable.

Should the non‐statutory contributions by processors and livestock exporters fail to meet agreed funding levels for joint industry functions, and as specifically agreed by these two sectors, the government has their prior agreement to maintain levies at a required level to ensure there is adequate funding.

The buffalo industry sector has chosen to use RIRDC to meet its collective research and development programs and will not be contributing to the new service delivery company. Separate levy legislation will provide for direct buffalo industry sector contributions to RIRDC, and continued contribution by this sector to the NRS and NCDE.

The government will continue to match industry r&d commitments. Matching funds will continue on a dollar for dollar basis on eligible expenditure up to the maximum matching of 0.5 per cent of the industry's gross value of production. However, to qualify for matching funding for levy monies, contributing groups will need to meet specific eligibility criteria.
MOU and deed of grants
The bill recognises that much of the prescriptive detail for flow of levy funds and management of reserves will be set out in a deed of grant.

The deed of grant will be implemented between the government and the producer owned service delivery company. The deed will set out the conditions upon which levy monies and matching funds are passed to the company and how those funds may be applied. It will also set out the minimal accountability requirements that enable the minister to meet his responsibilities under the Audit Act 1901.

The MOU will primarily be between industry peak bodies, and also the government. Where appropriate and where they have identified responsibility the service delivery company and other entities will be required to be signatories. The document will consist of a statement of principles and supporting schedules, clearly outlining the new arrangements to which industry sectors have agreed. It will also outline intended joint function areas, core function areas and set out the guiding principles for the operation of the Red Meat Advisory Council.
Assets and liabilities

In consultation with industry and appropriate central Commonwealth agencies, my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon John Anderson, will determine the most appropriate placement of the assets and liabilities of the ALMC and the MRC. The legislative provisions to effect the transfer of such assets and liabilities to private companies is provided for in the Australian Meat and Live‐Stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997.

Some of the industry reserves will be transferred to the new service delivery company to offset liabilities which exist at the time of transfer and to meet start‐up capital requirements. A full due diligence exercise will be conducted for accountability purposes to ensure all assets and liabilities are identified prior to transfer. Start‐up capital will also be provided to the processor and livestock exporter companies. Minister Anderson will, in consultation with industry, determine how the balance of reserves will be used to benefit the industry as a whole.
Role of government, ministerial powers and accountability

The role of government in the new arrangements will be minimal but will remain necessary while tax payer monies are involved. Ministerial powers of intervention and mechanisms to guarantee appropriate standards of governance and accountability to parliament and levy payers will be retained through the combination of legislation (including the corporations law), regulation, appropriation, deeds of grant and the industry MOU.
The Commonwealth will not be a member of any of the new companies, nor will it have board representation or carry any liability in relation to their operations.

The government will, however, continue to fulfil its responsibility. The government will also continue to assist industry through working to ensure the economic framework provides for a genuinely competitive environment and that the global trading environment does not disadvantage our competitive advantages. The government will continue to maintain a strong presence in areas of food safety and hygiene, research and development, industry adjustment processes, training and education delivery, market access negotiations, competition and contestability, workplace reform, and infrastructure.
Legislative provisions
The legislative package consists of this, the principal bill, and sixteen associated bills.

The principal bill makes provision for some staging (by proclamation) of implementation. This is critical, because many of the mechanisms which will underpin effective and efficient industry management, the creation of representative corporations, the development of industry contractual arrangements, and negotiations by industry leaders, must be completed before the current legislation is repealed and levies adjusted. These activities are well advanced.

The legislation provides for the continued management of existing export licences, export quotas and enforcement powers. At present these functions are managed by the ALMC and paid for by levy payers. They will now transfer to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, including the provision for full cost recovery for the administration of licences and quotas.
Provision is made in the bill for the secretary of DPIE to have regard to policies formulated by prescribed industry bodies when exercising licensing and quota powers.

Provision is also made for levy funds, for marketing and promotion activities and r&d functions, to flow to the new service delivery company. There is also provision for the government to identify those organisations which, after meeting prescribed conditions, will be recognised as eligible donors for the purpose of Commonwealth matching funding on eligible r&d expenditure within the service delivery company.

The principal legislation makes provision for ministerial direction, but only in situations of emergency and where the national interest is involved. The power of direction is limited to matters for which the Commonwealth has authority under the constitution.

The new structural arrangements impact directly on other legislation, including the meat industry's present levies and charges acts. The Australian Meat and Live‐Stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential) Bill 1997 makes provision to repeal or amend relevant parts of the affected acts. In addition, a new set of levy and charge bills has been drafted to accommodate the change to the nature of future contributions. The changes are as follows:

the Cattle Export Charges Act 1990 will be replaced by two new Cattle Export Charge Acts which deal separately with producers and exporters. This allows for subsequent reduction of the export sector levy components to zero, when that sector deliver on its funding commitments under the new partnership arrangements.

the Live‐Stock Export Charge Act 1977 will be replaced by two new Live‐Stock Export Charges Acts which deal separately with producers and exporters. This will also allow for subsequent reduction of the export sector components to zero.

the Live‐Stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964 will be replaced by a Livestock Transactions Levy Act and a Livestock Slaughter (Processors) Levy Act, to allow for the separation of producers' and processors' funding and for the processors' funding to move to zero levy rates.

the particular requirements of the buffalo industry will be met by new Buffalo Export Charge and Slaughter Levy Acts. Separate levy acts are needed because the buffalo industry will retain slaughter levy and export charge arrangements. Contributions from the buffalo industry will continue to go to RIRDC, the NRS and the NCDE, as at present.
the Beef Production Levy Act 1990 will be amended to allow for the processors' funding to move to zero levy rates.

the new act replacing the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1995 will provide for the imposition of separate levy components for grass fed and grain fed cattle producers to support their individual contributions to the new service delivery company, as well as continued funding to the NCDE and AAHC.
a revised set of National Residue Survey bills has been included in this package to allow for continuation of the provision of producer linked payments on cattle, buffalo, sheep, lambs and goats.

In all cases, the promotion, marketing, r&d and program specific components will be specifically identified. Provisions will ensure collections of levies and voluntary contributions relating to any particular sector will be clearly and transparently identifiable.
Collection arrangements and cost recovery for these levies will remain as they are at present.
National eating quality standards scheme

Minister Anderson has long promoted the need for a proper meat grading system. He expects the new service delivery company to maintain the high priority being given to the early introduction of the proposed national eating quality standards scheme and further expects funding for this initiative to be of a high priority for the industry sectors.
Support for producers' marketing initiatives

The new service delivery company will be asked to give careful consideration to ways to assist groups of producers who wish to pursue various marketing initiatives. Such initiatives would include the development of brands and the development of niche markets and a means by which innovation and initiatives can reap rewards.

Finally, I would like to repeat that the legislation package I have just outlined will facilitate the reshaping and refocusing of the Australian red meat and livestock industry. The new statutory arrangements will:
empower industry;
reduce government involvement;
achieve a more focused and cost efficient service delivery;
provide a more responsive structure capable of adapting to rapidly evolving competition and customer needs; and

encourage the development of systems and structures which promote the culture of industry cooperation and a sense of corporate behaviour in developing and ensuring the future prosperity of the Australian red meat industry.

These new arrangements represent a radical move to industry self‐determination. The changes will be carefully implemented to ensure that structures, relationships and operations are corporate in their nature and have proper and workable settings and control measures.

Since the announcement of the government's decision, industry has had time to appreciate the historic opportunities being offered to it and acknowledged that the package will accommodate most, if not all, of what the various sectors have been seeking. All sectors have assured minister Anderson they accept the decisions taken and that they will get behind them to ensure their effective implementation. Above all, industry has recognised that the new arrangements are offering a necessary opportunity to bring about a fundamental cultural change. Rather than relying on government involvement and legislated instruments, the package offers industry control and ownership of its own destiny.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY (REPEALS AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to repeal and amend certain acts as a result of the enactment of the Australian Meat and Live‐Stock Industry Act 1997, and for other necessary provisions including transfer to the secretary of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy the authority to administer the Export Quota Scheme and to issue export licenses. The Australian Meat and Live‐Stock Quotas Act 1990 is amended to provide for the department to recover the cost of administering the quota scheme. Licensing costs will be recovered under the provisions of the Australian Meat and Live‐Stock Industry Act 1997.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
BEEF PRODUCTION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Beef Production Levy Act 1990. The amendments provide for the redirection of levy funds to newly prescribed industry bodies and permit the levy rate to be set at zero once satisfactory non‐statutory funding arrangements are in place.
I commend the bill to the honourable Senators.
BUFFALO EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose a charge payable by producers on the export of buffaloes to fund research and disease eradication. This bill will replace the charge imposed by the Live‐Stock Export Charge Act 1977.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
BUFFALO SLAUGHTER LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose a levy payable by the owners of buffalo when they are slaughtered to fund research and disease eradication. This bill will replace the levy imposed by the Live‐Stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
CATTLE (EXPORTERS) EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to continue the capacity for charges to be payable by exporters on the export of live cattle. The bill is designed to recognise the future non‐statutory nature of contributions by exporters and provides for charges to be set at zero in regulations. This bill will replace the charge imposed by the Cattle Export Charges Act 1990.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
CATTLE (PRODUCERS) EXPORT CHARGES BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose charges payable by beef cattle producers on the export of cattle to fund the new industry service delivery company, disease eradication and animal health. The levy is only payable if levy under the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1997 has not been paid and is not payable, or if cattle for export are held for times in excess of those reasonable to cover any quarantine requirements. This bill replaces the charges imposed by the Cattle Export Charges Act 1990.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
CATTLE TRANSACTIONS LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose levies payable on transactions involving cattle or leviable bobby calves. The levies will be used to fund the new industry service delivery company, disease eradication and animal health. This bill will replace the levy imposed by the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1995.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER (PROCESSORS) LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose a levy payable by processors on the slaughter of sheep, lambs and goats. This bill is designed to recognise the non‐statutory nature of funding collections by processors by providing for levies to be set at zero in regulations. The levy imposed by this bill will replace the one imposed by the Live‐Stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
LIVE-STOCK TRANSACTIONS LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose levies payable by producers on transactions involving sheep, lambs and goats. This bill will replace the levy imposed on the sheepmeat and goat industries by the Live‐Stock Slaughter Sevy Act 1964, which provided for levies at the point of slaughter and paid by processors. The levies will be used to fund the new industry service delivery company, disease eradication and animal health for the sheepmeat, wool and goat industries.

In the light of decisions taken for processors and live exporters to move to non‐statutory levies, and for reasons of simplicity, equity, and transparency, the Sheepmeat Council of Australia and the Goat Industry Council of Australia proposed a transaction levy be introduced in lieu of a slaughter "pass‐back" levy. The Sheepmeat Council of Australia has demonstrated this is clearly the majority industry decision, including support of this approach by the wool council of Australia.

The transaction levy under this bill will closely parallel the existing transaction levy that has operated successfully in the cattle sector for many years. By aligning industry collection mechanisms with those already existing for cattle, meat industry levy collections are effectively standardised. It is this standardised approach that has assisted in gathering strong support.

The bill also makes provision for exemptions in such circumstances as are prescribed by regulation to provide the flexibility in the future to cater for industry decisions in relation to levy exemptions. Such regulations will be disallowable instruments and industry, in seeking levy exemptions or conces sions, will need to clearly demonstrate the proposal has majority industry support, and meets all the requirements of the government's levy principles.

The Sheepmeat Council of Australia and the Goat Industry Council of Australia have requested an exemption from levy for sheep, lambs and goats sold for $5.00 per head or less, to cater for cases of genuine hardship. This exemption has met the requirements outlined above and it is intended to give effect to this through regulation.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
LIVE-STOCK (EXPORTERS) EXPORT CHARGES BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose charges payable by exporters on the export of sheep, lambs and goats. This bill is designed to recognise the planned non‐statutory nature of funding collections by exporters by providing for charges to be set at zero in regulations. It will replace the charge imposed by the Live‐Stock Export Charge Act 1977. There will be no increase to the present maximum charge rate under the new act.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
LIVE-STOCK (PRODUCERS) EXPORT CHARGES BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose charges payable by producers on the export of sheep, lambs and goats. The imposition of charges is invoked if levy has not been paid, and is not payable, under the Live‐Stock Transactions Levy Act 1997. The charges imposed by this bill will replace that imposed by the Live‐Stock Export Charge Act 1977. The levies will be used to fund the new industry service delivery company, disease eradication and animal health for the sheepmeat, wool and goat industries.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (BUFFALO SLAUGHTER) LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose levies on the slaughter of buffalo that will be used to fund the national residue survey. There will be no increase to the present maximum or operative levy rates under the new act. The levy imposed by this bill will replace the one imposed by the National Residue Survey (Livestock Slaughter) Levy Act 1992.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (CATTLE TRANSACTIONS) LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose charges payable by producers on certain transactions and other dealings involving cattle or bobby calves. The levy will be used to fund the National Residue Survey. There will be no increase to the present maximum or operative rates under the new act. The levy imposed by this bill will replace the one imposed by the National Residue Survey (Cattle Transaction) Levy Act 1995.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (CATTLE EXPORT) LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose levies payable by beef cattle producers on the export of cattle that will be used to fund the national residue survey. There will be no increase to the present maximum or operative levy rates under the new act. The charge imposed by this bill will replace the one imposed by the National Residue Survey (Cattle Export) Levy Act 1995.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (SHEEP, LAMBS AND GOATS TRANSACTIONS) LEVY BILL 1997
The purpose of this bill is to impose levies payable by

Producers on certain transactions and other dealings involving sheep, lambs and goats. The levy will be used to fund the National Residue Survey. This bill is being introduced as a result of the sheep, lamb and goat industries' wish to move from slaughter to transaction based levies.

The levy imposed by this bill together with levy imposed by the National Residue Survey (Sheep, Lambs & Goats Export) Levy Act 1997 will replace the levy imposed by the National Residue Survey (Livestock Slaughter) Levy Act 1992.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (SHEEP, LAMBS & GOATS EXPORT) LEVY BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to impose levies payable by producers on the export of sheep, lambs and goats. The levies will be used to fund the National Residue Survey. This bill is being introduced as a result of the sheep, lamb and goat industries' wish to move from slaughter to transaction based levies.

The levy imposed by this bill together with levy imposed by the National Residue Survey (Sheep, Lambs & Goats Transaction) Levy Act 1997 will replace the levy imposed by the National Residue Survey (Livestock Slaughter) Levy Act 1992.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, this bill facilitates implementation of the significant changes in the delivery of child‐care payments contained in the Child Care Payments Bill. It introduces a number of transitional arrangements which ensure the smooth introduction of the new payment arrangements for families and child‐care providers. In particular, it ensures that children currently using the long day care sector to provide outside school hours care for their children are not disadvantaged by the introduction of the new school child rate of child‐care assistance. It also provides exemptions from the planning framework for child‐care operators who had taken action to build or extend a child‐care centre before the planning limits were announced on budget night. The bill provides for the repeal of the Child Care Rebate Act 1993 and provides for amendments to various other acts which are necessary to implement the new payment arrangements. Madam Deputy President, I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 facilitate the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Authority as agreed in 1995 between the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victorian governments. The corporatisation thrust of this legislation has been agreed by those on this side when we were in government and we continue to support it now. At this stage I foreshadow, though, that the opposition will move an amendment in the committee stage of the bill. That amend ment will be discussed in detail at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.PARA: The rationale for the corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Authority is that it will enable the authority, under a new corporate entity, the Snowy Hydro Ltd, to participate fully in the emerging competitive national electricity market. This is an important advance in the move towards establishing a national electricity market and ensuring competition amongst energy suppliers. The establishment of a national electricity market has been pursued since 1990‐91 and was started by the Labor government. I can interpolate here, being a Western Australian senator, that it covers every state in the Commonwealth except Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't got any water over there.

—We have a lot of water over there—it is in the north—and we have a lot of natural gas, but our tariffs are a lot higher than for electricity generated by the Snowy scheme, which I think provides the cheapest electricity generated by any source in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The nature of the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐Electric Authority is that complementary legislation is required to be passed by the Victorian and New South Wales governments. I understand that this is in the process of occurring. The Victorian legislation is expected to be passed by the Victorian parliament in the near future. The New South Wales legislation has, unfortunately, been blocked by the New South Wales upper house in the first instance. An amended version of the New South Wales legislation is expected to be introduced into the New South Wales parliament later this year or early next year.

The corporatisation of the Snowy is such that the Commonwealth legislation cannot be proclaimed until complementary state legislation is passed and an independent water inquiry on the water flow of the Snowy has been conducted. It is that aspect which goes to the heart of the amendment which I will move in due course.

The bills terminate the existing legislative arrangements in relation to the Snowy scheme and form a new company, the Snowy Hydro Ltd. The Snowy Hydro will manage and operate the Snowy mountains scheme and the Commonwealth and two state governments will have shares respectively in the new company. New South Wales will have 58 per cent, Victoria will have 29 per cent and the Commonwealth will have 13 per cent. The corporatisation will also seek to ensure that the Snowy operates on a financially viable basis in accordance with the corporate plan approved of by its members.

In regard to transitional arrangements, an issue that is always important on this side of the chamber, all current Snowy Mountains Authority staff will be offered a transfer to Snowy Hydro Ltd and no net loss of their benefits or their entitlements will occur. In addition, the corporatisation process will enable the facilitation of repayment of substantial debt owed by the Snowy Mountains Authority to the Commonwealth.

As I have said, the opposition will support this bill, but I do foreshadow an amendment. I must say, as someone who in a previous parliamentary life had ministerial responsibility for the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Authority, I hope all of these changes can result in the authority being able to develop some capital investment to upgrade some of its operational needs, particularly on the power generation side. Some of the turbines have been maintained in a way which is a tribute to the ingenuity of Australian engineering. With that commercial for some capital investment in the scheme, can I say that we will support the bills.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats believe that the first issue we should be looking at is the issue of water and water allocation. The Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 really are about water and the use of it. Yes, one use is hydro electricity, but there is an awful lot else that needs to be considered as to who will get the various allocations, what they will be using them for, how much of it will be allocated, et cetera.

BREAK.PARA: We believe that we should not be dealing, and cannot really deal, with the whole issue of corporatisation until we have completed the inquiry into water. But, as we have just heard now, that inquiry has not even begun yet. We are being asked to pass this legislation today. But the means of determining the environmental needs—indeed, the irrigation, recreation and community needs, et cetera—of the various rivers involved that rely on the Snowy scheme have not even started.

These bills, along with two other pieces of legislation—the one in New South Wales that is now being reassessed and, indeed, I understand, rewritten to some extent, and is to go back into the New South Wales parliament next year; and also the one in Victoria—will set the fate of the Snowy River and the Murray-Darling Basin for many years to come.

This government is apparently happy to wash its hands of the most important river system in the country—and also of one of the most degraded rivers we have, the Snowy River, thanks to the fact that it now effectively has no water in it. The government is saying basically, `Don't worry about that, the states will look after everything.' What does this government believe is important enough for it to maintain an active interest in? If this is not an issue that the Commonwealth feels it should maintain an active decision‐making role in, what is?

As we all know, we live on the driest inhabited continent on this planet. But it seems that, for this government, water use, water allocation is a secondary issue to the making of money through, in this case, hydro electricity; and that really it is not an issue for the interest of the national government.

The minister is shamelessly aware that both the New South Wales government and the Victorian government are preparing to privatise their shares of the Snowy scheme. He has, in fact, indicated that the Commonwealth will consider selling off its 13 per cent share. I think one of the reasons given was to `simplify the governance' after the scheme has been corporatised. All of this, without any idea as to how the final water allocations will work out!

This legislation does contain corporatisation principles, but it does not safeguard community or environmental concerns. All is pinned to the water inquiry that is yet to be agreed to and commenced. Here is the legislation before the Senate, with the government apparently—and, as I hear now, also the opposition—happy just to let it through.

The public is being asked by the federal government to accept a corporatisation package that leaves out the most important details. On top of this, there is no provision in the legislation for the federal government to have any responsibility for the Snowy River Alliance once agreed to: no responsibility for the environmental flows, no responsibility for the affected rivers, passing it all over to the states to look after it.

Obviously, New South Wales and Victoria have to be very closely involved in the process of looking at, first of all, the licences but, in particular, the whole issue of corporatisation. But we have got it around the wrong way. Let us first get all the interested parties together, sort out what we are doing with the water, and then sit down and look at the pros and cons of corporatisation.

The minister claims that he does `place a high priority on ensuring that arrangements to corporatise the scheme recognise the community interests in the future of the Snowy scheme'. But how, Minister, will you ensure that this happens, if you are effectively passing it all over to the states? We do have the power to say no to corporatisation until the outcome of the water licence is determined. But, obviously, with the opposition supporting you, that will not happen here today.

I would just like fellow senators to consider for a moment in particular the fate of the Snowy River. There have been many concerns raised about this river for many years, and I just bring a few to the attention of the Senate today.

The Total Environment Centre in New South Wales argues that the federal government should not allow its desire for maximum sale price to affect the environmental flow outcome for the Snowy River. If it is sold for less, then the other side of the coin is that it is really an investment in the health of the river, and in a potential job creation scheme. The centre points out that additional jobs will not come from corporatisation but from expanding tourism along the restored Snowy River. This could be an opportunity, indeed, for the New South Wales and federal governments to work on an invigorated ecotourism plan for the area.
The Australian Conservation Foundation has stated that they:

. . . regard the Snowy River as a litmus test of Government policy on river health—to returning water to stressed river systems and restoring them to health. Without major increases in flows, the Snowy River is doomed.

They look at the Snowy scheme itself and comment that it is a scheme that has profited from running the Snowy River dry, and it is now time to repay the environmental debt ahead of the Commonwealth's financial debts and return the Snowy to health. The snowy mountains hydro was built and has operated under the Commonwealth act and it has virtually destroyed the Snowy River in not much more than 30 years.

Presently, the diversion of the Snowy River inland is shared equally between the Murray and Murrumbidgee rivers. However, without restrictions on the equal release of water, there may be opportunities to divert larger quantities down one side. More importantly, if we look at this legislation, the potential to change the timing of these releases during the course of a season can affect irrigation entitlements.

But if the primary objective is to make money, and water is needed for hydro electricity, how will the needs of the rivers, particularly the Snowy, of irrigators, of inland communities be dealt with? We need to have all of that organised first—to know the timing, to know the volumes, to know where the water is being allocated.

The Victoria National Parks Association believes that the proportion of water from the Snowy River diverted to the Murray and Murrumbidgee rivers should not be increased—indeed, it should be reduced. Any water savings made from upgrading irrigation schemes should go back to restore the Snowy River flow—and I certainly agree with the association wholeheartedly.

If the federal government passes this legislation prior to the detail being worked out, then it will be automatically supporting any decision that New South Wales and Victorian energy and treasury ministers make on water resources and on the management of this system for the next 125 years, which is the term of the licence.

Since the construction of the Snowy scheme, flows to the Snowy River just below Jindabyne Dam have been reduced to less than one per cent of their natural flows. The Snowy Mountains Hydro Power Act 1949 did not allocate any water for the Snowy's environmental requirements at all. Thirty‐odd years of this has virtually destroyed the Snowy River and as a result this Australian icon has become a narrow, weed‐choked stream virtually devoid of native species and indeed aquatic life at all.

The Snowy scheme was originally planned as an engineering undertaking and only limited, if any, consideration was given to a wide range of community needs and to the likelihood and pattern of environmental changes. Surely in 1997 we know better than that.

The community based group, the Snowy River Alliance, has seen what the bottom line of the argument is against passing this legislation now. They believe that the new legislation must allocate adequate environmental flows to the Snowy River and that this must be done prior to consideration of corporatisation. I will quote from one of their documents:
. . . if the parliament passes this legislation before a decision is made between the states, then the parliament has rubber stamped any decision that the states might make.

Placing the control of a large section of south‐east Australia's water in the hands of a corporate entity will result in the interest lying with the maximisation of profits through power generation and not with environmental issues. Both the ACF and the Snowy River Alliance have expressed concern for the cost to taxpayers in the future if we wake up and find that we really have damaged these rivers to such an extent that we have to change the licence allocations in years to come. I will quote from the alliance which said:

If there is going to be compensation involved, we believe that there will be a great reluctance by governments to alter those arrangements. Given the length of the term of the licence, it would be quite foreseeable to see a situation in ten or twenty years time, where there needs to be significant changes in those arrangements. That could mean that we will be paying the Snowy Hydro, which could be privatised by then, compensation for over 100 years.

I will close by saying, let us deal with the water issue first. Let us look at making sure that the Snowy River flows again, and then come back in here and discuss the issue of corporatisation.(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this legislation on behalf of the Australian Greens. In the words of the Snowy River Alliance:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this bill should be withdrawn from the Federal Parliament until satisfactory agreements have been established between the State governments and the communities locally on environmental flows for the Snowy River and other affected rivers including the details of other outstanding issues including irrigation.
The Snowy River Alliance, which had led the campaign for the rescue and return of the Snowy River's flow, says:

If the Senate passes this legislation prior to the formulation of the detail of the proposed corporatisation, then it will consequently be supporting any decision that the NSW and Victorian energy and treasury ministers make on water resource management for the next 125 years.
That is because the corporatised authority will be able to enter into agreements for water flows for 75 years with options to the recipients of those agreements for another 50 years.

This legislation takes away from the government the responsibility for the environmental outcomes of this scheme. The Snowy Mountains scheme provides five per cent of the electricity in the south‐east grid of this country. On the other hand, the scheme prevents 99 per cent of the water flowing down arguably the most famous river in this country—certainly in the culture of this country—the once great and mighty Snowy River.

BREAK.PARA: Local residents, supported by environment groups, have been saying that there should be a restoration of flow to the once mighty Snowy below Jindabyne to enable the ecosystems at least to survive at a tenuous but possible level in the Snowy River. In June a group of local residents on foot and horseback protested outside Parliament House in New South Wales when the analogous legislation for corporatisation was before the New South Wales parliament. It was notable that the New South Wales Premier, Bob Carr, did not come out to speak to that group of people. In the coverage of that protest by Snowy Mountains and Snowy River residents this was said:

Since the Snowy Mountains Hydro‐electric Scheme diverted water flow into the Murray and Murrumbidgee irrigation schemes in 1967, the flow has dwindled to less than one per cent of the original flow, Snowy River Alliance chairman Paul Leete said.

"The trouble is, they took the lot. They wiped the Snowy River clean off the map . . . (Scientists) all say that if we don't get at least one quarter of the river back then we might as well get the liquid paper out and wipe it off the map."
Mr Leete and about 40 fellow protesters, several of them on horseback—
as I have said—
invited the Premier . . . to accept a framed photograph of the Snowy River before the flow was halted.
That was not possible because the Premier ducked the protest. However, veteran actor Gus Mercurio was at the protest and, as the report goes on:
. . . while acting in The Man From Snowy River movie, he had been shocked when he first saw the river.
"It's choked with weeds. It's a shrivelling, little meaningless creek held together by pools . . . The Snowy that I and thousands of Australians once knew is in its death throes."
Rae Solomon Stewart, elder of the Monaro Aboriginal people, said her people dispersed from the Snowy River area since the flow was halted.
Ms Stewart, who said she was born on the river's banks where her ancestors had spent much of their time, said camping there had been a central part of daily existence.
"Being Kooris, black kids, we used to swim in the river because Aboriginal children were not allowed to swim in the swimming pools.
Of the towns, that is.
We used to get water from the river for cooking and washing. We'd take our washing down and boil water up in old kerosene buckets."
Ms Stewart said her family also caught eels in the Snowy. "When it dried up, the families just scattered.
That is, when it dried up after the Snowy scheme. It stopped the flow.
"The families just scattered. They all moved away," she said.
She said flow should be returned so that young people could enjoy what she experienced as a child.

Instead of listening to the Aboriginal people and all the residents and locals of this region—and, I suspect, to the heart of the Australian people who, without exception, have heard of the Snowy River and see it as part of this nation's cultural history as a whole—this bill is about shutting out the environment and social and cultural considerations and shrugging off the responsibility we have to the environment of what is, as Senator Lees aptly said, `arguably the greatest river in this country'.

As it is, there is an amendment from Labor which concerns the holding of the water flow inquiry—and what a remarkable thing; we are being asked to pass this bill before the results of an inquiry into the need for returning flow to the Snowy River are available, before that inquiry has been held. However, Labor has an amendment flagged before the Senate which would enable the minister to act on the results of that inquiry. The minister, it turns out, is Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. So here we have an environmental outcome being placed in the hands of the minister for holding back the flow of the Snowy River, who sees this as an irrigation outcome. We are asked to trust Senator Parer in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust him implicitly.

—I would rather trust the sensitivities of the Snowy River Alliance and get the results of that water inquiry and ensure the environmental flow in the Snowy River before we hand this across to the corporatised authority and basically the laws of New South Wales.

BREAK.PARA: I have recently watched the environmental concerns of the minister in question regarding the mine at Jabiluka in the Northern Territory. I have noticed no great proclivity for understanding the concerns, social and environmental, of local Aboriginal people, let alone the sentiments of a wider nation about Kakadu National Park. So it would be quite foolish and remiss for the Greens to accept that the same minister might have a different point of view, a different approach, a greater sensitivity, when it comes to the needs of the Snowy River. Of course he has not. That is absurd. Of course we cannot expect that anything but a greenwash will occur post-corporatisation as far as the flow of the Snowy is concerned.

And, of course, it will be the holy dollar which determines the outcome—not the needs of the river, not the concerns of the Aboriginal community and not the concerns of all those communities downstream of the scheme right through to the Victorian coastline. They are not going to rate when it comes to a corporate entity which is doing business and which is selling that water for money. We do not live in that sort of society and we cannot expect in this day and age that sort of outcome. We know from the behaviour of the minister, as I have just said, that we certainly cannot leave this in his hands. We would be very foolish to put the safety of the chookhouse in the hands of the fox.

I make an appeal here to the Labor opposition. This is a matter of holding up a process of corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains authority, not the flow of the Snowy River west into other systems for irrigation or for the production of electricity. That will go on. This is an appeal to halt the process of corporatisation, and essentially the Commonwealth divesting the influence it has, until the environmental safety of the Snowy River is returned; until an adequate flow—and the scientists say 28 per cent is the minimum—is returned to this majestic river.

A couple of months ago here in Canberra I watched film of the river as it was. I saw canoeists going down this remarkable, majestic river on the snow melt, on the spring thaw from the Snowy Mountains, back in the 1940s. It can only be described as stupendous: a fabulous experience, a life‐moving experience. Today, if you go to emulate that experience, you find, as Mr Mercurio said, a riverbed choked with weeds, a shrivelling little meaningless creek. If we as a nation cannot get this right, if we as a nation cannot return 28 per cent to nature, to the environment, to local residents, to the Aboriginal community—it sounds minimal to me—while 72 per cent goes to the other pursuits for which the Snowy Mountains scheme was put in place, what does that say about us?

If we as a Senate—and I include particularly the Labor opposition in this—cannot say, `Let us stay the execution of the Snowy until we get the outcome of the relevant inquiry into water flows, till we know what we are dealing with. Let us put off this corporatisation and not divest ourselves of powers until we ensure that the health of the Snowy and the aspirations of the people who live along it are met,' what does that say about the Senate, what does that say about the parliament and, indeed, what does that say about the Labor opposition and its claim to be sensitive to social and environmental matters of this sort?

I do not hold out any hope with the government. I do not hold out any hope with Senator Parer. I do not hold out any hope even with government members who represent communities along this mighty river. But we have got the numbers in this place to delay this corporatisation until the river is spoken for and until those people are spoken for. So I make this appeal to the opposition to join the Greens, the Democrats and, hopefully, the independent component in this place so that commonsense, if not environmental excellence, prevails and we get the information from the water inquiry into the needs of the Snowy River for centuries to come. What is the basic flow, the minimum flow, the least we can give back to this grand river to ensure its health into the future? We should have that information before we throw away our ability to do the right thing by the river and the people who live along it.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of concern that I rise to speak on this issue to do with the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the related bill. The Snowy system is of significance to this country. It is significant to the heritage and the folklore of the country and it is significant to people within the Labor Party because the Snowy Mountains project was something that was seen as being very much the brainchild of the Chifley government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very vital system. In the diversion down the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, it provides a lot of vital water—and down the Murray—enabling the existence of some significant irrigation areas and some significant irrigation systems. This system supports the maintenance in jobs of many thousands of people who live in vibrant, stimulating and interesting communities on the system—communities which contribute a significant, valuable input to the economic viability and wellbeing of this country.

On the Murrumbidgee system is Griffith, which is the centre of the area which produces the greatest quantity of wine in this country. I know that those from South Australia, Victoria and elsewhere are going to be absolutely aghast at this and not believe me, but the wine production of the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area—particularly that of the Griffith area—is the greatest, by volume, in this country.

The wine produced in the area is of a standard higher than rough red or pretty rough white. Over the last few decades, the vignerons have worked very hard to improve their standards and they are now providing very important wines, both in terms of volume and of the blends their wines are able to be used for. They used to be known for their fortified wines, but that is no longer the case. They are now known for being able to provide blends for some of the top wines that this country produces—and we know that this country produces wines that are of international standard.

We also have a significant chicken industry down there. It would not be there if there were no water. The Bartter's enterprise is significant. The factory alone employs 1,500 people. We have the ricegrowers cooperative down there. This industry was started by a Japanese gentleman who moved to the area around Griffith and Leeton. Now we are beginning to see Australian ricegrowers being able to export their rice back into places like Japan. That is of major significance to the economy not only of the area but of this country.

A lot of fruits are also grown down there. The orange industry is in a bit of a bad state at the present, and the government has got to do something to address the problems associated with that, but the area is productive and fertile.

Around Wagga Wagga, Narrandera, Leeton and Hay we have some feedlots. These are not enterprises that are at all sustainable without an adequate supply of water. That is where the availability of water to those involved in the irrigation and farming industries on those valleys becomes of the utmost importance—not just to the valley but, as I say, to the whole country.

There have been concerns on the part of the irrigators, and they are seeking a guarantee that in times of drought they can be assured some access to the flow. They recall that in 1983, during the previous El Nino when the drought was very severe, they were able to go to the then state minister, Terry Sheahan—whose actual electorate was Burrinjuck, which of course included Burrinjuck Dam and a significant part of the upper reaches of the Murrumbidgee—and negotiate with his department a sensible arrangement between all the major parties involved. They were able to ensure that, if the drought did not break before the end of the autumn, they would be able to keep a sufficient flow for the hydro to meet its water needs for electricity production for heating and power during the peak times in winter.

Also they were able to ensure that it was possible to tell the ricegrowers—halfway through the season when the season was particularly bad and the problems were becoming critical—how much water they could have on allocation over the next couple of months. While not getting the full amount of water they needed, they were able to get enough to enable them to get the crop off. It enabled them to remain viable in that district, and it enabled us as a country to have our exports and earnings. They still talk about it being a very amicable arrangement.

New South Wales is currently engaged in a review of water in that state—a review which is most important for the state, and, probably, for this country. The health, the use and the future needs of all the New South Wales water systems are being looked at. For this Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill to be passed and proclaimed prior to that inquiry being completed would be the most ridiculous, stupid thing that could possibly happen.

It is vitally important that the amendments that get passed make it very clear that no proclamation will take place until all the parties are satisfied. The electricity generators, the irrigators and the environmentalists need to be satisfied. This system is one that has to balance the needs of at least three major groups in our country. It is vitally important, therefore, that the amendments to be moved by Senator Cook get passed, because that is one way of ensuring that the legislation will not be proclaimed until after this has been sorted out—until after agreements and arrangements can be instituted and put in place such that there can be an equitable and fair distribution, to the benefit of all the players involved in this great river system.

It would be absolutely foolhardy to ignore the work that the New South Wales Minister for the Environment, Pam Allan, and the Minister for Land and Water Conservation, Kim Yeadon, have undertaken in recent times, and are continuing to undertake with this water inquiry. It is certainly under way. Reading my local media it is quite apparent to me that the community is being involved. The community is being invited to participate and to have its point of view heard, and visits are being planned and public hearings and community consultation times have been set aside for all of the major river systems: the Darling; the Macquarie leading up to the Bogan and the Darling; the Gwydir area; down the Lachlan; and the Murrumbidgee and the Murray as well. So it is vitally important that nothing of this legislation be proclaimed until that inquiry has been completed, there has been a resolution and concerns have abated, and the three major groups have had an opportunity to have considerable input and reach agreement.

This is the vital part of this issue: if this water is handled badly and the power generators get the vast majority, and get the overriding say, the other two groups are not going to be happy. They are not going to be satisfied and there are going to be problems. It is vitally important that such issues as how to handle El Ninos and major droughts—such as the drought of 1983 when Blowering Dam was empty and water had to be moved between two dams to keep the generation of power available—have to be resolved.

There has to be a balance struck between the needs of the generators, the needs of the irrigators, the needs of other farmers as well—because there are farmers who do not irrigate but who certainly rely upon the water for stock in particular—and the needs of the environmentalists for the water in that area. It is vitally important that all those needs are balanced. I would urge members of the Senate to certainly take this into consideration and to take Senator Cook's valid amendment into consideration in considering this bill.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say right at the beginning that the Greens (WA) oppose the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill . I flag my opposition because I know that the ALP does not oppose the bill per se and because I will be putting up a second reading amendment. I oppose the bill because I do not think we should be privatising natural water resources or substantial electricity production capacity. I also believe that such privatisation or corporatisation will result in large, unrecoverable, negative consequences for the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: In the face of the almost certain passage of this bill, I want to be assured that the issue of the environmental impact is addressed as a part of its passage. For that reason, I am moving my second reading amendment which, if passed, would defer this bill until the environmental matters concerning the rehabilitation of river systems are resolved.

BREAK.PARA: The reason why I oppose this bill is that the corporatisation is a mechanism to allow privatisation. Even corporatisation removes the ability of the public to act through government and the bureaucracy to manage the Snowy scheme in the public interest. It is part of the law. Corporate managers are legally bound to defend corporate profits and are not bound to defend social or environmental policy except as required by law. So if it is not specifically stated it is not available to corporate managers to impose something which might be considered a cost on their shareholders.

The corporatisation narrows the ambit of responsibility for management of the Snowy scheme. The corporation is seen primarily as an independent electricity generator in the national electricity market rather than having a role in water management. Yet it does retain high levels of control over water originally established under defence provisions to override state interests. The corporatisation gives the Commonwealth 13 per cent of stock, Victoria 29 per cent, and New South Wales gets control of the corporation with 58 per cent of the stock. Under normal corporate law, there is no requirement for a majority shareholder to consult or consider minority shareholders as long as it is not acting to the commercial detriment of minority shareholders—that is, as long as it is acting for profit maximisation. There is no way to guarantee that this means it must be of benefit to the environment or the wider community.

New South Wales is understood to want to include the Snowy shares as part of the sale of state electricity production assets. While we recognise that the privatisation of New South Wales electricity assets has been rejected by the rank and file of the ALP, it is also clear that the executive favours it and would not let it drop altogether.

The coalition would privatise in a moment, should they gain power. In such a case, the majority ownership of the Snowy plan would go to the private sector and entirely out of the public domain, except as a commercial investment.

There is no body which has been given the charge of regulating the Snowy scheme—that is, the environmental impacts or the social impacts of the scheme—under New South Wales environmental laws. There has been some discussion of a Snowy scientific committee being given a role in integrated management, but there is nothing about that in this legislation.

With the issues that arise about the environmental management of the riparian ecosystems and the history of failure to consider the environment, I believe an integrated approach is required which represents the interests of both New South Wales and Victoria, as well as the Commonwealth as the body protecting our natural heritage on behalf of nature and of the wider public.

I think there needs to be an administrative body with the specific tasks of regulation, oversight and assuring that measures taken in the interest of nature and people are enforced. I do not believe that the interests of New South Wales are necessarily equivalent to the interests of Victoria and the Commonwealth. In particular, I do not see how New South Wales environmental water and planning laws will deal effectively with environmental impacts of the Snowy scheme on rivers such as the Snowy River in Victoria.

The primary objection I have to this bill is the fundamental one that I do not believe the interests of the people of Australia, of New South Wales or of Victoria are best served by taking the Snowy scheme out of direct public control. There are too many issues affecting the environment and people around the distribution and pricing of water resources, of power and the environmental impacts of how the scheme is run. I think that direct control through those who operate it is the best mechanism, rather than attempts to regulate a for profit corporation.

The secondary objection I have is that there is no responsibility taken in this bill for the environmental issues. It is that objection to which my amendment is directed, and I note that Senator Brown has spoken to that already and Senator Lees has mentioned those issues in relation to the environment.

The government and the ALP will claim potentially that their amendment and their water inquiry are sufficient, even though the legislation in its form will already have gone through. So basically the legislation will not take account of the findings of the inquiry.

The reference to the water inquiry, while dealing with water flows, does not have as any sort of reference the re‐establishment of water flow rates sufficient to see the environments of the river system re‐established. So we can assume that, no matter what happens, there is nothing to ensure that that will happen.

The report may raise those issues, and they will certainly be realised during the inquiry, but it will not necessarily make recommendations to support the re‐establishment of such flows. It is really not an inquiry that even includes a brief to determine what those flows might be, though it is currently widely reported that they—and Senator Brown has mentioned this—are around 28 per cent of the original flow. Currently, the flows in the Snowy are only about one per cent of the original flow.

I am further distressed because the procedure being followed is again to pass a bill with known problems, with some indication or promise that after passage the problems will be examined and fixed. We saw that occur with the competition policy legislation, which was passed without any adequate treatment of what `public interest' meant and with no clear idea of what bills would be exempted. We were told that that would be sorted out in the future. The states were given a year to establish what basis they would use for asking for exemption and what community service obligations would be imposed. As far as I know, there is still no really clear notion of what constitutes public interest, and yet there are over 2,000 pieces of legislation throughout Australia—that is Commonwealth, state and local legislation—being reviewed as we speak.

In regard to the Snowy scheme, I do not think it is adequate to have an identified problem with a bill and then pass that bill on the condition that an inquiry will be held. The inquiry will make a report, present options and these may or may not be taken up in any final agreement.

What you are doing is effectively removing the power of the Commonwealth parliament to have any effective input or review of this process.
