We do not know if the recommendations will be adequate and if what is agreed upon will be adequate to address the issues. We know that there are issues, and many, many people, especially in Victoria in the Snowy watershed, are concerned. We have no idea whether their issues will be addressed or addressed adequately.

We are being asked to pass a framework to create a problem—to create a problem, I emphasise—without being aware of any solution being offered and in a way that the parliament will never get to have input into that solution. This is not an adequate way to deal with such an important issue.

The Snowy hydro scheme is an important issue. It covers a very large part of the watershed of the south‐east of Australia and many of our significant river systems. It is not just about electricity privatisation. It is not just about getting a quick payback for the Commonwealth by generating private sector debt or the sell‐off of an asset.

My amendment would reverse the current process. It would say that, before corporatisation or privatisation are even considered, the environmental issues must be resolved and some means of assuring that regulation, oversight and enforcement be provided. This should be included in legislation. At that point, the parliament can examine the provisions and consider whether they are adequate and well formulated and whether changes must be made. I commend to the Senate my amendment, which says that the bill should be withdrawn until that time. On the issues of corporatisation, I would like to make a few additional points. One of the issues arose in respect of the hearings into competition policy. I mention that because there is so much about this which was brought up in relation to competition policy in respect of the whole issue of environment and public interest.

One of the issues which arose then was in the submission of the Institute of Engineers. They made the point that one result of corporatisation and privatisation would be the loss of intellectual capital and intellectual history, using the examples of the dams and water management. They pointed out that once that history and expertise is lost, as it almost certainly will be with outsourcing and contracting out of dam maintenance services, the result will be the loss of that engineering expertise from Australia.

Australia is not big enough nor does it have enough dams—probably fortunately—to maintain a single contractor for dealing with the engineering issues of large hydro‐electric projects. The result the Institute of Engineers outlined would be loss of such expertise here and contracting out of such services to experts from nations such as the United States and Canada.

By far the biggest issue being raised is that of the effect of the current water flow practices into the riparian ecosystems, especially that of the Snowy River. From a major river system which was one of the significant features of the Australian continent, the river has been now slowed to a trickle. This is in a region which is relatively unrepresented anywhere else in Australia and hence anywhere else in the world. The Australian continent is biologically unique. We have huge numbers of unique species and in creatures such as the marsupials we have unique lines of biological development. This is due to our geographical isolation. Continental Australia is relatively flat and the only area of significant mountains is the Snowy Mountains. As a consequence, the ecological conditions in much of this area are not duplicated in other areas of Australia. This area is therefore a unique area in a unique continent.

The plant and animal systems evolved within that area with certain river flows. Cutting off those flows constitutes a huge change to ecological systems and conditions. It affects plants and animals, insects and other creatures that depend on them directly and indirectly.The establishment of the Snowy hydro scheme effectively closed off those river flows. From 1967 flows into the Snowy River dropped to about, as I mentioned, one per cent of the level they were before construction of the dam at Jindabyne.

The result has been large changes in environmental conditions in that watershed. It has been estimated that you need about 28 per cent of the flow to re‐establish even the basis of the ecosystem. The changes that have occurred do not have an impact only on the Snowy Mountains, they affect the entire river system all the way down to Orbost. The environment at the very mouth where the river enters the ocean has been affected and the reduction in flow has meant massive sea salt incursions from the sea into what was a rich and diverse fresh water delta system.

While the Murray‐Darling Basin Commission may have a role in the regulation of the Snowy scheme it is a somewhat marginal role in terms of its ability to argue that it can regulate the flows into the Snowy without being granted specific powers to do so. An example of the problem of corporatisation is that the corporation is seen as an electricity company, rather than as an integrated system manager. There is little or no consideration of either the ecological effects I have already mentioned or the management of the resource for irrigation purposes. There are no guarantees that the water flows to irrigators will be maintained and, once corporatisation occurs, there are no real mechanisms to address this other than the Murray‐Darling Basin Commission.

In the Murray‐Darling Basin over‐irrigation means that rising salinity has already badly affected 500,000 hectares of some of the best land in the country. There is little or no way the Commonwealth can effectively regulate water use. The term of the water agreement granted to the corporation is 75 years with a 50‐year renewable option. The New South Wales legislation has, I understand, options for more frequent review—every 10 years—but this does not make the Commonwealth abrogation of responsibility more acceptable.

The terms of the corporatisation principles at the end of the explanatory memorandum extend the existing rights through a licence agreement which under defence acts allow the authority to effectively exert full control over the water. While there is some leeway for changing the current water regime most of the clauses, and indeed the inquiry into environ mental impacts proposed in the ALP amendment, refer to the existing or current pattern of water flows. These are inadequate to maintain the Snowy riparian ecosystems.

I have to again highlight the proposed second reading amendment which is in my name because passage of the amendment will result in the bill being withdrawn until after an inquiry. An inquiry will be required to establish the flows required to re‐establish ecological viability of the Snowy ecosystem and to make what recommendations are necessary to ensure that such flows can be established and maintained. The recommendations and a mechanism to ensure that the environment oversight can be maintained and regulation enforced must be incorporated into any bill to corporatise the Snowy scheme.

The parliament would then get to see the entire package before it removes the Snowy scheme from the sphere of effective and accountable public control. I have to repeat, because it is very important, that if the bill goes through without those measures in it then under the Corporations Law it becomes very difficult, if not impossible, for the public interest to be included in the way that corporation is operated.I think our amendment is the proper and responsible approach to dealing with this issue. If my amendment gets up the bill will be withdrawn. If it does not, I will oppose the bill. In principle, I believe that the control and ownership of the Snowy hydro scheme should remain in public hands.

It is one of those issues, if we add it into the lot of what is happening in the government, that should be seen in perspective. Bit by bit the Commonwealth is withdrawing from nearly all aspects of environmental oversight in relation even to such things as world heritage areas. Not only has the Commonwealth not taken action on such areas as Shark Bay, for instance, but in fact as soon as there has been whatever agreement, adequate or inadequate; as soon as whatever action has been taken by the state governments like Western Australia; as soon as whatever has happened to hound species, whatever has happened in inadequate research, whatever has happened in inadequate reporting or whatever has happened anywhere, it is considered by the government to be okay. As long as they get it off their hands, as long as they can turn their back on it it appears to be okay.

Handing over holus bolus to states seems to be the only method this Commonwealth government has of dealing with the environment. I guess if I was to make a fairly sure assessment of the future I would say that as soon as the Natural Heritage Trust money runs out that will go hand in hand with the Commonwealth by that stage having got rid of just about every element of environmental oversight, even to do with the Commonwealth bills they are supposed to be administering.

I certainly hope by that stage that there is some sort of High Court challenge. I hope that, if not, there is a major debate within the community about the urgent need for constitutional reform to make sure that no Commonwealth government can act in this way again; that is, to pretend that the environment is not their responsibility and to pretend that they have no responsibility in Australia for those things such as ecosystems that straddle more than one state. There are issues of ecological sustainability and issues such as world heritage areas and species that they will not accept any responsibility for.

More and more, people are believing that Commonwealth, state and local governments all have a responsibility. That is my firm belief as well. I believe it is only when these kinds of responsibilities are firmly entrenched as a right of citizenship—that is, that ecological sustainability is a right of citizenship in Australia, as it is in many other countries—that we will have an assurance that Commonwealth governments of any sort will take their responsibility seriously. I move:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"the Bill be withdrawn and that corporatisation or privatisation of all or any part of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Authority not be considered until such time as:

PARA.TAB: (a) an inquiry is completed into the level of water flows which will be required to re-establish the viability of the ecosystems to a state similar to that prior to the existence of the Scheme, for the Snowy River, and other riverine systems affected by the Scheme; and
(b) recommendations are made to assure such flows are maintained; and
(c) the necessary measures to incorporate the recommendations, and assure oversight and compliance, are incorporated into the Bill".

BREAK.PARA: I commend my second reading amendment to the Senate.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the second reading debate on the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill 1997 and the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 to endorse the comments that have been made by senators so far about the significance and the importance of the Snowy River to Australia's heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: An officer from my electoral office and I took the time to travel down to the Snowy River to have a look directly at the environmental damage and degradation that has occurred as a result of not having environmental flows on that river since the dam was constructed. I endorse the observations made by previous senators about the state of that river. It is weed‐choked and it is dying. There is a golden opportunity for the governments of Australia to rectify this issue.

I would like to talk about the potential for rectifying this issue. We understand quite clearly that this process of corporatisation has progressed to a critical point. So I would like to backtrack slightly and look at the motivation as to why we would consider this window of opportunity to deal with the issue of environmental flows.

First of all, the act being amended presents the only window of opportunity prior to corporatisation for this issue to be addressed from an environmental perspective. Post corporatisation there will be very little opportunity, if any, as there is a direct correlation between an increase in the flows for the Snowy River and a reduced output for Snowy Hydro, which is the company to be formed once this bill is eventually passed—if it is passed.

Post corporatisation, there will be very little opportunity for any changes to be made to the flows. I am speaking from a very pragmatic point of view. Of course Snowy Hydro would be able to make such a decision, but in the context of the way Snowy Hydro is being established, and considering its role, purpose and intent, I think due consideration of environmental issues is something that certainly is not likely to be at the forefront of its agenda and not of primary consideration.

What are the motivations? Not only is there an opportunity for the Commonwealth to play a direct role in instigating and rectifying activities to enhance the environment of the Snowy River corridor, but also there are some economic reasons to do it. Regional development is one, which I will turn to. If environmental issues are not enough to motivate this government to take the appropriate action that is open to them through our amendment, if it is passed, then some of the regional development issues could be factored into their decision making.

The whole area of the Snowy River beyond the dam is not exactly a thriving opportunity for local industry to develop. But an increase in Snowy River flows opens all sorts of opportunities, including ecotourism and the development of sporting and recreational activities downstream, in both New South Wales and Victoria. It also opens the doors to the consideration of building an agricultural industry based on the reintroduction of flows to that river. So it is too simplistic for this government to stick to its dry arguments about its motivation for not addressing environmental flows.

Turning now to the water inquiry: we have heard about the mechanism that is provided through the water inquiry to allow the minister to play a role in determining the merits or otherwise of that water inquiry and, if you like, endorsing or otherwise its outcomes and its processes. This window of opportunity that our amendment provides for does just that. Although not too much of what this government has done gives one hope for such due consideration to be made, it does lock in a mechanism that will give the minister an opportunity to deal with this issue prior to gazettal.

The water inquiry I think has quite a high degree—perhaps an undue degree—of focus in the context of the debate about this bill. There could have been a far simpler mechanism, which is this Commonwealth government insisting that that inquiry be completed prior to this bill being considered. But, failing that, the mechanism that we are providing for will provide such a process.

I would like to now turn to the role of the Commonwealth with respect to Snowy Hydro. It is a player in terms of the three governments that are involved in this issue. The Commonwealth's involvement in Snowy Hydro is one of great responsibility, and that responsibility will essentially be dispelled with the passage of this bill.

I would like to make some references to the report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on this particular bill and in making such references turn to a quote that Mr Collis of Native Fish Australia made. He pointed out:

. . . the state of the Snowy River has come about directly as a result of Commonwealth government activities. We see that the Commonwealth government has a responsibility to do something about that situation.

No‐one can argue with that statement. There is no doubt about that. The question I think here is whether or not the government will take up the opportunity to act in conveying a strong view about the water inquiry.

Of course, there is the opportunity under that water inquiry to determine that environmental flows must begin. That could in fact be a recommendation of that inquiry. I know from all the evidence that I have heard, through both particular Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee hearings and my dealings with Paul Leete from the Snowy River Alliance and all the other activists who have devoted a significant proportion of their personal time to solving this issue in favour of the river and the communities that live around it, that this issue is quite fundamental. They still see there is an opportunity for these flows to be allocated.

The campaign of these people—and I would like to acknowledge particularly the work of Paul Leete through the Snowy River Alliance—has been one of passion and one of dedication, and they have had a high degree of commitment to what is a fundamental government responsibility. It really does pare this issue right back to the bare bones of what government is all about.

The Commonwealth did initiate the Snowy River scheme and, because of this convoluted process of government responsibilities and proportional allocation of assets relating to the Snowy hydro‐electric scheme, we as a Commonwealth find ourselves in almost a legislative bind in terms of process and hence a quite disempowering process from the Commonwealth government in that the joint decisions between the Commonwealth and states are driving it. Hence the argument will no doubt be put by Senator Parer that this is not the Commonwealth's baby; it is something that is being driven at best jointly, at worst by the states, and something in which the Commonwealth is just a bit player.

I do not believe that in this day and age such an argument holds any merit and that, in issues relating to the environment, environment protection and in this case restoration of the environment that is achievable through a government decision, any such ducking of responsibility is acceptable. I do not believe it is acceptable to the community and it should not be acceptable in this place.

I would like to put forward the view that the people who involve themselves in the water inquiry have to take the highest degree of responsibility for these considerations and should not see it as just an exercise that was negotiated to allow the passage of these bills and the progression of the corporatisation agenda. They should see it for what it is constructed to be under this legislation: a genuine inquiry into all matters relating to the water that flows through the Snowy hydro scheme, and that of course includes the environmental flows.

It would be a great shame if that water inquiry were to be allowed to focus specifically on the economic issues relating to the flows coming out the other end of the Snowy hydro scheme, and not take into consideration the full environmental impact of not allowing the Snowy River to flow again through water allocations. I believe that the minister, Senator Parer, has a direct responsibility to make sure that that water inquiry addresses that specific issue in a thorough way, in a contextual way, with a strong environmental focus. I would go so far as to say that that environmental focus must begin to consider how to quantify how much we value a river. How do we put a price, an economic value, on something like that? It is very difficult.

I would like to see the minister make sure that this water inquiry take into their considerations these very broad issues, recognising of course that that single opportunity that is articulated certainly in our amendment to provide the minister with that opportunity is probably the last opportunity in the context of the corporatisation bill. If he fails in relation to that responsibility, and it is a pretty tough call for Senator Parer, he will be condemning not just the river but also the community that has grown around that river for the last however many years and has seen the degradation that has arisen as a result of the restriction of the flows.

There has been a report about the environmental flows. When we talk about environmental flows, we are talking about the restoration of about 28 per cent of the original water flows to the Snowy River. This figure is not arbitrary; it is based on a scientific study that has been presented before the committee and circulated well in the context of the consideration of this bill. At this stage the government has not shown any degree of interest in acting upon that particular study. But it has, through its statements as part of the inquiry and public statements, indicated that all such research will be considered as part of that water inquiry.

The 28 per cent flows are what is required to restore the river to a minimum degree of flow that will strive to achieve some sort of ecological balance and sustainability for a river. Nonetheless, it still will be far diminished. In the preparation of that particular study and the activities once again of the Snowy River Alliance, a high degree of maturity, sensibility and practicality has been shown.

So, Minister, it is obviously a situation of dealing with more than just a strung‐together community group. You are dealing with a group in the Snowy River Alliance who have taken the time to prepare their facts and figures, have had the opportunity to come before various committees as witnesses and state their case and have had the support of significant environment and community organisations who are concerned about the Snowy River. To disregard their evidence and not give it the status it deserves is as much an abdication of the responsibilities of this government as would be allowing the water inquiry to proceed without the factors being taken into account, as I have discussed.

Finally, I would like to make the point again about the Commonwealth's responsibilities. There was some discussion in the committee about section 100 of the constitution and the application of the Commonwealth jurisdiction in the establishment of the Snowy River scheme in the first place. I alluded to the convoluted nature of the way the states and the Commonwealth have had to negotiate the process to achieve corporatisation.

It is, I believe, an anomalous situation. By the virtue of that fact, I think that strengthens the argument that the Commonwealth must take the highest possible level of responsibility in dealing with this, as the gazettal of this bill will remove the opportunity for the Commonwealth to ever have a say on environmental factors of the Snowy River. When it was established, there were no comprehensive environmental reports conducted and there is nothing on the record to explain or assess the potential impact of the Snowy River scheme in the first place. For that, we as the parliament and you specifically as the government have to take responsibility in the very first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sitting here doing my duty, listening to Senator Lundy and, prior to that, to Senator Margetts, I was reading the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech. This legislation does seem to have confused purposes. I am sure the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), with his intellectual ability, will be able to resolve the confusion in his usual lucid way. The attachment to the explanatory memorandum, as an introduction, says:

BREAK.PARA: Corporatisation of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority . . . and related aspects of the Snowy Mountain Hydro-electric Scheme (collectively the Scheme) by the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria is a significant national micro-economic reform initiative and is being undertaken in accordance with Council of Australian Governments commitments.The message that comes through there is clear—that this is a micro‐economic reform, that this particular bill is aimed at ensuring that Australia's economic wellbeing is forwarded. That would be consistent with attachment 1 to the explanatory memorandum, which says:
The principal purposes of Snowy Hydro are to include:
(1) participation on a commercial basis in the emerging NEM—
that is the national electricity market—
as an independent electricity generator;
(2) participation on a commercial basis in any future developments and operations approved by its Board; and
(3) meeting appropriate water arrangements.

A reading of that particular document would indicate that this is an agreement between Victoria, New South Wales and the Commonwealth to ensure that there is a commercial basis to the scheme and that the gross national product is going to be increased by the way that particular scheme is put into operation.

Having read that, it would be reasonable to assume that the sooner this act is passed the better, because that is the basis upon which it would go forward. So why should there be any delay? That is if you look at the attachment to the explanatory memorandum. But when you go to the second reading speech, that does not seem to be the thrust. It says:
The idea is not to bring this legislation into operation as soon as possible but to delay the coming into operation of this legislation for a considerable period.

Indeed—a period beyond six months. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you know, six months is the usual period that is allowed, the longest period that is allowed, before legislation comes into operation. Drafting instructions, for example, say that any legislation that gets the royal assent should come into operation within six months of that happen ing. That is not the case with this legislation. So you say to yourself: why the delay in the time at which this legislation comes into operation? The answer probably lies on page 8 of the second reading speech:

At the broader level, the Council of Australian Governments agreed to a process for water industry reform in Australia at its meeting on 11 April 1995. Of particular relevance to the corporatisation of the Snowy scheme is the agreement by government that the environment is a legitimate user of water.
On page 21 of the explanatory memorandum the word `environment' is not mentioned. So a different concept is now introduced into the equation in the second reading speech. It goes on:

Governments have taken these concepts seriously. A water inquiry is to be held before the scheme is corporatised. The inquiry will examine issues arising from the current pattern of water flows in the rivers and streams within and flowing from the Snowy mountains area, resulting from the operation of the scheme. The Commonwealth has agreed that New South Wales and Victoria are the two states which have principal responsibility for the Snowy scheme. Water management will jointly sponsor the public inquiry.

So if we set aside the concepts of commercialisation, of competition and competition policy and take on the issue of the environment, then it makes sense that you have to have an inquiry. That is the thrust, as I understand it, of page 8 of the second reading speech.

So the question arises—and it has been referred to already by previous speakers: why does this bill come in now when the second reading speech says: `No, the effect of corporatisation should not become apparent until after an inquiry'? This legislation, if it is passed today, will come into operation more than six months down the track—which is not good, according to drafting instructions and according to such outstanding committees as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. This legislation will come into operation at a time that is not in accordance with the general rules about legislation. It will come into operation after an inquiry, which inquiry will have, I would have thought, some significant impact on the very question of whether this scheme should be corporatised.

No doubt one of the problems that faces the government is that this is an agreement between three governments: New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth. They have sat down and had a look at this and they have come to an agreement. Part of the agreement is that each of those jurisdictions will bring into operation legislation. It is always difficult, no doubt, to arrange things so the actions of all the governments synchronise in the way that is wanted. Nevertheless, taking into account that issue, the problem remains: why take an action now that depends upon another action further down the line which may well impact upon the action of these three governments? So there seems to be a confusion of concepts in this legislation. The second reading speech goes on:

The inquiry will be conducted by a single commissioner appointed by New South Wales and Victoria and will report within six months, followed by a two month period to agree a final outcome corporatisation to agree a final outcome. Corporatisation legislation will be finalised in all three parliaments following the states' agreements on the outcome.

So you have this paragraph in the second reading speech which guarantees that the legislation is going to come into operation more than six months down the line. Indeed, it might be a considerable time down the line because there has to be a report within six months followed by a two‐month period to agree a final outcome. How that is going to happen within two months, I do not know. Say the states do not agree. Say, in the light of the report by the single commissioner, Victoria does not agree or New South Wales does not agree or the Commonwealth does not agree. Then what will happen?

How can anybody prior to an inquiry agree that there will be a final outcome? It seems to me to be a strange logic that you have an inquiry now; that the results of that inquiry are to be sent to three entities, the Commonwealth and two states; and then they have to finalise an outcome within two months. But suppose that they cannot; suppose that the discussion does not allow for that—unless there is already an agreement as to what will be the final outcome. If there is already an agreement as to what will be the final outcome, why do you need two months after the inquiry to get to it? This piece of legislation is a matter of concern. The speech continues:
Corporatisation legislation will be finalised in all three parliaments following the states' agreement on the outcome.

Does that mean that the Commonwealth does not have to agree? Does it mean the only agreement that is relevant is the agreement between New South Wales and Victoria? If the Commonwealth also has to be a party to the agreement, then why does the second reading speech say—and I read it again—`Corporatisation legislation will be finalised in all three parliaments following the states' agreement on the outcome.' What about the Commonwealth's agreement? Is the Commonwealth to have no say in this? The speech goes on:
Any outcome on environmental flows can only be determined in light of the finding of the water inquiry.
That sounds a very sensible and logical statement.

The Minister's second reading speech is really saying that you can only determine a very central issue to this whole issue in the light of the finding of the water inquiry. Has there been an agreement? What is the extent of the agreement? What effect is the water inquiry to have on the outcome? Is it allowed to have any effect on the outcome? If so, that would seem to be inconsistent with some of the assurances given in the second reading speech as to when a finalisation of this matter is to be reached. The speech continues:

The inquiry will allow the views of all interested parties to be considered—irrigators, environmental interests and other downstream users of water. Until then, there is no valid basis on which governments can take any action to alter water allocations from the scheme.

Why bring in legislation prior to all these issues being determined? Is it being brought in now because the three governments cannot agree without there being some sort of legislation such as this put in place? If that is so, how does this legislation assure that that agreement will take place? Further in the second reading speech, the following statement is made:

Governments have been unfairly accused of taking no notice of calls for increased environmental flows for the Snowy River. To respond only to the views of one interested group in advance of a public water inquiry—particularly by legislating for environmental flows in the Snowy River—would clearly disenfranchise other legitimate interests in the inquiry from the decision making process. Governments have not been prepared to do this.

It is good that they should not do that. It is good that, as this second reading speech says, everybody's interests should be taken into account—not only the environmentalists' interests but also the interests of farmers, of people who use the water generally. That seems to be a most sensible sort of a suggestion.

But why have legislation introduced and why go ahead with this now when in the second reading speech the minister himself says, `Look, it would be a silly sort of a thing and a bit unfair to do anything before you have an inquiry.' That seems absolutely correct. But then, having said that in the second reading speech, the government goes ahead and does do something: it introduces this legislation and wants to pass it through. So it is a very confused message that comes out of this legislation, that comes out of the explanatory memorandum and that comes out of the second reading speech. The second reading speech continues:

It is also important that the potential financial impacts of any changed water arrangements impacting on Snowy Hydro Limited be identified before the corporatisation legislation is proclaimed. This will ensure that the company is established on a sound commercial basis and can operate in the competitive national electricity market.

That again makes a lot of sense. But then why take the steps that are taken in this legislation, without having all this worked out? If it had all been worked out, the minister could have come in here, in his lucid and intellectual way, and said, `Look, this is what we've done. We've had an inquiry. This is what we've found out. We've looked at the commercial projections. These are the sound commercial projections we are going to have with this corporatisation. We'll go ahead now and do it.' Then there would not be any need to put the proclamation of the legislation off to some unspecified time in the future.

Probably the best way of making the point is to ask: if this legislation is passed, when will it come into operation? I do not think anybody can tell us that. If they can tell us that, then much of the material in the second reading speech does not have the force that one would have thought it should.

Instead of passing legislation now and putting off its proclamation until some time down the line, why not go ahead and conduct the inquiries? Why not look at the economic ramifications, the environmental ramifications and the ramifications that it will have on the farmers? Then, with all that knowledge that will be before us, we can look at this legislation in a calm and measured fashion, as we always should in this chamber, and, as the minister would know, the measured debate which we always have in this chamber can be repeated in respect of this legislation. They are my thoughts from sitting here and listening to the debate. It seems that what has been said by previous speakers has a lot of force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Margetts's excellent amendment because it builds on the commonsense of the argument that the heart of the Labor Party—if I might describe Senator Cooney and Senator Lundy in that way—put to the committee. It is absurd to have a situation where the corporatisation, and therefore the loss of power, of the Commonwealth is being proposed in this bill when we do not have the results of a water inquiry into the sort of flow that is needed down the Snowy River to ensure its environmental viability.

SPEECH.PARA: To reiterate, since the dam was built in Jindabyne, the flow down this remarkable river has dropped to less than one per cent of its previous natural flow. The result has been catastrophic. The description of everybody who goes to the river these days is that of languid pools, weed invasion, a shrivelled river, a haunting echo of the grandeur of the wild Snowy River of the past.

Scientists have already established that more than a quarter of the natural flow—28 per cent—is the minimum required to ensure some ecological viability for the river in its flow through southern New South Wales and Victoria to the ocean in the centuries ahead. Once corporatisation has occurred, that will not happen. The problem with the Labor Party's argument on this issue is that it does not flow through to a logical conclusion. We should take this opportunity to ensure that the outcome of the water inquiry is debated in this chamber before we go ahead and wipe our hands of responsibility. That is what we are doing if we pass this legislation for corporatisation.

If the Labor Party is really serious about these concerns that the river be given viability, if it is genuinely going to do what it can and act on behalf of the river, its residents and all those who have come to love it, it will support Senator Margetts's amendment. What is the difference between Senator Margetts's amendment which says, `Let's withdraw this bill until we have the results of a scientific and community inquiry and then we can proceed,' and Labor's amendment which says, `Let's pass this bill in the Senate now, divest ourselves of power and leave it to Senator Parer to decide whether he is satisfied at the end of the inquiry to allow the corporatisation to go ahead'?

The difference is that of course Senator Parer will be satisfied. It will not matter what the outcome will be of the inquiry into the Snowy River's environmental health. As I said earlier, look at what Senator Parer did with the Jabiluka uranium mine proposal. Firstly, the traditional owners are opposed to that mine. Did he safeguard the key interests of that community? No, he did not. It was thumbs down to them; thumbs up to the uranium cartel. He gave the mine the go‐ahead.

Secondly, there are extensive environmental reasons why that mine should not go ahead. For example, it will impact on the wilderness and the natural ecosystem, and there are insoluble problems that result from uranium mining, with uranium being dispersed around the planet. Does he have answers to those concerns? No, he does not. Has he held up the environmental concerns—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, I refer you to the matter of relevance in regard to Senator Brown. We are talking about the corporatisation of the Snowy.

—On the point of order, the point is that what I am saying is of key relevance to what Senator Parer, who has just come back into the chamber, does. The Labor Party amendment, as against that of Senator Margetts, gives him the power to act. That is what I am arguing. That is important and germane to the point of discussion, which is Senator Margetts's amendment.
—There is no point of order. Continue, Senator Brown.

—What I am saying and what Senator Parer obviously does not like is that his environmental record, let alone his concern for community groups in big developments, is abysmal. And what the Labor Party is saying here is, `Let's leave it to Senator Parer. Let's leave the fate of the Snowy River to Senator Parer.' I say to the Labor Party, that is abysmal. If you really mean that you are going to act in the interests of the Snowy River and the residents downstream of the Snowy scheme, you support Senator Margetts's amendment. Give some teeth to the rhetoric about protecting the interests of that community and that river because your amendment does not. Your amendment puts it into the hands of Senator Parer.

SPEECH.PARA: Is that what the Labor Party thinks of the environment? Is that what the Labor Party thinks of the communities at Dalgety, Orbost and all the other places downstream of the Snowy scheme? I would hope not. They say not. But you get judged on these things on your actions. So, when inevitably there is a division on this matter I will be supporting Senator Margetts and the Greens' determination that the community and environment interests of the Snowy River be looked after and that we do not give away our powers to Senator Parer.

I appeal to the Labor Party to think again about this. It has not said that it will not support Senator Margetts's amendment but that is what I was waiting to hear. In the absence of that assurance I fear they are not going to, that they prefer Senator Parer's record on the environment and community response to Senator Margetts's record. That speaks for itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does.
—The whip opposite, the representative of the government, says it does speak for itself. So there we have the difference.
—What can Senator Margetts do when she is not in power?

—Well, at the moment Senator Margetts is empowered. She is empowered to come in here with an amendment which acts in the interests of the great Snowy River system and the residents downstream of the scheme. And she is empowered through that to call on the opposition, which understands the argument, to defend those interests against this government and its corporatisation bent and its constricted and narrow view of life which brings everything down to dollars and puts in the never‐never other fundamental values about community and local environment which average Australians hold as important.

SPEECH.PARA: So there it is. This matter will be determined by the Labor Party. This matter has the Labor Party in the balance of power. So I appeal to the Labor Party: as far as the Snowy River is concerned, support Senator Margetts's amendment and do not, as you are intending to do through your amendment, hand the matter across to Senator Parer on a plate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Margetts and to also indicate that the Democrats will be supporting this amendment. I am very disappointed that the Labor Party amendment is apparently—and from what we have heard, definitely—as far as they are prepared to go. In particular, I draw the attention of all senators to the speeches by Senator Cooney and Senator West, but in particular by Senator Lundy, who have outlined the concerns that Senator Brown, Senator Margetts and I have also been outlining. So how the Labor Party can now apparently be prepared not to support the amendment I find amazing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what this amendment requires. It requires exactly what Senator Cooney was pointing out. Exactly the problem that Senator Cooney has identified will be solved if we support this amendment—if we look at the level of water flows before we move on and deal with the issue of corporatisation. I find it quite amazing, and interesting too, that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) stands up, raises a point of order and says this bill is about corporatisation. Yes, of course it is, Minister, but almost all of us here are arguing that it should not be until we have dealt with the issue of what we are going to do with the water.

As the second reading speech of the minister says, and Senator Cooney has referred to this, all of this is set in place and the understanding of what needs to be done is well and truly on the table. But it is all being done in the wrong order. The order in which we should be dealing with this issue is, firstly, to decide where the water is going so that once it is corporatised we are confident that all community interests have been met—at least that they have been heard. But here we have a Commonwealth government hell bent on getting rid as fast as it can of any responsibility for basically the Murray‐Darling Basin as well as the Snowy.

I understand the difficulties that giving more water—indeed, giving any water—over to the Snowy is going to create. That is why we need, I would suggest, a very thorough look at the upgrading of quite a number of irrigation schemes. If they are not upgraded they are finished anyway. Several of them are in their final throes. But the idea that irrigators seem to have that, yes, we will upgrade, but only if we can hang on to the water and then sell it off, is not in the best interests of any of our river systems.

So, if people such as Senator Lundy, Senator Cooney and Senator West, who have spoken very well about the key problems in western New South Wales and the key problems in the Snowy and the actual problems within the bill of the process, are really serious, hopefully they will talk the Labor Party around to understanding that we are not throwing out the concept of corporatisation. We are not even seriously discussing that here today. What we are saying is that we have to deal with the issue of where the water goes first. Surely, Minister, you understand that basic principle, that corporatisation should not go ahead until we know what is happening with the water out of the hydro‐electric scheme; indeed, the water out of all of that area in terms of whether it is even going to go east or west.

So I ask the government but particularly the Labor Party to have another think about what we are doing here. I know the Labor Party is concerned not to be seen to be voting against corporatisation. We could have that debate later on down the track. If this amendment goes down and the second reading goes through at this stage, this government is abrogating its responsibility to the most important river system in this country. So I ask again that people seriously look at what the real issue is on the table before us today. Yes, of course it is the Snowy River. I have been there recently as well to look at the degradation. It is really a series of pools that are occasionally connected by a bit of a trickle. I commend a couple of the communities along the river in that some of the weeds have been cleaned up, but it is a losing battle unless we get some water back in the river. But this is not just about environmental flows to the east; it is also making sure we have sufficient environmental flows going west as well and looking at which rivers they are going to go into and how it is all going to be managed by way of timing. So I appeal to all senators to think again about what the real issue is before us here today.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Since I last spoke in this debate, an amendment has been moved to the second reading by Senator Margetts of the Greens WA, and I would like to briefly address the amendment. The first thing I should do is rely on what I said at the beginning of my speech on the second reading. I said then that the corporatisation thrust in this legislation has been agreed by those on this side when we were in government and we continue to support it now; and that at this stage I foreshadowed an opposition amendment to be moved in the committee stage of the bill. I will discuss that later.

SPEECH.PARA: The point in making both those observations at the commencement of my remarks on the second reading was to indicate that the opposition supports the thrust of this legislation and that were we in government it would be legislation that we would enact. Although that speaks to the principle of the legislation, the second part of my remarks was to mark the spot, that we did not regard the legislation as perfect in every detailed respect, and, at the same time as endorsing the principle, to indicate support for an amendment that I intended to move to bring the bill back to a level of detailed content that we could support.

The issue that is behind the amendment moved by Senator Margetts I believe I understand well. Her amendment is quite clear. The effect of it would be that the bill does not have passage until such time as the findings of the water inquiry, as it has been referred to, with respect to the state of the river and the riverine systems affected by it have been brought to a conclusion and are able to be then proceeded with. So the obstacle that would be imposed by this amendment is that the bill would not proceed if this amendment were carried. That is not consistent with what I said at the beginning of my remarks—

TALK.START.PARA: —Until the inquiry has been done.

—Senator Margetts interjects, `Until the inquiry has been done.' I acknowledge that what she says is true and, to the extent that I erred in my interpretation, that is a correction to my interpretation. It is until such time as those steps are completed.

SPEECH.PARA: What the opposition believe though is that our amendment better addresses this issue. I know this matter has been the subject of debate, but I would like to go to the detail of our amendment. Our amendment is to clause 2 of the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill. It would omit subclause (3) of clause 2 and substitute a new subclause which would read:

BREAK.PARA: (3) A proclamation fixing a day for the commencement of Section 59 is not to be made unless:

(a) a public inquiry sponsored by the governments of New South Wales and Victoria has been held with respect to environmental issues arising out of the current pattern of water flows in rivers and streams, caused by the operation of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme, and the Minister is satisfied with the adequacy, outcome and—
and let me emphasise these words—
planned implementation of the inquiry, having regard to the continuing viability of the scheme.
Subclause (b) is irrelevant to this debate but enshrines back in the legislation what the provision essentially was before we deleted subclause 3.

In the opposition's view there are two issues here. One issue is that of balancing Labor's very important concerns about the Snowy River and the surrounds of that river system. Those concerns have been canvassed by many members on my side—and I acknowledge their expositions and thank them for them.

We are also concerned about the electricity generating elements of the Snowy Mountains scheme and the need to press ahead with corporatisation in the context of rationalising electricity power generation in Australia: that is, in all parts of Australia except Western Australia. Therefore, we do not approach this from a one‐dimensional viewpoint. We approach it from the two‐dimensional viewpoint of what this scheme is about.

That does not mean to say that we place less weight on one or the other, but we do strongly state that both have to be considered. It is not a case of one to the exclusion of the other. In those circumstances we think that the amendment we have foreshadowed will address the problem that has been of concern to the Senate this afternoon.

This does not delay the bill in the way the Greens' amendment would do. Therefore, we do not support the Greens' amendment. However, it does address both issues. For that reason, when the opportunity presents itself—if it does—we will move the amendment I have foreshadowed.

While I am on my feet, I must also say that I apprehend a further amendment that may be moved in the committee stage of this bill. That is an amendment by the Democrats. I can indicate to the chamber that, if that amendment is moved, we will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on the Snowy Hydro Corporatisation Bill and its associated consequential amendments. Following the introduction of these bills, the Treasurer, (Mr Costello), in his press release of 4 August announced changes to the way in which depreciations are to be calculated on assets of previously exempt entities that enter the tax net. As a result, any determination or regulation made under either Clause 51 or Clause 52 of the bill will be consistent with the policy announced by the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts has moved a second reading amendment which calls for the bills to be withdrawn until a water inquiry is conducted and its recommendations are incorporated into the bills. As Senator Cook has quite correctly pointed out, that would kill this bill. The government will be opposing Senator Margetts's amendment. Senator Margetts obviously does not understand that corporatisation is not a threat to the environment. On the contrary, it is an opportunity to address any environmental problems that have been caused by the scheme.

The scheme's existing arrangements prevent it from releasing water for environmental purposes, if that release reduces its capacity to generate electricity. That is the existing situation. In 1949, when the Snowy agreement was drafted, no‐one considered that there might be environmental problems associated with the scheme. Indeed, the whole great Snowy scheme was predicated on the diversion of the Snowy, predominantly, I might say, for irrigation purposes. The major engineering feat was incorporating the generation of electricity, in supporting that major aspect of the scheme.

New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth have worked closely together to set up a mechanism to address the environmental flow issue. It has been agreed that a six‐month water inquiry will be held before the scheme is corporatised. The legislation will not be proclaimed until after the inquiry has taken place and the states have considered its recommendations. If there are alterations to the water flow, they will be incorporated in the Snowy hydro's water licence. The licence will be reviewed regularly.

When we were discussing the issue with New South Wales and Victoria—and this has gone on for a long time—there was extensive debate about whether the inquiry should take place before or after the scheme was corporatised. We have come out with the best result. We will be able to corporatise the scheme and implement the results of the inquiry process as soon as it is complete, rather than waiting for legislation to drag through three parliaments. I do not have to remind honourable senators of the long processes which can occur in getting legislation through three jurisdictions. That is quite an exercise.

Senator Margetts wants to lock the results of the inquiry into legislation. It is a shame, Senator, that you did not attend the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee hearings of the bills, which you could have done. Senator Lundy and other senators on the committee did. You would have learnt that the Commonwealth does not have the constitutional power to grant water rights or to specify environmental flows.

The corporatisation is an important initiative. As I mentioned earlier, it has been in the making for a long time—I think Senator Cook mentioned it goes back to 1990. It will enable the scheme to operate in the national electricity market; it will improve its corporate governance; it will facilitate the repayment of Commonwealth debt; and, at the same time, it will enable the process that we have outlined in the bill for a six‐month environmental impact flow inquiry, which will be broad and will cover all aspects.

Someone mentioned Senator West's comments. I listened carefully to what Senator West had to say. One of her major concerns was the continuing flow for irrigation purposes to places like Griffith, and I think she talked about the great wine production that goes on down there. So it is not just the environmental aspects and not just the electricity considerations; it is also the water flows. It is the water that flows into the irrigation systems, and bear in mind that some of it flows eventually into South Australia. I commend the bills to the Senate.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (PARENTING AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Parer) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
This bill gives effect to a number of measures announced in the Government's 1997‐98 Budget and to one non‐Budget item.

The first of those measures is the introduction of a single parenting payment", to replace the current sole parent pension and parenting allowance. The new payment simplifies income support arrangements for parents by providing support for people with child rearing responsibilities, regardless of whether they are partnered or not. It also aims to reduce the social stigma which is sometimes associated with being a recipient of sole parent pension.

Parenting payment also aligns a number of conditions that currently vary between the existing payments. Administrative arrangements will be simplified, particularly where people move between lone parent and partnered status. Currently they need to cease receiving one payment and claim another. Core conditions, such as rates, income testing and concession cards will be maintained.

Both parenting allowance and sole parent pension are paid for the same reason, except that parenting allowance is paid to partnered parents and the sole parent pension is paid to lone parents. A single parenting payment recognises a person's responsibility for caring for children irrespective of marital status.

Consistent with the move toward simplicity and consistency, the bill also makes amendments to the social security allowance provisions aimed at simplifying the hardship rules that apply in relation to the ordinary waiting period, and the income maintenance period. Currently, the rules for waiver of various waiting periods in the legislation are inconsistent. They have different definitions of hardship and different types of expenditure can be taken into account. Amendments contained in the bill introduce a common approach.

The hardship rules will be standardised, with the first requirement being that the person is in "severe financial hardship". The test for determining whether a person is in severe financial hardship will be whether or not the person's readily available funds are less than the appropriate fortnightly rate of allowance. For the liquid assets waiting period and the income maintenance period, there will be an additional requirement that the expenditure that caused the severe financial hardship must have been "unavoidable and essential" (such as emergency medical treatment or mortgage/rent payments falling due in the waiting period.)

The bill also provides that the liquid assets waiting period may be partially waived, which is not possible under the current rules. This will align the liquid assets waiting period provisions with those applying to the income maintenance period.

The bill also contains amendments to simplify the Data‐matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990. In particular, the bill will remove references to specific payment and program types dealt with by the Social Security portfolio and replace these with a generic reference. This will remove the need to make legislative amendments each time a new payment is created or an old payment is renamed. Other amendments will also be made to the act to streamline the administration of the Program.

The bill contains amendments that introduce significant reforms in the area of child disability allowance. A simpler assessment process, involving a Child Disability Tool, will be introduced for use in relation to all new claims for disability allowance from 1 July 1998. The Assessment Tool will measure the impact of a child's disability on his/her functional ability in communication, mobility, self‐care and community living skills against developmental milestones. It will also assess a child's behaviour, emotional state and special care needs.

The use of the Assessment Tool will provide a simpler, more objective means of assessing eligibility for child disability allowance than the current criterion of "substantially more care an attention". It will provide a more objective method of assessment for parents and treating medical professionals, will minimise the subjectivity and inconsistency in the current criteria, will reduce the number of reviews and appeals, and will increase the level of understanding of the program by staff, parents and the medical profession. Parents with very disabled children have ben concerned that the child disability allowance payment has been seriously compromised over recent years.

A list of manifest disabilities and a list of chronic medical conditions that will be attached to the Assessment Tool tables will provide fast tack entry to the program and less frequent medical reviews.

Existing recipients of child disability allowance are protected through the insertion of a 5 years savings provision. The amendments will also increase the number of days allowed in the temporary cessation of care provisions and a reduction in the maximum period for which child disability arrears are payable.

The bill also makes amendments that impact on Health Care Cards. The first change is a part of the major overhaul of the child disability allowance that has already ben mentioned. It is designed to assist those children whose parent or guardian does not qualify for child disability allowance (due to the amendments to the child disability allowance qualification criteria for a disabled child), by maintaining their eligibility for a Health Care Card. The second measure extends the period over which a person's income is assessed for the purpose of determining whether they are a low income, disadvantaged person who is eligible for a Health Care Card. The assessment period, presently 4 weeks, will be extended to 8 weeks.

Finally, the bill changes the name of "family payment" to "family allowance". The change is made to help customers to understand more easily the social security system and their entitlements. Many families still use the term "family allowance", which was used to describe family payment entitlements from 1987 to the end of 1992.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Carr) adjourned.

TITLE.XREF: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE (SEX DISCRIMINATION AMENDMENT) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 September, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 makes discrimination on the basis of marital status illegal. The Student and Youth Assistance (Sex Discrimination Amendment) Bill provides for a permanent exemption from that part of the Sex Discrimination Act for the Austudy and Abstudy student assistance schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, a person who is married, but not a person living in a de facto relationship, is entitled on that basis alone to the independent rate of Austudy, subject to the normal income and assessment tests and the actual means test, if applicable.Abstudy living allowance, income testing and rent assistance eligibility criteria also come into conflict with the requirement of the Sex Discrimination Act in the same sort of way.

The Sex Discrimination Act contains an expiry provision which exempted student assistance schemes for a period of three years. This was to allow time for a way to be found to provide assistance to students without discriminating between those who are married and those in a de facto relationship.

This point is very important because, unlike social security payments where the lower rates are often payable to people in married or de facto relationships, the incentive in Austudy is the other way. If de facto relationships, as well as marriage, were the sole criteria for receiving the independent rate, there would be a financial incentive for students under 25, where the independent rate is payable on the basis of age, to set up such relationships in order to be regarded as independent and free of parental means tests. This incentive is much stronger now following the government's unjustified and unreasonable decisions in its first budget to raise the independent age of Austudy payments from 22 to 25.

Once the temporary legislative exemption for student assistance schemes in the Sex Discrimination Act had expired, the previous government sought exemption administratively through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Such exemptions are granted only for a finite period. When the Labor government's exemption period had expired the new coalition government sought a further exemption which will expire on 31 December this year.

In seeking this further exemption, the then minister, Senator Vanstone, undertook to provide a report to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission prior to the expiry of that exemption on long‐term solutions to address marital status discrimination in student assistance schemes. This report has only just been given to the opposition. We have only just received it, a very short time ago. I have not actually had an opportunity personally to view this report, but staff of the opposition received it a few minutes ago.

The opposition finds it extraordinary that this bill which makes very clear the direction in which the government is heading on discrimination in Austudy and Abstudy was introduced before the commitment to report to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission had in fact been properly met. I say it ought to be properly met by our actually having the opportunity to study that report. Perhaps the government believes that the Commission would be too preoccupied with its own downgrading which has been forced on it to be concerned with student assistance matters. Perhaps the government just does not care.

Either way, we in the opposition are appalled by such an approach. No‐one is going to deny that this is a difficult issue for any government to resolve. However, we cannot understand why a difficult issue must also be handled with such insensitivity. Student assistance matters have come in for a great deal of insensitive treatment from the Howard government, starting with the half billion attack on Austudy in its first budget, moving into Senator Vanstone's now infamous and incompetent administration of the revamped means test and culminating in the 1997‐98 budget's extraordinary attack on Abstudy.

The recently completed review of the means test was initiated because of the anger amongst coalition backbenchers who had to go and face great numbers of angry meetings and deal with extraordinarily large numbers of constituent complaints. Constituents were frustrated and bewildered, complaining of up to 50 minutes in waiting time to get onto the so‐called hotline or having to wait for more than three months for a review. It is apparent that many have given up attempts to study because the minister's incompetence has restricted, beyond the point where they could carry on, their right to access income support.

So it is not just a question of insensitivity in the way this matter has been dealt with. It is now, in the opposition's view, having a direct impact on the capacity of students to undertake study. The Commonwealth Ombudsman's report of 24 September said that Austudy needed a total overhaul. The report said the system was so complex that a PhD was needed to understand it and that it was failing students. At the centre of the complexity is the actual means test which has been changed by this government to make it almost unworkable.

BREAK.PARA: The 1998 academic year will see yet another version of the means test. However, we hope that with the new ministerial arrangements the system will now be administered with a great deal more competence than has been demonstrated by this government in the past. In the 1997‐98 budget, the government turned its attention to Abstudy. It announced $38.7 million in cuts out of what was an annual expenditure of only $130 million. The government has described these cuts as better targeting but if this government was actually about better targeting then in the opposition's view these funds would surely not have been cut; they would have been redirected.

Worse still, the government has announced a review of Abstudy after the cuts with a clear instruction that it should not recommend increased expenditure. These unjustified cuts demonstrate the government's lack of commitment to both indigenous education and to student income support. I know that the new Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, has indicated a preparedness to have another look at the Abstudy budget cuts and I hope this leads to a major rethink on the whole issue.

Recently the education committee of the Senate was in the Northern Territory speaking to Aboriginal groups about Aboriginal education and matters relating to the committee's work and it became abundantly clear that the government had not understood the full implications amongst Aboriginal communities of its changes to student assistance. It had not understood the impact on Aboriginal students in this country. During the second reading debate on the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill in November 1996 the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) spoke about the government's commitment to equal opportunity and the prevention of discrimination. Given the government's behaviour in relation to discrimination and student income assistance, however, and its pre‐emptory introduction of this bill it appears to have had no such commitment.

This bill makes it perfectly clear that the government has decided that the issue of discrimination between married and defacto couples in relation to the student assistance scheme is too hard. Of course, it is too difficult for this government to actually resolve.

The opposition does not believe that this question should be dealt with in such a cavalier fashion. It is not good enough for the government to simply walk away from these important issues. We are not prepared to support a permanent exemption for Austudy and Abstudy from the marital status provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act. I will be moving an amendment which provides exemption for a three-year period only, during which time we would expect, and the community has a right, to see some sort of genuine effort being made by this government to address this difficult problem in a realistic, sensible and significant way.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student and Youth Assistance (Sex Discrimination Amendment) Bill 1997 seeks to grant a permanent exemption for Abstudy and Austudy from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. I note that the exemption specifically applies to the treatment of students in defacto relationships and their definition as either independent or dependent. Currently student assistance schemes discriminate on the grounds of marital status in that the schemes differentiate between legally married and defacto couples.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats oppose the government's proposal for a permanent exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act. We believe that this is yet another deferral, another move, to avoid the task of finding a solution to this particular problem. We do not believe the proposal for a permanent exemption is acceptable and/or necessary. I take up Senator Carr's point relating to the report that was promised to this place and other senators. I acknowledge that it was faxed as soon as it was available, as I understand it, to my electorate office. So we have had an opportunity, albeit brief, to skim those pages. It is very important in the context of this debate.

I note the most recent exemption that was granted to DEETYA by HREOC. I will quote from the correspondence that was addressed to the first assistant secretary of the youth, students and social policy division on 29 November last year. In granting the exemption, HREOC gave a specific proviso. The precondition was the following:

That Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator the Hon Amanda Vanstone, give an undertaking that a report will be made to the HREOC prior to the expiry of the proposed exemption—
It is due to finish on 31 December this year—

on long term solutions to address the marital status discrimination within student assistance schemes (existing and proposed). This reporting would need to take into account the outcomes of the "Review of the Notions of Dependency" being conducted by the Minister for Social Security, Senator the Hon Jocelyn Newman.
Clearly, this particular report is key to this entire debate because it was the basis on which the previous exemption was granted.

The Democrats, like the opposition, will be moving an amendment. Originally we thought that a six-year exemption period would be appropriate. But I have decided that the most appropriate date would be 1 January 1999. That would be the maximum period of time that an exemption should be obtained or sought because it basically allows for the introduction and the operation of the common youth allowance legislation—something we will be debating in this place some time soon, I have no doubt. That is expected to start in July of next year. Assuming that something goes wrong, or it does not start on the date anticipated, I think 1 January 1999 is an appropriate time for which the exemption should be sought. I hope to see that amendment circulated shortly.

That is the basis on which the Democrats would be prepared to grant an exemption. We think that it is time to have a short period. For that reason, we do not believe that Senator Carr's amendment is appropriate, simply because three years is too long. Governments—Labor governments and the current government—have avoided finding solutions to this problem for too long. If you have a period that is at the latest January 1999, it takes into account proposed changes to student and other assistance schemes.

BREAK.PARA: My understanding is that in that report and in the Commonwealth youth allowance legislation this anomaly, this discrimination, should be cleared up. If that is the case, I commend the government on actually solving that, but I look forward to the minister's remarks in response.

From 1976 to 1982 de facto couples were able to be defined as independent if they fulfilled certain criteria, including two statutory declarations, preferably from their parents. I note that that criteria was removed by the then Fraser government for new but not continuing students. That was back in 1981. In 1984, when the Sex Discrimination Act was enacted, section 40 of the SDA granted either a two-year exemption for prior legislation directly inconsistent with the act in order that those acts could be properly aligned with the SDA; or a permanent exemption for certain legislation.

The Student and Youth Assistance Amendment Act 1973 was not included on the permanent list. Instead, a two-year exemption was granted with a view to rectifying the discriminatory aspects of the act. In 1991 student assistance schemes were given a further three-year exemption. This exemption was granted despite the government's intention yet again to find a solution to eradicate the discrimination.
I note that the minister, the Hon. Robert Brown, stated during the second reading speech of the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991 in the House of Representatives:

An exemption . . . is to be given to student assistance schemes provided for in the Student Assistance Act 1973. The criteria for means tests and rates of payment for these student assistance schemes are discriminatory on the basis of marital status. The Government has decided to undertake a review of the discriminatory provisions of these schemes over the next three years and has limited the period of exemption accordingly.

So after this expired Abstudy and Austudy became subject to a series of rolling exemptions through the system of administrative exemptions provided through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

In 1995, as some may recall, the ALP government proposed that a solution to address the discrimination was not to allow married couples to be granted independent Austudy. That proposal was rejected by the Senate and by the Australian Democrats. I mentioned earlier the most recent exemption to be granted—that is, in November last year—by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the proviso on which that exemption was based, and that was that a review was being conducted.

So it is obvious certainly to the Australian Democrats and I hope others in this chamber that yet another exemption is not an acceptable solution to address marital discrimination in student assistance schemes. At no point over the past 13 years was it proposed that student assistance schemes be permanently exempted from the SDA, although there were such opportunities, I believe, in 1984 and 1991. However, the coalition government has decided to pursue this option—that is, of seeking a permanent exemption.

I note that the bill before us has passed through the House of Representatives without any member of parliament citing the particular report. We may be complaining, Senator Carr and Senator Margetts, that we have not seen a copy of this report but what about those members of the lower house who had to debate and make a decision on this bill with no knowledge of that report? It certainly does highlight the scrutiny and the nature of the Senate.

But when this was raised in the House the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Mr Abbott, did brush aside this concern—that is, that no report had been cited or read—and he claimed that the government was preparing the report and it would be entirely consistent with the legislation that is before us today.

How can this be possible when the government has not been consistent in its own treatment of de facto couples? De facto status will enable a young person to establish independence for the purposes of the proposed common youth allowance, yet students will not be able to similarly establish their independence in this manner. So it seems a bit unusual and somewhat unfair to treat students in a different manner from that of young people generally.

It would be highly unlikely that the provisions made under the common youth allowance legislation to avoid `rorting the system' could not be readily applied to student assistance schemes as appropriate data matching and fraud checks are already in place.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) During the 1996 calendar year what sums were provided to (a) government and (b) non‐government schools within the postcode areas of (i) 7310, (ii) 7315, (iii) 7316, (iv) 7320, (v) 7321, (vi) 7322, (vii) 7330, (viii) 7331, and (ix) 7256.
(2) In each instance in part (1), what was the (a) sum, (b) location and (c) purpose of each grant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Commonwealth schools programmes operate on annual calendar year funding arrangements. Details of grants provided to both government and non‐government schools in the selected postcodes for the calendar year 1996 are provided at Attachment A.

Commonwealth grants for government schools are paid as block grants to the State and Territory Governments. The Capital Grants Programme is the only government schools programme under which the States and Territories are required to report expenditure on individual schools. These details are provided at Attachment A.
Grants under the National Equity Program for Schools, operational in 1996, is paid to block grant authorities and the Commonwealth does not hold information on grants to individual schools.
